  3. DISGUSTING!!! It mostly faded but did nt completely the hair color. Not to mention THE SMELL!! The smell lingered throughout the house for DAYS. 4-5 washes in, my hair still smells!!! The smell is so strong and nauseating! Suck up the bad hair color!
  4. Did not work to get black dye out of my hair, even though I haven't dyed it in a few months.
  5. This stuff worked great. I'd gone super red and it just didn't look right on me, plus my roots were bright pink, which... no... do not like. I used this product and then dyed my hair light neutral brown and it worked great. Yes, you can smell the sulfur for a long time afterwards but it's worth it if you hate your current dye job, as I did.<br /><br />So here's one thing to be aware of: the mix is super liquid! I mean, like no thicker than skim milk. If you're like me and have dyed your hair at home for a long time, this is a shock to your normal routine. I got it everywhere. It's super runny and does NOT thicken like hair dye. Just thought I'd warn you.
  6. I loved this product, it stripped the brown dye off my naturally strawberry blond hair and the hair felt good after. I did use a hot oil treatment afterwards but it's optional. The smell didn't bother me one bit despite what other reviews say, boxed hair color smells much stronger. I followed instructions to take my time rinsing the hair out and I believe it is an important step for the product to work as advertised.
  7. Looks like it's worked on some people but it hardly changed my hair at all. Still looks pretty much exactly the same and I followed directions exactly. I put a cheaper box of dye down to get this and that was a huge mistake. Wont be buying again, I definitely learned my lesson. Just made my hair smell bad
  8. I wanted to strip my black dye off my hair, so I purchased opps and it works. I had to purchase 2 of them because I've been dyeing my hair black for a long time and it didn't strip it all off on the first one but the second time it worked. I must say that this stuff smells bad and even after you wash your hair it still stinks. It takes about three different days of washing before the smell is completely off.
  9. One thing that I didn't know until I had bought and opened the product, &#34;Color Oops is not designed for and will not perform on direct color dyes such as bright pinks, blues, greens, lavendars, purples, etc.&#34; I had red in my hair, and it turned it into a dark purple color. I was hoping that it would just take the red out and leave me with my weird orangy-bleached hair color so I could re-color it. I had to go to the salon to get it fixed. Here are my before and after pictures.
  10. I've been coloring my hair dark reddish brownish black for many years, and it's always been lighter and brighter on top than at the middle and bottom--which I hated! It had been about 5 weeks since my last at-home coloring, and I was tired of the uneven results so I wanted to try this product to attempt to get a more even result the next time I colored. My hair is VERY fine and can't take the abuse of bleach, so honestly I was slightly terrified to try this. But I'm glad I did. Even though I have long hair, one box was enough. I started at the ends and went up to the roots. I wouldn't say that it smelled good, but it was not nearly as strong as many other hair colors I've used. As it was processing I was nervous that it would get too light so I rinsed it out after 15 minutes instead of 20. (I probably should have done the strand test beforehand). I was surprised at how well it took the color out (I followed the rinsing and conditioning instructions). It was no where near my natural color (which is an ashy light brown) except at my roots which were unchanged, but I didn't expect it return my hair to its natural color anyway. The result on my colored hair was a an orangey-blonde color; but it was still brighter on top of my head and probably 1-2 shades darker near the ends and underneath. I was a little disappointed that it didn't turn out more even. But the next day it was a little less bright on top--thank goodness. I read another review that said she let the mixture process on her ends for 10 minutes before applying to the rest of her hair and now I wish I would have done that.
  11. I have used this product 3 or 4 times in the past few years, and it works fantastically. It removes the darkest colors, right down to the tips of my hair which have several layers of different hair color accumulated on them. Does it smell? YES. The smell is pretty awful, and this last time was the worst. I don't know if they changed the formula slightly or if it was just me, but it hung around for a few days, despite repeated washing. So yeah, be prepared for that. Also, if you've used any hair color that had any lightening agents in it at all, you will end up with a brassy tone after the color is removed. The product removes all artificial color, but it cannot redeposit color that has been previously bleached out. Even if you've only tried to go a shade lighter or redder, you will have this issue. Be prepared to re-color with an ash-toned or &#34;cool&#34; color. Also, if you're going to recolor your hair within a few days of using Color Oops, use a shade at least 2 shades lighter than what you want the result to be. The shaft of your hair will be wide open and will suck up color like a sponge. This past time I wanted a light medium brown, so I colored my hair with a box of dark ash blonde. The directions also say to use a deep conditioner after using Color Oops, and I would second that. While my hair wasn't wrecked, it was markedly drier.<br />All in all, it's a great product. I would highly recommend it to anyone wanting to fix a coloring mistake.
  12. I've used 2 boxes one at night and one the next morning. My hair is now a brassy orange/red. It looks terrible & was isn't anywhere near where I wanted it. I followed everyones tips and read all the reviews. I am very frustrated. DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY!
  13. Purchased this product out of desperation a week after a bad dye job. I was hesitant to put anything else on my hair, fearing more damage, but couldn't have been more pleased by the results. The process is a little time consuming, but WELL worth it!! Not only did all the dye dissolve from my hair, but my hair was not damaged at all. Beware: the smell is a bit strong, like that of a perm, but it does go away after shampooing. Be sure to use a good conditioner afterwards. I used Nutrogena Triple Action conditioner, left it on my hair for 5 minutes. My hair is shiny, feels soft, and looks really healthy. THANK YOU to whomever created this miracle dye-removing product!!!!!!!!
  14. I love this stuff. I was extremely skeptical at first, but decided I had nothing to lose. I dyed my hair Manic Panic's Atomic Turquoise a week ago and got sick of the color really quickly. I bought some Color Oops, but when I got home and read the directions it clearly says it will not work on bright pinks, blues, greens or purples, but I did a test strip and it worked! And quickly too. It smells, but not as bad as bleach. It's very easy to use. It didn't itch or irritate my scalp and there was no visible damage. I don't know how they do it, but this stuff is amazing. Highly recommended.
  15. I've now used this product a few times, and have learned: 1. When they say rinse, RINSE! The package says it will undo hair color in 20 minutes, but that's just the application time. You'll easily spend another half hour or more just rinsing your hair. The rinsing is very, very important, as it removes the old hair dye molecules from the hair shaft. If you don't rinse enough, those molecules will stay on your hair, waiting to re-oxidize (and there are lots of things out there, not just peroxide, that will \\"oxidize\\" those molecules, turning your hair dark). So RINSE...until you think your arms are going to fall off. 2. You'll need to seal the hair shaft afterwards, some how, some way. There will be some stubborn old dye molecules still stuck to your hair (especially if you didn't rinse as much as necessary), and you do not want to reactivate them, or your hair will return to the color you were trying to get rid of. So, you'll want to create some sort of barrier between those old molecules and anything that can possibly oxidize them. That means lots of protein products, and lots and lots of conditioning.
  16. I was soooo excited to take the color out of my hair, I've had it since October, and it is now December. Color Oops says it will take it out if it is a day, or a year old, so that shouldn't matter anyway. I googled ways to get rid of the color, vinegar, crappy shampoo, and Color Oops were all recommended. Color Oops had AMAZING reviews, and those that seemed bad, seemed like it was the users fault. I waited two weeks before finally being brave enough to go and get some, but I couldn't find it at Sally's, WalMart, Target, etc. I finally found some at Walgreens, and I bought two boxes (thick, long hair) I applied it, did EVERYTHING the box said to, I washed it really good because everyone seemingly said that that part was very, very important. Nothing. I'm now out $26, with my hair untouched. ABSOLUTELY UNTOUCHED. It didn't do a THING to it. I'm absolutely disappointed. I've contacted DeveloPlus explaining my situation, I will follow up IF they reply. I envy those of you who this worked for :/ I wish I had that luck.
  17. my hair was dyed dark brown and I wanted to use this to lift it a couple shades closer to my natural color (dark blonde) so I could color it again. I followed the instructions (lots of waiting and rinsing) and ended up with...dark brown. At most about 1/2 a shade lighter. The only thing I got out of this was a stinky bathroom and hair that felt like yarn. I definitely do not recommend using this, I've tried other color removers that work a lot better. Maybe if your hair is not a super dark shade it would lighten better but overall a giant waste of time and money.
  18. Everyone keeps talking about the rinse rinse rinsing. Well, why don't you just use some of the shampoo's that stop and get all the molecules out of the hair in the shampoo. I have used DeveloPlus Chemical De-Activating Shampoo for years. Stops the processing and get all the chemicals out. Anyone have any other ideas? I rated because I had too post this question. I will rate after tryng Oops.<br />tks
  19. Color Oops took my hair from a horrid purple burgundy to a light copper red (I'm blonde naturally). The burgundy was supposed to only be some low lights but the salon had put too much in my hair and I looked like something out of a Halloween movie for the last 2 weeks! It is now much better as I am now blonde with coppery low lights.<br />Yes, the stuff stinks, but it also works to get rid of very dark frightening hair dye. One also has to follow the instructions completely even though the rinsing part is very tedious and turns you into a prune.<br />My thought is that the folks who used it and found the color back when they woke in the morning, didn't follow the rinsing instructions. I washed 4 times and rinsed, while scrubbing very hard, the full 5 minutes each time. Also, this product will not correct a bad lightening nor will it work on the new fangled colors which are not used with a lifter originally, lifter being a peroxide. It has to be oxidized coloring.<br />I am very pleased with this product and now know that I cannot have any salon do anything to my hair from here on out. Thank you Clairol!
  20. My hair is naturally a dark brown, I have dyed it many times and more recently I dyed it a much lighter redish light brown. Then, wanting my old color back, I used garnier natural dark brown which turned my hair a hideous jet black. I came across this product and used it the next day. The smell isn't even that bad and it worked great! My hair is now restored the the red light brown it was before. Great product.
  21. I used the new John Frieda foam hair color in a lovely light brown shade, my natural color. I needed to color my grays. Well, to my utter shock & disbelief, the color turned my hair dark, dark brown which looked plum in the sunlight. I was horrified. I have never, ever worn my hair this dark in my life. So, I remembered seeing a coupon for Color Oops and found some at the local retailer. I bought the 'extra strength' version as that is all they carried. First, if you buy this product, be prepared as it has tons of directions and hints. It takes time to sort through them and you'll likely want to read them several times before you even consider beginning. When I mixed the two chemicals together, I immediately thought it smelled like a home perm. It's stinky, but in a milder way. It stinks, but it worked. Probably the worst part about this product is the rinsing. But, do it. It works. When I was done, my hair was back to its normal color AND my grays were still covered. I did have really bad split ends though, which I admit I had before I used this product, but it definitely made them worse and much more noticable. And, that perm smell was still around two days later. Thankfully, I had an appointment for a haircut a few days later & the split ends are gone now. I'm going to be using a heavy conditioner for at least the next few weeks to restore the moisture back to my hair. But, if I had it to do all over again, I would still buy this product. It truly works.
  22. okay so i purchased this at a local walgreens since it was easier, and i had blue dye in my very lightly bleached blonde hair and this helped to remove most of it. there is still a hint of a light blue-ish hue but i like it so i dont care.<br />!!!!warning!!!! this stuff is rank smelling like my whole house smelled like rotten eggs for more than a day. so my suggestion is if you can get someone to help you put this on but outside and then dispose of the remaining contents to outside garbage, and until its ready to wash out just sit outside until you rinse it out. trust me it will help also be ready to spend a lot of time rinsing this out it takes more then one shampoo-ing to get the smell off my hair. just wash your hair with a couple different shampoo's if you can and it should help get rid of the smell.<br />also make sure you use a conditioner so your hair doesn't get too dry. good luck
  23. I used this product 2 weeks ago, and I absolutely recommend it. I have brown hair with some gray, and I dyed my hair too dark - it was supposed to be dark brown, but it came out black. I waited a month for it to fade, but it didn't. Finally, I tried Color Oops, and it worked perfectly. I followed the directions exactly and even tacked on an extra 5 full minutes of rinsing. My hair was kind of an ashy blond color (lighter than natural color) for about 12 hours, but then it darkened to brown - exactly my natural shade. My hair was dry for a day or two, but not bad. And I can still smell the terrible Color Oops smell a little bit sometimes (like, when I am washing my hair). But I would absolutely recommend this 100%.
  24. This product removed the excess color from the ends of my hair, but the sulphur smell lingered even after washing several times. To get rid of the rotten egg smell I opened up 10 vitamin C capsules and combined the powder with shampoo to create a paste and then washed my hair with it. After washing I rinsed my hair with hot water really well BEFORE using conditioner. I think it's really important to rinse well before using conditioner which seals the cuticle of the hair. Hope this helps those who are sick of the awful smell.
  25. I have been coloring my hair at home for almost 20 years and have generally stuck with the same product & colors. Any time that I have strayed from the tried & true, a disaster has ensued... which has usually been correctable after a 911 call placed to the product hotline. Recently, however, I tried a Garnier product that looked very similar to my usual Clairol auburn shade, only to have my hair turn a hideous FUSCIA-MAGENTA!? I tried reapplying my usual shade over it, which did even out the color, but it was really dark with fuscia-magenta accents - YUCK! I went online to look for another solution, read about OOPS, and gave it a shot. I followed the instructions very carefully and EVERY TRACE of color came out, leaving me with an even, strawberry blonde base to re-color. THIS STUFF WORKS!!! NOTE: be sure to follow all directions, including the ones that tell you how to condition your hair, choose a lighter shade when re-coloring, & ONLY allowing the new color to process for 5 MINUTES before rinsing (or you will wind up having dark hair again & repeating the whole process!)
  26. Ok so I read all these reviews and looked on youtube for video reviews and decided to just go for it. I had dyed my hair red about 4 times and was just tired of the upkeep and not finding a box color that was as awesome as the stylist's color. I want to go back to a more natural color so I don't have to worry about roots so much and I didn't want to keep putting dye on it and I definitely didn't want to bleach the hell out of it because that's why I went red in the first place, to stop the blonde damage. From the other reviews and my experience I'm going to safely say that if you're currently red, used to be blonde and use Color Oops, your hair is going to turn...pumpkin spice, is the best color I can think of. It's not horrible, and I've heard that the color tends to change a day or 2 in so I'm letting my hair rest before I re-dye it a very light ash blonde since I want a medium ash result. FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS! I'm so tired of hearing bad reviews or mixed reviews when the person didn't even do exactly what the directions said to do! Work quickly to put it on your hair then leave it on for 20 minutes, shampoo then rinse your hair for 20 mins and then shampoo and rinse for another 5+ minutes, then use a good conditioner. My hair felt pretty decent and I used an overnight repair serum before I went to bed just as an extra precaution. The directions even give you caution and advice on how to re-dye your hair because your hair will be really porous. A neutral protein filler at Sally's is decently priced and you get more than one use out of it plus you can use it as a once a week conditioner (you'll need to buy a spray bottle in order to use it). It states in the directions that it does not work on fantasy colors and do not use heat or cool air while it's processing. It did what I expected and I'm fairly happy with the results. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is only due to the smell, and I didn't really mind it considering it's a small price to pay to get this redout.
  27. I was attempting to remove very dark brown dye from my blonde hair. The 1st and 2nd treatment of color oops didn't do anything, even though I followed the directions word-for-word. My 3rd attempt finally yielded results. It took my hair from very dark brown to light brown.<br /><br />Here's what made the difference the 3rd time around:<br /><br />&#34;Apply quickly&#34; really means get in it your hair as fast as humanly possible. Once it's mixed it begins to lose effectiveness. You need to get it on your hair ASAP to get really good results.<br /><br />&#34;Stay out of a draft&#34; really means sit in front of a heater. You will need to keep your hair WARM to get good results while you use color oops.<br /><br />&#34;Rinse well&#34; really means don't bother using Color Oops unless you're going to rinse for at least 25 minutes under warm water. No cheating. 20 minutes of rinsing won't cut it. Also, don't use cold water, it won't work.<br /><br />I found out later that the reason I had such a difficult time was because I used a cheap/bad dye. If you used a really cheap dye, your going to have a hard time. My hair stylist said that cheap dyes are nearly impossible to remove without bleaching, even for them. I give this product 5 stars because once I figured out how to use it, it worked well enough and I was able to avoid beaching my hair.
  28. Okay-my natural color hair is dark brown--I am half portugese, so its pretty dark. Over the years I have had highlights put in here and there and in the fall I usually put a brown dye in it for the winter months. In May I put highlights in that turned a dark strawberry blond and then in June went to do it again and it was too much. Most of the top of my hair was a strawberry blonde and the roots were dark and the old part that had grown out was an orange color--not good. So I got a dark color from the beauty supply and it turned black and not a good black. It was black and in some areas it had a blue tint. I washed my hair with dawn dish soap for a few days and was out in the sun and the black was not fading but some strands were getting more blue. Every morning when I looked in the mirror I wanted to cry. I havn't felt like this about my hair since high school. This morning I got online and read about color oops and I was hesitant but I kept reading---then I thought well, my hair will probably turn out orange, but orange is better than black with a blue tint--so off to the store I went. I bought a box of light brown hair dye just in case the orange was a little much. Anyways I followed the directions and when its all said and done, my hair turned out BEAUTIFUL!! The black is gone. The bluish greenish color is gone! I decided not to even put the light brown dye in. My hair has not looked this good in years. Honestly! The smell is like sulfer and even as I type, I can smell it, but that is nothing compared to having goth hair. I could not have planned this better if I tried. I never write reviews but I know that when it comes to things like hair color its always good to know how to get out of a mess sometimes. And dark hair I think is a little bit harder to dye than blonde because of the ash tones and red tones. I hope you find this review helpful and I guess you just have to weigh your options, and for me, red would have been a lot better than black/blue. Good luck.
  29. I am a natural blonde and dyed my hair RED for Halloween. After the party, I went to dark auburn. I have used dark auburn before and typically it fades from my hair pretty quickly. This time, it didn't thanks to the bright red underneath. I decided to give this a shot to get the funky maroon it tuned into out. It DOES lighten - but do not expect to get to your natural hair color. If you do, consider you one of the lucky ones! I ended up doing two applications and got it to orange. Reds seem to always be difficult to counteract - my solution was to go out & get a dark ash blonde to tone down the orange. It is nice to have a product to lighten your hair that is without bleach. Trying this with bleach probably would have destroyed my hair. The smell, yeah, it smells. But honestly it was the hair dye that made my eyes water. It wasn't as bad as I was expecting. So did it strip some of the color out of my hair? Yes. Did it restore my natural hair color prior to the dye? No - not even after two applications AND following the 20 minute rinse instructions. Did I have to re-dye it to get the funky color out? Yes. So yes, it does somewhat what it advertises, but don't count on it to be your one shot cure. Be prepared for orange or something else depending on your hair type & dye color you are looking to get out. I didn't get my natural hair color back, and still have some red in it, but it is lighter and more of a natural color that I can definitely work with - and my hair feels very soft & silky.
  30. I used this after coloring my hard a deep red/brown. I liked the color, but wanted to go back to my original. I used this in hopes of removing the dye. It did, but left my hair brassy and unnatural looking. As the label warns, your resulting color is whatever is left of your original color after the dye strips it. My hair was slightly damaged after using it, but should be alright after a bit of deep conditioning. The semi-permanent dye I purchased to color my hair with after using this product stuck as well as Color Oops said it would, and the color is definitely darker than the box. Overall, it did it's job but I am knocking one star off for the TERRIBLE sewage-like smell that it gives off and leaves both in your hair and in the space in which you used it, and I am knocking off another because they claim to bring you back to your \\"natural\\" color, but only mention INSIDE the box that you may never get your natural color back as the dye used may have ruined it. It's a bit misleading.
  31. Long story, short: I've been dyeing my naturally dark blonde hair dark brown hair for quite a while now (like, years!), but wanted to go back to blonde. I thought I would try Color Oops, and if it didn't work, I'd resort to bleach.<br /><br />Well, after two applications, I managed to get up to a nice, warm light-brown color! My hair was dry, but not super damaged. From there, I was able to bleach just once back up to blonde. A month has gone by and I'm still blonde! It's slightly brassy, but I'm using all those blue products, which is keeping it in check. Oh, and my hair is far less damaged than if I had tried to bleach from dark brown up to blonde!
  32. I'm going to write this review it two parts. I will come back and update in a couple days. Because your hair darkens after using it. I am a natural golden blonde, fair skinned gal with light green eyes. One day being a little bored and looking to change my look (as well as save money) I decided to dye my hair Loreal Medium Golden Brown. Mistake #1. My hair turned too orange/brassy. I should've picked an ash or neutral shade to tone down the gold in my hair. So wanting to change it a little darker and make my eyes stand out, I chose a non-permanent dark burgundy so it could fade out if I didn't like it. Mistake #2. This made me look older and was not at all flattering with my skin tone. Enter the Color Oops. After reading literally 100's of reviews on this site as well as Walgreen's (they have over 400 reviews there), I felt I had enough info, tips and courage to try the Color Oops. I purchased 2 boxes because I have thick hair to the middle of my back. Did a patch test to see if I was allergic. I also did a strand test a couple days before using it on my head. I mixed an equal capful of each 2 oz bottle and did a 15 minute and a 20 minute test on strands. I gave myself a haircut a couple days earlier after the dye jobs so I used this hair. The strands looked like they had almost all of the color removed and were very blonde with the solution. I washed/rinsed and put them aside noticing the next day they darkened up quite a bit, to a dark blonde almost brunette but without red tones. I still went ahead and used the Color Oops. Bring a radio to listen to while in bathroom/shower because using this product takes some time. I mixed first bottle and applied to head. It's very runny and be careful shaking it gently, gasses build up in bottle and spray out a little when you open it. Don't get it in your eyes! I used almost both bottles, one would not have been enough for my head. I also kept my hair untangled and combed it with a comb to apply the product evenly. Then I used a shower cap and timed it for 20 minutes. I made sure there were no drafts and I sat in a warm room. The smell was not as bad as people were saying. One girl in her review wrote it smells like \\"lemon fart\\". Perfect description! I thought Yellowstone hot springs were bad, but honestly I don't think Color Oops smelled as awful as I'd expected. After 20 minutes I got into shower and I rinsed it from hair, shampooed/rinsed/shampooed, then rinsed for 20 minutes with very warm water. Rinsing is key. This was actually the worst part for me. I wanted the water to be very warm/hot, cold would close the hair shaft and you won't be able to rinse dye molecules out. I actually felt like I was going to pass out (kinda scary) from the heat and smell together and 20 minutes is a long time. Radio helps. After all of that I applied Original Hair Mayonnaise Conditioner and sat for 20 minutes with it on my hair. Then rinsed some more. When I towel dried hair I noticed almost all color was removed, roots were brassy/light blonde and ends were dark blonde/light brunette. I was happy it was almost back to normal. It has now been an hour and my hair has darkened up almost to the color it was before this whole ordeal. It has less burgundy but it is a reddish brunette color. The ends are dark and roots are still orangey/brassy, like a copper penny. Wonderful? Not so much. But my hair feels healthy like before, doesn't feel damaged. But I always use lots of shower conditioner and leave in conditioners. It also doesn't smell sulfury anymore, maybe just when it's wet. So I will wait a couple days before I use any more products to try to fix my hair. I also think it will darken up some more. Honestly girls, if you have gorgeous hair to begin with, don't mess with it! But if you're reading this, you're probably in the same boat as me, and want to try to fix a mistake you made by trying to do your own hair. So bottom line, Color Oops didn't work for me. It didn't bring it back ANYWHERE close to my natural color. And I followed directions to a tee. I also used the product a week after the colorings, and one was non-permanent dye. I had high hopes for Color Oops but I'm left disappointed. I guess I'm in minority though. So if you feel your hair can't get any worse, maybe give it a go. But if you have the money, have a professional fix your hair. I wasted $28 altogether using this product. And I'm back in square one.

I left it on for a total of 40 minutes and it lifted my hair almost back to the original blonde hair color that I was dying it before. Its now a really light brown, almost strawberry blonde. I also almost think it left my hair in better shape than before. It did NO damage to my hair at all! I really REALLY recommend it!!!

The rinsing is a pain but it got me to the light brown I wanted in the first place! I have no intentions of re-dying. I gave it a 4 because it dried my hair out but I did a 30 minute hot olive oil treatment and my hair is pretty close to where it was before.   43. My natural haircolor is dark brown. I went back to CVS and lo and behold, the same clerk was there. I told her I wanted to try it. I bought 2 OOPS extra strenth, since my hair is medium length and moderately thick. I had to wash my hair several times to get rid of the smell from my hair. When my husband came home from work the next morning he thought sewage was coming up from the pipes and freaked out. BUT my hair is a natural brown shade. Not streaky at all. I'd say it's worth it considering the smell.

I'm the maid of honor in my best friend's wedding next week, so I was upset when Aveda basically told me I had no options. I did some research and found Oops. I was freaked out about trying it because if it didn't work, I was going to look stranger than I already did. I did a strand test and the color looked okay, so I applied it to my whole head. It developed very fast. In four minutes it had lightened to about the shade I wanted, so I ran and jumped in the shower and washed it out. It looks so much better.   50. BACKGROUND<br />As a naturally medium blonde 20-something, I'd been talked into going red by my salon stylist. I loved it, but 8 months down the road I was frustrated with having to touch it up every few weeks, let alone not being able to consistently find the right shade in the drug store (sorry, but I'm not paying a stylist obscene amounts of cash to do my hair every few weeks). I'm a beginner when it comes to color and didn't realize how difficult it would be to try to take my hair back to blonde after having it red for many months.<br /><br />I asked my stylist, who said that she could strip it, which would be time-consuming, damaging and expensive. The other option was to highlight my hair repeatedly over the course of a year or so while my natural hair grew back in (again, expensive). I thought, surely there has to be some other way...<br /><br />PREPARATION FOR COLOR OOPS<br />Then I found Color Oops online. I read hundreds of reviews on multiple Web sites, some good and some frightening, and picked up lots of usage tips along the way. I proceeded to purchase two boxes of Color Oops, two boxes of hair color (Nice n Easy - Natural Dark Neutral Blonde and Natural Lightest Golden Brown) in case I had an \\"omg\\" moment, a shower cap, a wide-toothed comb and a thermal conditioning treatment (heavy duty conditioner). If you use Color Oops, I highly recommend making sure you have all these items handy. Also, read the box insert, and know it like the back of your hand. This is a must.<br /><br />Make sure to do a strand test. Cut out a small piece of your hair and just do it, or you'll be sorry later. Check it every five minutes so you can see the various shades of change and decide on the best time for your hair. They recommend no longer than 20 minutes. Based on mine, I saw my hair change from red to blonde after 20 minutes and elected to leave it on for the full amount of time.<br /><br />THE PROCESS<br />Still, I was super nervous as I prepared the mixture and dumped it on my hair. It is a thin mixture, maybe a bit thicker than water but not by much, so be careful with the dribbles. I didn't notice any bleaching effect on the red robe I was wearing. As everyone else has said, it has a very strong odor - citrus and sulfur, so be prepared. I made sure to spread the mixture quickly and evenly, using the wide-toothed comb to ensure that my hair was fully saturated, then put the shower cap on to help \\"lock\\" in the product. I avoided being in cool areas of my house, as the insert said this could cause it not to process correctly (also a good reason to use the shower cap). I'd recommend checking your hair periodically, even after the strand test, so you don't let it go too long.<br /><br />Rinsing it out was a breeze in the shower. This is the most important part of the process. I kept the water warm, rinsed for several minutes, shampooed and rinsed for several minutes, and repeated once more. Rinse until your water gets cold, no joke! Your hair may feel a little stiff at this point, so use your restoring conditioner after the second shampoo. I had some left over from an older Nice n Easy kit and it worked better than the thermal treatment I bought specifically for this purpose (read on to find out why I ended up having to condition twice).<br /><br />THE MOMENT OF TRUTH<br />After I got out of the shower I could tell right away that my hair was looking pretty bleached blonde and much lighter than my natural color, but probably due to the previous dyeing I'd done (most over-the-counter permanent dyes include a bleaching agent, no matter what color you choose). I dried it using my blow dryer and it came out looking pale and brassy - almost a strawberry blonde. My boyfriend said, \\"Your hair is kind of orange...\\" I didn't think it was hideous, but not exactly what I had envisioned. It didn't seem damaged, either, though I had very healthy hair to start with.<br /><br />REDYEING AFTER COLOR OOPS<br />So I started thinking about that boxof blonde hair color I bought to use after the Color Oops, in case it didn't turn out. Color Oops recommends using a color filler if you choose to dye right after the color removal process. They also advise that you choose a lighter, warmer shade than that of what you are trying to achieve and say not to let it process for more than several minutes. I skipped the color filler and applied just the color, noticing that by the time I'd applied it to my whole head, it had already \\"taken\\" and rushed to rinse it out, but it was too late. After no more than just a few minutes, the blonde hair color had turned my hair a distinct brown, and on the ashy side (even though it was labeled a \\"neutral\\" shade). That wasn't the hair color's fault, though - it was mine. The box insert is not joking. Use a color filler and/or buy at least a couple shades warmer and lighter than your desired end result if you are dyeing right after Color Oops. So if you're looking to go medium/dark blonde, buy a golden light blonde (or even lightest blonde).<br /><br />COLOR OOPS... TAKE TWO!<br />Luckily, I had bought the second box of Color Oops, did another strand test, and decided to leave it in for only 15 minutes this time. I got the same result as the first Oops application (glowing blonde hair), and still little, if any, damage. Stinky, though. I don't notice the smell one day after, if that's any consolation.<br /><br />THE AFTER GLOW<br />Realize that the rinsing process is absolutely the most important part of making Color Oops work (yes, I'm reiterating, but honestly it can't be repeated enough). Even after what I thought was excessive rinsing, I did notice that my color darkened overnight, meaning that the first application probably would have done the same thing if I'd been patient. I am still blonde, but not back to my natural caramel blonde. It appears very golden with some glowing reddish tones, which could be from the previous dyeing, but definitely toned down after just 8 hours. I have actually received compliments today on the new color, and told people that I had my hair stripped at the salon. They commented that it didn't appear damaged at all. The results are that good. Just be aware that you will likely have some darkening up to 24 hours after you complete the process (and also take this into account if you are redyeing).<br /><br />THE END?<br />Sorry this was so long. I learned quite a bit about Color Oops by reading reviews and realize that this information is invaluable to other people who are thinking about taking the risk to get their hair back to normal (or at least close to it). I hope the detail in this review helps you to relax and embark on your Color Oops adventure!of blonde hair color I bought to use after the Color Oops, in case it didn't turn out. Color Oops recommends using a color filler if you choose to dye right after the color removal process. They also advise that you choose a lighter, warmer shade than that of what you are trying to achieve and say not to let it process for more than several minutes. I skipped the color filler and applied just the color, noticing that by the time I'd applied it to my whole head, it had already \\"taken\\" and rushed to rinse it out, but it was too late. After no more than just a few minutes, the blonde hair color had turned my hair a distinct brown, and on the ashy side (even though it was labeled a \\"neutral\\" shade). That wasn't the hair color's fault, though - it was mine. The box insert is not joking. Use a color filler and/or buy at least a couple shades warmer and lighter than your desired end result if you are dyeing right after Color Oops. So if you're looking to go medium/dark blonde, buy a golden light blonde (or even lightest blonde).<br /><br />COLOR OOPS... TAKE TWO!<br />Luckily, I had bought the second box of Color Oops, did another strand test, and decided to leave it in for only 15 minutes this time. I got the same result as the first Oops application (glowing blonde hair), and still little, if any, damage. Stinky, though. I don't notice the smell one day after, if that's any consolation.<br /><br />THE AFTER GLOW<br />Realize that the rinsing process is absolutely the most important part of making Color Oops work (yes, I'm reiterating, but honestly it can't be repeated enough). Even after what I thought was excessive rinsing, I did notice that my color darkened overnight, meaning that the first application probably would have done the same thing if I'd been patient. I am still blonde, but not back to my natural caramel blonde. It appears very golden with some glowing reddish tones, which could be from the previous dyeing, but definitely toned down after just 8 hours. I have actually received compliments today on the new color, and told people that I had my hair stripped at the salon. They commented that it didn't appear damaged at all. The results are that good. Just be aware that you will likely have some darkening up to 24 hours after you complete the process (and also take this into account if you are redyeing).<br /><br />THE END?<br />Sorry this was so long. I learned quite a bit about Color Oops by reading reviews and realize that this information is invaluable to other people who are thinking about taking the risk to get their hair back to normal (or at least close to it). I hope the detail in this review helps you to relax and embark on your Color Oops adventure!

My husband talked me into dying it dark red and i quickly grew tired of it because the up keep was just to much with my blonde roots growing in. I tried everything to get the dye to fade, its been over a month since i last dyed it and it faded to a medium redish brown. I wanted to get it to my natural medium/dark golden blonde without stripping my hair or paying an expensive salon. I bought color oops hearing that it doesnt damage your hair and takes the colour off.. I wish it lighted it a little more, especially since i am still left with a bright orange which i have no idea how to cover without going back darker.. But i think if you start with a brown it will work wonders for you.. As for if your starting out with redish hair like i did.. make sure you ahve a back up plan because this orange hair is not a great look.

  63. So I've been highlighing my hair since 11th grade and I'm not really sure what color it is at this point, light brown probably...Anyways, with the economy the way it is, starting to resent the $100 every 6-8 weeks for a professional salon, I decided a few weeks ago to go slightly brown-ish (Loreal Light Ash Brown). It came out beautiful, but within 2 weeks it had washed out and I was Real Housewives of Beverly Hills Blonde again. So day befofe yesterday, I figured I would use Medium Ash Brown instead. Went back to the CVS and bought Oops, and I'm glad I did. If you're used to doing your own color, it comes out a lot quicker (not as gel like) as regular hair color, but it doesn't drip. I followed the directions to a T, keeping it on the full 20 minutes. Then set my timer and jumped in the shower for my 20 minute rinse session. That's the hardest part. Someone before said they almost fainted, and I understand. Even with me turning it to warm, standing under the shower head for 20 minutes gets HOT! But I didn't want to ever see Elvira again, so I rinsed and rinsed. Put conditioner on for five minutes at the end, and when I blow dried my hair is back to the pretty light ash brown from 2 weeks ago. So very happy with the fix I can't stand it! Just stand in front of a fan when you're done and drink ice water! I could not be happier!

My natural hair color was a light to medium brown. The Color Oops not only removed the current hair color I had used but it also removed all of the original hair color I had also used.   67. I have naturally light red hair that I have been dyeing black for about three years now. Everyone (including professionals) told me it would be impossible to come back from black without serious damage to my hair. I did a lot of internet research and decided to take my chances on color oops. Yes, it stinks, but it's not unbearable, and I didnt notice the smell lingering in my hair afterwards. I did the strand test first--very important--to make sure your hair isnt gonna melt or something tragic. I was happy with the strand test and went full steam ahead on my whole head. It is thinner than hair dye-so be careful for running down your face. One bottle was sufficient enough to thoroughly wet my shoulder length hair. I let it process for the full twenty minutes with the cap on. I followed the instructions about repeated shampooing and rinsing. When I was finished, my hair did not feel damaged at all, maybe even a little softer than before the process. When it was dry, I was back to my natural red, even having nautral highlights and lowlights. It took every speck of the jet jet black color that I had been using for three years right out of my hair. I highly recommend this product, but I also highly recommend the strand test for many reasons. First, you need to know how long to process it for the result you desire. Second, no woman wants to fry or melt her hair. Third, some dyes have metallic salts in them and unless you are sure that what you are dyeing your hair with does not......you could seriously damage your hair with the remover. Good Luck everyone----I love this stuff

  72. I have a lot of thick hair that's cut into a chin-length bob and I had been coloring it soft black for over 6 months to hide my grays and also blend in a bad color job that left sections of my hair a strange red color. The soft black had been doing a great job but I just turned 43 and it's summertime and I felt like it was too harsh for my age and time of the year so I read a lot of reviews and watched a lot of videos on YouTube and decided that for the price, Color Oops was the one I was going to try. My hairdresser was afraid to use anything on my hair to take the black out and she suggested lightening it through session after session of weaving. I was never convinced that I was going to be satisfied with those results and I can truthfully say that for $12, I am happier with my results. Let me just say that I have really strong hair that can take a real BEATING but that my scalp is on the sensitive side. I did not do the sensitivity test or color test either....which I probably should have done but I was eager to get the black out. I left the product on for 30 minutes instead of the recommended 20 BECAUSE my hair is strong and in good condition. If your hair is not like mine, you probably should not leave it on that long. I put the heat cap on and went out to my back yard in the sun because the directions say not to be anywhere in the cold or where cold air can hit your head. The secret is in the heat while it's processing AND in the amount of time you spend rinsing it out of your hair. I came in and took a shower letting the water hit my head 30 minutes making sure it was all out and also shampooed with a dandruff shampoo one time and frizz control shampoo the second time. I was hot and tired from the hot water by the time it was all done, but I'm happy I took that long rinsing because the results were totally worth it. I also used deep conditioner that I had saved from a previous hair coloring to apply right after and also sat with my hair in a different heat cap for 20 minutes. My hair was not damaged or dried out or fried in the least. The black is completely gone from my hair. It's now a darkish brown with pleasant shades of red throughout. I've never lightened my hair anytime so there are no traces of bleaching/lightening that other people might find with their hair. The product takes all of the dark pigments out of your hair that have been deposited by coloring your hair. It does not take any bleaching/lightening pigments out of your hair because that's not what it's designed to do. The directions say you can color your hair the same day, but if you don't seal your hair with a conditioner after using Oops, then your hair is going to be VERY VERY porous and will grab the hair color like a sponge. If you have to color your hair again immediately, be sure to use the deep conditioner FIRST so your hair will not soak up the color as much. If you can wait several days in between using this product and coloring your hair, that's even better because your hair will become less porous over time. Also, be certain that you choose a hair color that is LIGHTER than the shade you are trying to become. Everyone who has used this and the company all say that if you use a dark shade to color your hair that you're going to be back in the same boat that brought you here in the first place. So IF you must recolor, go lighter. The only down-side to Color Oops is that it does smell like sulfur or rotten eggs to some extent because of the chemicals used. But there is NO bleach or ammonia! If you can open a window wherever you're applying the product, do so and be sure you have a garbage sack to throw the bottles and heat cap away after you're finished and that will help air your house out faster. Also, if you have a strongly scented conditioner or leave-in treatment to put on your hair afterward, that will also help get the smell out of your own hair. It's really NOT that bad. I asked 3 differentpeople to smell my hair after I was all done and none of them told me that I stunk. I promise, it's all okay! Just follow the package directions and read as many other reviews and tips that you can. It will remove the dark pigments from hair coloring just like it says. And if it can work on my hair, it can certainly work on yours.
  73. Ok, so my hair is naturally medium to dark blonde, I do highlights twice a year with two different warm blonde colors. When I went to get my hair highlighted this time, it came out too brassy yellow.   74. Color Oops WILL remove too much or unwanted hair color. If your hair was colored before the latest \\"oops\\", it will also remove that color, leaving you most likely with yellow-y, orange-y, and somewhat uneven hair that in most cases will require additional coloring to be transformed into something pretty;-) At this point you have two choices: 1) Immediately (possibly wearing a hat?) go to a professional salon, explain what happened, and let THEM do the job with demi-permanent color of your choice. I recommend to ask the stylist to treat your hair with a protein filler before coloring it, or better yet, do it at home right after \\"color oops\\". This is a foolproof way of getting preferred hair color and saves you quite some money, since this isn't a \\"correction\\" anymore, but a single process dye job. 2) At home - If you are coloring your hair yourself, you HAVE to have a \\"Neutral Protein Filler\\" (sally's, amazon). Use it as a leave-in conditioner BEFORE a hair dye job. The filler will restore the structure of your hair, so subsequently applied color will grab on evenly. The treatment also helps covering grey, avoid the \\"hot root\\" effect, and overly processed ends. I apply this treatment even before professional dye treatments. I am really, really pleased with the results! Less damage, better color, no oversaturation. For those going brunette: Use a NEUTRAL shade (to avoid too much red) of a medium/dark blond or light brown demi-permanent hair color or hair gloss. Put protein treatment in your hair, wait 20 min., don't rinse!!! TIP for those fearing too much red - buy the \\"UNRED\\" drops (Ricky's, Sally's, Amazon). Add a few drops (following the instructions) to the color mix, this will take care of the unwanted red. After putting the color mix on your roots, massage it through the rest of your hair, let it sit for 5-10 min. max! This should be enough time for the color to grab. Rinse, wash, rinse, deeply condition, style. Voilà, your new color! Other tip based on experience: If your hair turned very light and you want to go to a deeper brown shade, you want to use a double process. First you color with a light strawberry blonde/light golden blonde, after that you color with a neutral shade of medium/dark blonde/light brunette. This will give your hair a nice dimension and add gloss. You probably will still end up on a \\"warmer\\" side.

  80. I purchased this because I knew I wanted to go a few shades lighter... from dark brown to medium brown. The ends came out meh... still sort of coppery and a bit odd looking, but my roots turned almost bright orange (she called them hot roots). So then she had to dye the roots darker. And then she had to put in really fine highlights to try to blend it a little better and make it look less odd. In the end, she got my hair to look good, all things considered. But I couldn't have fixed it without the help of a professional. And I have a feeling that if I'd let her remove the color, I'd have had much better results. When all was said and done, it took me five hours in a salon to fix this when it probably would've taken just a few hours if I'd not used this product.<br /><br />And I can't write this review and not mention the smell. It is hideous... like rotten eggs, or as another reviewer stated, &#34;lemon fart&#34;... with a lot of emphasis on the fart side. It's two days later now and I had to throw away the towel I used and am now in the process of bleaching my bathroom to rid the smell. And I have scented candles lit everywhere. I'm not over-reacting here... I've dyed my hair at homes plenty of times, and believe me when I say this is NOT the same smell as hair dye.<br /><br />So, I kind of really want to give this two stars, but it does sort of do what it says it will, so that's why it gets three. But will I ever touch this product again? NO. Would I recommend it to friends? NO. Save yourself the trouble and save your nose the horror of smelling this stuff, and head to a salon.
  81. All this product did was make my hair, bathroom, entire apartment smell awful. I've shampooed 4+ times since applying this WORTHLESS product and I still smell like chemicals. It should say right on the box that won't work for everyone. Black dye is especially resistant to stuff like this but this didn't even make a dent, didn't even lighten it. If you've dyed your hair black and don't like it, tough. Shave your head or let it grow out but don't buy Color Oops, it won't do anything.
  82. The first time I tried Color Oops was more than a year ago when I was tired of having black hair. My natural color is a medium brown but I have been dying my hair black for about 5 years. I get bored with my hair soemtimes and so I got bored with black. I read about Color Oops online and I decided to give it a try since the Walgreens close to me carried it. I was very skeptical, becasue I knew nothing would take black (BLACK) out except bleach, and I did not want to fry my hair anymore. I tried a bottle and followed the directions with about 30 minutes in the shower for rinsing. Yes, it smells horrible but I survived. When I was rinsing my hair I could actually see the discolored water go down the drain. I was really surprised becasue the black hair color seemed like it would stay with me forever. Once I got out of the shower and looked in the mirror, my hair was actually lighter. It had a darker reddish tint to it and my roots were about 2 shades brighter than the rest of the hair. I was so happy! I repeated the process a week later and another week later and was finally happy with the results. The red tint goes away and your hair color will eventually return to a natural looking color, but rinsing is the key! Ever since then I had my natural hair color back! However I do like to experiment with hair color and since i knew Color Oops worked I dyed my hair dark brown to light brown to currently red. If I do not like the result, I just use Color Oops and the color comes right out. Currently I want to try going red, but it is quite hard to fid a bright red color that will not show up really dark on my hair after the Color Oops. Overall, it is a lifesaver and the damage to hair is very minimal. One thing I would highly suggest to anyone useing this product is to apply the Color OOps to the ends first and minimal amount to the roots. By the way, I dye my own hair and I have never gone to the salon to have it diet or strippe dor whatnot, its just cheaper that way and sois Color Oops! Two thumbs up!
  83. BACKGROUND (skip if you don't care):<br />I've had streaks of crazy colors (i.e., silver, pink, red, purple, blue, etc.) in my hair for the last 10 years but they were always somewhat hidden in the under-layers for a peek-a-boo effect that made them easy to hide if I needed to (for example, professional work events). About 7 weeks ago, I finally got bored of my color streaks and decided to jump on the ombre bandwagon. I have long, black, straight Asian hair that almost touches my elbows so I went dramatic and had it fade from natural black on top to platinum blonde at the ends. It looked exactly how I wanted it to...for all of 3 days before the blonde half started turning more brassy yellow, like a terrible dye job. In hindsight, I should have just purchased something like [[ASIN:B000O5UWTA Schwarzkopf Bonacure Color Save Silver Shampoo 8.5oz]] to tone out the brassiness but instead, I decided on what I thought was the safer and more familiar route at the time and had my stylist throw [[ASIN:B004KEX6OE Jerome Russell Punky Colour Cream Flamingo Pink]] (probably my favorite hair color of all time) over everything to cover up the yellow. It sounds bright but is actually a very deep raspberry/black cherry color, which nicely complemented my dark hair.<br /><br />PROBLEM:<br />About 2 weeks ago (i.e., 5 weeks after dying my hair Flamingo Pink), the dark fuchsia started to turn noticeably lighter and brighter than I would like. Like all semi-permanent fashion colors, I knew this color change was coming but usually had to only deal with a few chunky streaks of my hair doing this at a time. In this case, with 90% of my hair in the previously-bleached-ombre-then-dyed-pink state, the brightness was getting pretty obnoxious. If I could leave it be, it'd turn to an almost neon pink within the next month and then slowly fade into a dark pink pastel followed by baby pink. While I do love the baby pink look, there's no way I'd be able to handle this in-between color for the next4-5 months so I headed to my nearest drug store, Walgreen's. While browsing the hair color aisle for a black or dark brown color to cover my bright pink hair, I stumbled onto [[ASIN:B0012JY4G4 Color Oops Hair Color Remover, Extra Strength 1 Application]] and decided to research it on here. Although it does explicitly say that it won't remove \\"direct color dyes such as bright pinks, blues, greens, etc...\\", some of the reviews led me to believe that there's a chance it might remove the pink anyway. If there's a chance I could get the original light blonde ombre back, or even blonde with a light pink tint, then I'd be happy. Worst case, if this didn't remove any of the pink, then I can always come back and buy a box of black hair dye later.<br /><br />TODAY:<br />I followed the directions on the box exactly and, as other reviewers have already mentioned, it smells terrible - kind of like a mix between old-school Nair cream and hair bleach at salons. I left the mixture in my hair for exactly 20 minutes, jumped in the shower, shampooed and rinsed twice as instructed. During the rinse, I saw plenty of pink running down the drain so I was definitely hopeful. When I got out of the shower and finally looked in the mirror, however, I saw that my pink hair had completely turned blue! How in the world did that happen? I had bleached platinum-blonde hair with a layer of hot pink on top and when the pink washed out I was left with blue?? I'm no expert on the color wheel but I'm pretty sure that's not supposed to happen. Perhaps if my hair was purple and I washed out the reds in it, then it'd turn blue... Who knows. Luckily for me, blue is my second favorite hair color and this blue was a muted medium blueish gray color, which is neither loud nor obnoxious so my mission is achieved.<br /><br />All in all, I like the product because it definitely removes hair dyes (even 7-week old punky colors) and I can't penalize it too much for my crazy result because it warned me that it's notmeant to be used on direct color dyes. But, the smell is really horrible and the dry, dry, dry texture it left my hair feeling has plenty of room for improvement. I have a feeling I will be going through alot of [[ASIN:B001AO0WCG Moroccan Oil Hair Treatment 3.4 Oz Bottle with Blue Box]] and [[ASIN:B000ZLVUYO It's A 10 Miracle Hair Mask , 8-Ounces Jars]] in the very near future.
  84. I see alot of reviews about how it worked for hair that was darkened, so I thought I would add my experience with lightening my hair. I am a natural dirty dishwater blonde (light ash brownish). I decided today that I wanted to go more blonde with less red tones for the summer. The store didnt have any feria in a lighter blonde so I opted for garnier #80. Mistake!! I noticed a problem as I was rinsing out the dye from my hair as it was looking way too dark while wet. After I finished drying it, my hair was a dingy ash brownish green! had a terrible green in it!! I went and picked up some Color Oops and put in the whole bottle waiting the full 20 minutes. I rinsed and shampooed a total of 5 times. The box does say it can take out new color and that it can also remove green tints on lightened hair and it does!!! I conditioned my hair after with a whole tube of left over conditioner from a hair coloring box, leaving the conditioner on for 30 minutes because my hair really felt like hay. But, I couldnt be happier! My hair is the beach blonde I was looking for to begin with and no GREEN! So, If you happen to lighten and end up greenish it can help. The stuff does have a stinky smell to it, but it wont kill you. I have smelled way worse with different hair dying products and keratin treatments.

I figured I'd wear my new color with my head high at least until I could find a salon that could be recommended and I trusted.<br /><br />That evening my boyfriend bought me Loreal Color Zap from Sally's. It seemed like a godsend, until you actually read the label and find out that it's all bleach. So before I put that into my hair, he (being the sweet man he is) drove to Walgreens and bought Color Oops. Without bleach or ammonia it was sure to at least be more gentle than the Color Zap. It fixed everything.<br /><br />Twenty minutes later, and about ten minutes into the process of putting the solution on my mid-back length hair I was already seeing it lighten. I had seen my hair lighten once before when I home bleached it and that was right before my bangs basically crunched and broke off. So, I didn't think I was out of deep water yet, but I got in the shower, rinsed, washed, repeated, four times, used Aussie 3 Minute Miracle, blow-dried and tossed around my beautiful hair like one of the Charlie's Angels.<br /><br />Please ladies, before you bleach, before you pay uber bucks at the salon, try this Color Oops. Even if for whatever reason it doesn't have the same miraculous results that mine did, it will not damage your hair and a stylist can always redye it. But, it's a miracle product to me and I'm thrilled to have my natural color back. Well worth the time, money, effort and most importantly, the results.can always redye it.   88. I wanted to go a little darker than my light golden brown/really dark blonde hair(with a few grays) and bought a level 3 \\"rich golden brown\\" hair dye. It went WAY too dark...almost black with some red highlights. I washed it after coloring and tried a lemon juice/conditioner combo that slightly lightened it to a super dark brown with some red highlights. The next day I tried this miracle product Color Oops after reading every review that I could find. I cut a small strand of hair from behind my ear to test, and it came out exactly the color I wanted. So I went for it. I followed the directions exactly, which is really time-consuming. The application took a few minutes then I left it on for about 17 minutes hoping my hair wouldn't go orange and straw-like. I then rinsed, shampooed (clarifying) and rinsed for 15 minutes, shampooed again (moisturizing), rinsed for 5 more minutes, then put on a 3 minute miracle conditioner for about 10 minutes. I could tell a HUGE difference when I rinsed it out. I combed my hair and let it air dry and now it is the exact color that I wanted. It looks completely natural and is a rich golden brown with red and gold highlights in the sun. I'm not going to color it again because it looks SO good. I do see a few random gray hairs underneath, but you can't tell unless I lift my hair. I still can't believe it worked! And my hair is super soft and shiny, probably due to the deep conditioning and the fact that I never blow dry it. The smell isn't great, but neither is the smell of hair dye. Awesome, incredible, unbelievable.

I used Color Oops reg. strength the first time since I had fine hair, and followed the directions to the T. It only lightened the redness to a light blonde/orange on the \\"roots\\"., SO, I got extra strength and left it in for 3 HOURS. Yes, 3. That's how bad I wanted the red out + I was losing track of time anyways. This time I applied it more evenly than \\"all over\\" and when the color oops was still in my hair, I couldn't tell if the red was coming out or not so I had to go in NATURAL sunlight to see and luckily enough I had \\"honey brown\\" hair color (my natural hair color is like a dark, chestnut brown). So I washed it out and THNAKFULLY had little to no damage since my hair is pretty healthy besides the split ends I have yet to cut. I then deep conditioned with L'oreal's Sulfate free line which worked like a charm. :)<br /><br />Overall, I am VERY pleased with my results. The only things I would advise you to do is DO NOT dye your hair IMMEDIATELY after you wash it because ONE you need to deep condition it because it WILL dry out your hair and TWO I'd give it a day or two to darken (thats what it did to me. It was a bright-ish orange with blonde and brown and then it settled to a nice brown thats NOT my natural hair color but I still like it anyways so eh). Also, do not put this on \\"virgin\\" hair. It didn't do anything when I did it, but still.. I wouldn't risk it. :)<br /><br />HAPPY DECOLORING.

Yes, you're going to get bored rinsing and you're going to feel like cheating on the rinse time but DON'T! Do yourself and your hair a favor and keep rinsing! If you don't, your hair will just turn darker in the next 24 hours. My hair felt like straw while I was rinsing but I used Neutrogena Anti-Residue Shampoo and Aussie 3 Minute Miracle conditioner. My hair is still a little dark for my taste but definitely not the scary, \\"I'm trying to re-live my teenager days\\" jet black shade it originally was.   101. First of all, I want to point out the things I have done to my fine, straight hair: Dyed it red for over a year, then a \\"change of pace\\" to black, then tried to lighten it with some... lightening... brown color dye (only worked on my roots) and then left my hair alone, sat in a corner and cried. Now, I bought this stuff not expecting much: my hair was black, and not even a lightener could change it. But my mindset was \\"Hey, the only really awful things it could do at this point is make my hair fall out\\". So, I went to CVS, bought an overpriced box, and went home with little hope it would do anything. Boy was I wrong. When you mix the two chemicals together, it creates some kind of godly reaction that is designed to demolish dark hair colors in twenty minutes, and that's exactly what it did. The black was gone after the first rinse, I reapplied, rinsed again and my hair was so light. Science, bro. Anyway, the makers of this stuff, in all their fantastic glory, decided Hey, we're going to market this stuff, girls can strip the permanent or semi-permanent color from their hair, AND THEN THEY CAN DYE OVER IT. And that's exactly what I futhermuckin' did. I used a warm auburn shade of Loreal Superior, and it held great. The color came out a little darker than I wanted, but that is warned of on the box. In summary, this stuff is wonderful, and it says inside the box (and on the back) that it works best on lighter hair dyed darker. So, it'll work best if you dye your hair brown to black, but if you lighten your way it won't work as well, if at all. Also, it may take a couple applications to get all of the color out, and I recommend conditioning with some serious Redken before dying over it. It's very mild and is pretty much my saviour.

  103. I usually color my hair a mid brown but chose a different brand with a hint of mahogany - colored my hair last night and woke up with red roots followed by a deep almost black color - not pretty!!<br /><br />After reading reviews decided to rush out to my local drugstore to pick up a box of this. It was simple to use and did the trick.<br /><br />To begin - the smell is really not bad at all, its actually far less potent than hair dye itself!! It smell is an issue to you you could light some incense sticks - I had a burner with some essential oil going as I figured I was going to be stuck in the bathroom a while! But honestly the smell is not that bad at all.<br /><br />The process is simple, the biggest issue is simply time. You mix the contents of one bottle with another and apply. This is very runny liquid and a bit tricky to apply, as first I found it going everywhere so used caution and found one application was enough for my hair which is just below shoulder length!<br /><br />You leave it on for 20 minutes, then shampoo and rinse for 20 minutes - this I found to be the biggest nuisance. I suggest taking some sort of timer with you as 20 minutes is longer than it seems (I also suggest taking some body scrub, maybe a face mask as you are stuck in the shower for 20 minutes might as well make the time useful!) Then I applied shampoo again, rinsed for 5 minutes, used a deep conditioner and I was done!<br /><br />It really did take the color out of my hair. The length of my hair returned to a pretty brown that was a tad lighter than normal - I did however end up with an orange root line which I had expected!<br /><br />It states you can color right away...some folks wait but for me, orange roots was not the look I planned to show off at work tomorrow! So after drying my hair and leaving the length a little damp to prevent color absorption, I colored again!! It tells you that your hair might absorb more color so I chose a light brown, 15 minutes on the roots and 5 on the length!! I am glad I chose a lighter color as it deep indeed turn into a deeper brown, so IMPORTANT, IF YOU COLOR YOU HAIR AGAIN AFTER USING THIS GO A SHADE OR TWO LIGHTER!<br /><br />My hair is now brown, no hint of red or orange, and it feels great from the deep conditioner!! Very impressed with this, it works well just follow the instructions!r as it deep indeed turn into a deeper brown, so IMPORTANT, IF YOU COLOR YOU HAIR AGAIN AFTER USING THIS GO A SHADE OR TWO LIGHTER! My hair is now brown, no hint of red or orange, and it feels great from the deep conditioner!! Very impressed with this, it works well just follow the instructions!
  104. I was extremely hesitant to try Color Oops after reading the reviews on here and a few other sites, but I was desperate to get the red dye out of my hair. This was my last resort and it worked!<br /><br />Here's my hair background:<br />I have naturally blonde hair that I have been dying religiously ever since I decided to dye it black (terrible idea) in middle school. I'm nineteen now. I haven't seen my hair its natural color since then, as I am constantly dying it to keep up with the blonde roots/dark brown hair dilemma. Basically, I have years of color on my hair.<br /><br />About four months ago I decided to get my hair dyed bright auburn at the salon, and although I loved it for a while, I don't have the time/money to keep it up. I tried to dye over the red with a brown box dye, but it didn't work at all. I researched different ways of stripping hair color without bleaching, and I came across Color Oops and shampooing with Head and Shoulders. I started the Head and Shoulders method and it actually got a LOT of the color out of my hair. After using head and shoulders multiple times for a couple of weeks, most of the red color was out and I wasn't seeing any more dye wash out of my hair in the shower. However, my hair still had a strong red tint that I wanted to get rid of. That's where Color Oops came in.<br /><br />The Aftermath:<br />I'm not going to give an in depth review of the process, as a couple of people gave some really good advice here already. But I do have some comments on the aftermath of the process.<br /><br />- I mixed some coconut oil in with [[ASIN:B000VHO1F2 VO5 TOTAL HAIR RECOVERY Size: 1 OZ]] as a post-treatment conditioner and my hair came out feeling healthier and shinier than it was before the process. I would definitely recommend using some kind of deep conditioner/oil treatment after the fact, but my hair honestly did not feel damaged at all.<br /><br />- My hair did not turn out anywhere near my natural light blonde color, but it didturn out very light. It's true that the color darkens overnight, so don't be alarmed if your hair looks super light orange at first. My hair ended up a very natural looking dark blonde/light brown color that I have actually gotten many complements on. Overall, I'm happy with the end result.<br /><br />- I still found that I had a little bit of a red tint to my hair, so I used [[ASIN:B002PMLGVI L'Oreal Paris Colorist Secrets Brass Banisher Hair Treatment]] and that got rid of any brassiness that I had. I would definitely recommend that product too if you're having problems getting out red tones.<br /><br />All in all, I would definitely recommend this product. It got rid of the red dye that I thought I would never be able to get rid of, and the end result looks nice and natural too!

The nape of my neck is salt and pepper, evidently the box color I had back there was cut out today during my hair cut. I won't recolor but I may go get some bleach next week and Manic Panic in Snow so I can move this process along faster.<br /><br />My roots no longer have a straight skunk line and there are areas that the color was lifted so it looks like my hair has been through a frosting cap. I walked out of there looking like a very angry Morticia Adams. So this morning I wasn't even looking for this product, I was hunting for a similar product but as luck would have it, my local beauty supply store was out of it. I saw this product on the shelf and thought to myself anything I end up with HAS to be better than what I've got..so I gave it a shot. I coated my hair liberally with it and combed it through, left it on for about 15 mins (the box states 20, but I was sweating bullets at this point, wondering what the hell I was going to end up with). I rinsed the bejesus out of my hair (as the box states). I must have stood under the shower for 15 mins, rinsing, shampooing, rinsing some more, shampooing once again and finally, I added a liberal coating of Redken conditioner. Left that in for a few mins and stood there rinsing for another 5 mins. I dried my hair and to my delight, my hair turned a beautiful shade of warm, medium brown with lighter highlights (where the dreaded orange streaks once lived). I am sure it was just a happy accident, but I ended up with the color I wanted when I first walked into the salon! Go figure. Love, love this product! Oh - and here's a tip..get yourself some Redken conditioner. (The heavy-duty stuff that comes in a tube, also available at beauty supply stores). This stuff STINKS to high heaven, but Redken conditioner not only conditions your hair well after this process but helps kill the bad smell you're left with. I couldn't be happier!

Anyway, I found the new color unbearable after 2 weeks and was about to call my stylist to get my hair color stripped. Then I remembered having it stripped as a teenager and it being $150 back then and they had to cut most of my hair off anyway! So, I figured why not try it myself first. I googled the predicament, found Color Oops and headed off to Walgreen's to get some. I did the strand test and was disappointed--I could not see any difference in the color. So, I was not going in with very high expectations when I applied it to all my hair. I followed the directions to a tee--rinsing that long seems crazy, but as others have said, I think it is the key. Most complaints of people saying that their hair smelled really bad after may not have rinsed long enough, because my hair only had a very mild residue of odor after the two shampoos prescribed. Anyway, the results: this product stripped my color back to the medium-dark brown I was accustomed to and I didn't even need to recolor to correct anything (which I was prepared to do). So, while it's not going to strip you to natural if you've been coloring for a while, it will lighten up black dye to a reasonable, \\"ok to leave the house again\\" color! Condition profusely for a few days and you're back to normal!

  122. It works like a charm!!! I showed up ate this hair saloon with a pic of Jenn Aniston in my hands and 3 hours latter left with my hair black and blue (I kid you not!). After crying my eyeballs out, I came to my good buddy, Amazon, looking for the right stuff to fix it. I did not want to wait for the shipping, so I got it at Wallgreens (2 boxes, believe me). I did the strand test and went for it. So now my hair is no longer blue or black. It's a fairly good looking strawberry blond with platinum highlights. I kind of like it! (Before the \\"accident, my hair had high and lowlights, sort of \\"Gisele Bundchen\\" like). My advise is: Get this stuff - at least 2 boxes (3 if you have a lot of hair or if you think you might need to apply it twice). CVS doesn't sell it anymore in stores, so go to Walgreens. READ THE BOOKLET, follow every step. Do it in a very warm room with no gusts of air coming in. Be sure to saturate your hair with it (I did the ends first b/c that's were it looked the darkest, even though the booklet does't tell you to do so). Finally and most important: rinse your hair like your life depends on it! I'm serious. I rinsed my hair for 20 minutes (i think that's the issue everybody who gave it a bad review: poorly rinsing). I also washed my hair with Neutrogena Anti-Residue Shampoo (http://www.amazon.com/Neutrogena-Anti-Residue-Shampoo-12-Ounce-Bottles/dp/B000OLE7WW/ref=sr_1_fkmr1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1279138945&sr=1-3-fkmr1) 6 times (for a total 45 min in the shower!). If you read the booklet, it tells you that rinsing is the most important part of the whole procedure, so do it. I would say that every hairdresser in the planet should have a few boxes of this in stock for those days when sh... happens. Even with the bad smell (vinegar and bad farts...), it left my hair with a really nice color and very silky.
