  129. THE BACKGROUND: I was born blond, then it started getting darker in my teens. I tried to fight nature by lightening it back. So, I've been dying my hair so long (23 years) that I don't even know what color it is naturally anymore, but probably a light to medium, mousy brown. Now, I am getting some grays at 38. THE PROBLEM: I bought some Clairol Natural Instincts Semi-permanent in Medium ash blond by accident. I always use a permanent color in some kind of ash or natural blond. Well, that's all I had in the house and I had 3/4\\" roots and some gray peeking through, so I decided to go ahead and use it. I thought the only downside would be the \\"semi-permanent part\\" and conceded to having to re-do the whole process in 1 month instead of 6-8 weeks. Then, CRAP! I got out of the shower and my hair was DARK, DARK brown with some streaks that were almost downright black... from something with the word \\"blond\\" on the box! (The real kicker was the gray was all still there!) In a panic I got on a chat with Clairol who informed me that as a blond (artificially) this crap won't wash out in the 28 washes, but will have to grow out! For 3 days I wore baseballs caps, washed my hair 9 times with dandruff shampoo, lemon juice, & dishwashing detergent (all internet advise). In all fairness it did fade a bit, but I developed some orange highlights-- not pretty with the gray highlights! Keeping it was plainly not an option, so I scoured the internet again and ran into Oops. It seemed like it was worth a try since I was told I'd pay hundreds to have it stripped. THE PROCESS: My test strip was exactly the same for 10 minutes and 20 minutes. I opted to go for the whole 20 minutes and started squirting the watery substance on my head. I followed the directions, except I did put a warm hair dryer on it for just a minute. I know, I know, I should follow directions.... but, it got really cold and stiff as soon as I got it on my hair and I was panicked that it wouldn't work due to the cold. (Plus, it's January!) Then I cranked up the heat and sat on a vent for the remaining 18 minutes. BTW, while it doesn't smell good by any means, the bad odor is waaay overstated by many people's reviews. I rinsed and rinsed (this is the worst part)... I even ran out of hot water. Immediately, soaking wet, I could tell a ton of color was gone. I put a good conditioner on my hair and sat around for another 20 minutes. It does make your hair dry, but honestly a 30-minute shower would do that anyway. (Not to mentioned all the harsh washing I'd done for 3 days prior.) In fact, I swear my skin is drier than my hair right now. I'll deep condition a couple more times and I'm sure it will be fine. RESULTS: I am back to blond! Yay! It's a bit more brassy or strawberry blond than I started with before this whole mess. But, I am delighted beyond words that the dark brown, orange is gone! I'll give my hair a break for a week and then throw some ash blond color in it. Here's a really interesting thing though... I expected it to strip the brown out and take me back to blond with some darker roots. But, I have no roots at all?! Weird... Go for it and good luck!

Sadly, I didn't think about the fact that burgundy is a very rich and pigmented color, so once I dried my hair it was orange. I was pissed at first but now its starting to grow on me a bit.   132. I got this because I used a dark brown dye that made my hair look muddy and inky colored. I dye my hair a lot and honestly can't even remember what exactly the base color looks like! Just used color oops today and am amazed at how well it worked. The smell is way over analyzed by other reviewers...it pretty much smells like a perm and if u're a girl like me who frequently colors, etc. It's no more obnoxious than any other dye/chemical smells. The only thing I don't like is how runny it is-it makes it hard to apply and I felt like I wasn't getting it through enough. But I guess I did cause my hair (for the first time in a long time) is evenly light brown colored. I shampooed with prell cause it's clarifying, rinsed for 5 min, shampooed again, rinsed for 20 min. Yes it sux and is really annoying doing it for that long but it's necessary! In fact I rinsed for so long that I ran out of hot water so I didn't condition yet-gonna wait a little later till I have hot water again! Then I'll probably deep condition for 20 min. I got a box of dye with it but the color isn't bad so I don't feel the rush to color for now!

I spent 45 minutes in the shower rinsing and shampooing so the results were in no way tainted by my ignorance. My hair lightened maybe half a shade all over.   135. I recently tried a new hair color that looked great on the box but the result in my hair was... OOPS! My hair was so red it nearly glowed in the dark. Needless to say I took a lot of ribbing at work until a co-worker told me about this product. I'm a skeptic generally but desperate times had me heading to the drugstore right away. I followed the directions, paying particular attention to the notes about temperature, and 20 minutes later I had a perfectly normal color again. This product is VERY easy to use, it wasn't harsh on my skin, and other than normal dryness from having to wash my hair twice it did not seem damaging in the least. It also didn't smell terrible or leave residual aromas. I've bought a second box to keep around the house. Hey, you never know!
  136. So just to give you a little background on me, I am naturally super blonde. I decided to dye my hair dark, (level 4 to be exact, black brown) and although it looked great with my blue eyes, the white roots peeking though was annoying so I decided my hair had enough and I'd go back to my natural. I started by going back to my professional hair dresser and he started lightening me up by doing heavy highlights. Well damaged bleached highlights and $200 dollars later and my hair looking like a Zebra, (I had platinum blonde highlights with black/brownish hair) My hair lightens really easy because my base is so blonde. I luck out that my hair doesn't go orange because my base is just that light. However I still hated my new striped locks, I started doing research on how to lighten this black brown out of my hair. I did the Johnson's Baby Shampoo which did help lighten the base (the PH in this shampoo helps wash out permanent hair dye) I then came across Color Oops. I was super scared, I have NEVER done my hair at home, but I was afraid of spending $100's more and bleaching to lighten my locks back up. So I did it, followed the directions to the tee, (my hair had been highlighted twice in the last 2 weeks) And prayed it wouldn't break off. 20 stinky min later (this product has sulfur in it so yes it smells like sulfur) I go in the shower and started rinsing rinsing rinsing. I didn't notice any color difference in the processing time but once I hopped in the shower I saw the black just rinse out!!!! My Highlights looked fine, but my base when from a black brown to a carmel blonde!!! I then purple shampooed to tone and did a cuticle repair treatment and TADA! I have beautiful highlighted carmel blonde hair. It's Golden but not brassy. It's not my natural color but at least now I look like a carmel blonde with highlights and not a black hair with highlights (zebra to be exact) Bottom line is THIS STUFF WORKS!! I am going to give my hair a break and enjoy my new carmel blonde,and when my roots start peeking though again I am going to color oops again and hope it take more of the dye out (instead of bleaching) It says you can use the product up to 3 times. My hair had been dyed darker for 6 months so I didn't expect it to rinse all the dye out, but I was still blown away at the results. This will dry your hair out a, so condition condition condition! But it was no where near as damaging as the bleach. I loved the product so much that I will be using it again in hopes to eventually bring my blonde back.

  142. I won't repeat everything every one else said about following the directions to the letter and how it only works if you went darker when you colored, not lighter -- all VERY true!!! My natural color is very dark, but I had colored it a few months ago with a red-brown that I really liked. I had to do something, so I colored with Garnier Fructis dark mahogany brown. Worked great, covered the gray, left my hair shiny, etc., BUT I had left it in the full 30 mins because the grays I have a resistant to color and my hair turned an extremely dark brown, almost black. UGH. I went to work for two days like that and I hated how it looked in general and it looked even worse in the fluorescent lights at work. Made me look really old and I'm definitely not old. OY. I figured I had nothing to loose, so I hauled over to the CVS and found OOPS Extra Strength. I stood in the CVS and read about a hundred reviews online on my phone while i debated if I wanted to try it. I am SO glad that I did! I did the strand test and determined that I would only need to leave it on for ten minutes to get the lightness I wanted. Like I said, my hair is very fine and since it takes color easily, I wasn't surprised that the color came out easily too. By the time I finished putting it on, I had nine minutes left and then washed with Suave Clarifying Shampoo, rinsed, washed, rinsed, washed and then conditioned. Twenty minutes of rinsing each time and 20 mins of conditioner. I was prepared to recolor after I finished, but I really like the resulting color. Oddly enough, it's similar to how it looked before I colored it dark but I have no dark roots and no gray at the temple. SWEET! I love it! My hair still feels healthy and I don't need to color. Best product ever!

For anyone using this product, it will lighten your hair, I'm not sure how much, but there will definitely be a difference. Be prepared for the smell, and the damage is nothing a good conditioner can't fix. Good Luck.

  167. I am revising my original review, which I wrote 36 hours after using Color Oops and following the instructions to the letter. Color Oops did strip away a lot of color, and, like many others, my hair darkened back up considerably within 24-36 hours after use. At the time I wrote my review, I thought it was reverting completely; however, my hair never returned to the near-black color it was before I used the product. I will say that 24 hours after using Color Oops, I did wash my hair again, lathering twice with clarifying shampoo, once with a color deposit shampoo (to add a little warmth), and deep conditioning for an hour. Maybe that helped. In any case, Color Oops did not return my hair to where it was before the unfortunate salon color incident (essentially black), but it did strip away enough of the unfortunate color to where I am now quite satisfied with the resulting dark ash brown. I would definitely recommend the product. A cautionary note: your hair will look different 24 hours after using Color Oops than it does one hour after using Color Oops. So, be patient and wait for the end result before making any hasty decisions about re-coloring, or any conclusions about your hair color. Also, regarding the odor: the smell did not linger on my hair once I had conditioned it and used my normal styling products. However, the smell did linger in my bathroom for several days!

  169. Well, I researched this product for weeks and read tons of reviews before I tried it. now it's my turn for a review!<br /> My hair is naturally a light ash brown to a dark ash blonde, but I get bored and color it a lot...Since last year it started lemon blonde, then I turned it into a mink style with black, then I payed a salon to turn it back to my natural, after a few months I got bored and went to the salon and got talked into a burgundy red base with crimson red and blonde highlights! It looked great for a while, but then my roots grew out. I didn't want to pay anymore money to get it done again so I tried Color Oops....<br /><br />In all the reviews it said that it was very runny, it was, but it wasn't THAT bad, definitely workable. My hair almost absorbed it so it didn't drip as bad as I was expecting.<br /><br />They also said it was very smelly...and it is pretty bad. When you're applying it, it's not that strong, but when it's left in and the day following it really does smell like rotten eggs, but not in a complete nauseating way, you kinda get used to it after a while. I do advise keeping the vent on when applying and rinsing though, and maybe opening a few windows in the house for the first day. I didn't notice it after a while, but my boyfriend did!<br /><br />Rinse, rinse, and re rinse. That how this works. The more you rinse the better it works (the box advises for 20 min, I only did for 15, but stick it out and go the whole 9 yards)<br /><br />As for the results....Keep in mind that I was going from deep burgundy red with bold red and blonde highlights, one of the hardest colors to get rid of...(I accidentally left Color oops on a little too long, but I don't think it affected the results and my hair didn't fall out, so that's a minor detail) After I rinsed and dried I was left with a golden blonde with a strawberry tint to it, and the blonde highlights just got brighter. The bottom was a bit darker than the rest so make sure you apply evenly and everywhere. The color I was left with (if the bottom had come out the same as the rest) really wasn't a bad color by itself, all the dark red was gone but I DID still have some red tint to it where the crimson highlights were. I waited a bit and used what I had left over of the color opps again, enough to get all of it, but the result didn't change at all. If anything it just blended the colors together a little. I don't believe my hair was damaged at all by the product, it doesn't even feel like I applied anything to it so it's a lot healthier than getting it stripped or bleaching it and for the MOST part it got the dark red out, which is what I wanted...<br /><br />I waited one day before I recolored, the new color is Ash Blonde from l'oreal paris. I think 8A. I got a \\"cooler\\" shade because it minimizes red tones... BUT I STILL have some strawberry tones on the top after dying that is uneven. I wanted the red tone completely gone, so I wish I would have gone to a brown or a platinum blonde instead to mask it better. So, my advice here is to be careful with what you choose to color it afterwords. If you still have the difficult-to-remove tones like red or black AFTER you use color opps, plan accordingly when redyeing. Also, you can still smell the color opps even after you redye, so there's no getting rid of it that easily.<br /><br />So, all-in-all I'm glad I used it. I didn't have to pay a crazy amount of money, and it did better than I thought it would, especially for what it had to remove.<br /><br />BEFORE color opps:<br />[...]<br /><br />AFTER Color opps AND redying:<br />[...]if the bottom had come out the same as the rest) really wasn't a bad color by itself, all the dark red was gone but I DID still have some red tint to it where the crimson highlights were. I waited a bit and used what I had left over of the color opps again, enough to get all of it, but the result didn't change at all. If anything it just blended the colors together a little. I don't believe my hair was damaged at all by the product, it doesn't even feel like I applied anything to it so it's a lot healthier than getting it stripped or bleaching it and for the MOST part it got the dark red out, which is what I wanted... I waited one day before I recolored, the new color is Ash Blonde from l'oreal paris. I think 8A. I got a \\"cooler\\" shade because it minimizes red tones... BUT I STILL have some strawberry tones on the top after dying that is uneven. I wanted the red tone completely gone, so I wish I would have gone to a brown or a platinum blonde instead to mask it better. So, my advice here is to be careful with what you choose to color it afterwords. If you still have the difficult-to-remove tones like red or black AFTER you use color opps, plan accordingly when redyeing. Also, you can still smell the color opps even after you redye, so there's no getting rid of it that easily. So, all-in-all I'm glad I used it. I didn't have to pay a crazy amount of money, and it did better than I thought it would, especially for what it had to remove. BEFORE color opps: [...] AFTER Color opps AND redying: [...]
  170. I have naturally dark, almost black hair and for the past few years have been coloring it reddish brown with henna. I wanted a matte, all-over, dramatic color and decided to color my hair completely black. I liked it, but it just didn't really work on me. It looked too harsh.<br /><br />I used Color Oops and followed the directions. I only rinsed for just the minimum 20 minutes. Perhaps if I had rinsed longer, more of the black would have come out, but I was impatient. My hair did not return to my previous color, but I didn't expect it to. It turned into a dark but warm brown. My hair now has a noticeable coppery/red tone to it. I actually like it a lot!<br /><br />In addition, somehow it made my hair incredibly soft. Before even coloring my hair, it was very strawlike and my ends were fried. After using this product, my hair is very soft and my ends look better.<br /><br />Don't have the expectation that using this product will make it look like you never colored in the first place, but it will get you close.
  171. This worked like a charm. Just follow the directions by the letter. I had reddish hair that wouldn't fade out on my blonde, so I used this to get the 8+ month dye out. No issues. The smell bothered my husband, but not me. Worth it for the hair correction. Way cheaper than going to a salon.
  172. My teen daughter insisted on going down the dye path, in spite of the fact that she had long, thick, milk chocolate colored hair that had red highlights when the sun hit it. I said no way, she said yes way, guess who won (she only lets me win an argument about every 30 days, just to bolster my esteem and foster the pretense that I'm in charge).<br /><br /> She started out with very light brownish/blondish highlights. I hated the way they looked, she liked them, she kept them for about a year. She got tired of them, and got darker highlights, which looked more natural, but her hair wasn't as thick and soft anymore, even with sulfate free shampoos and once weekly deep conditioning. Dying is HARD on your hair; imo it's better for your hair and less likely to end in weeping and drama if you go the non-permanent route, with color that washes out in 6-10 washes (there is another semi permanent color that washes out in 28 washes, it's a little rougher on your hair and the color stays in longer than 28, at least it did for me, and my daughter). My other daughter gets a kind of 'glaze' of color over her hair when she goes to the salon; it looks really beautiful and natural. It washes out in two/three days, but it's a safe way to experiment with color. We are all about drama free experimenting in a house of two teen girls.<br /><br /> Back to our story: daughter now has darker highlights for six months, gets tired of them, and wants all over color that is a bit darker than her dark highlights. (I did the coloring myself...I've paid significant amounts of money for terrible dye jobs, for color that washed out in the salon sink, for traumatically bad shades, i.e. hair that turned purple when it was supposed to be auburn. I don't pay for color anymore. If your colorist is amazing, count yourself among the blessed and be sure to tip them well. They are few and far between, in my experience, even at reputable salons). In spite of using the washes-out-in-28-washes semi-permanent dye of medium brown, her color came out almost black. It looked like it was coated with shoe polish, it absorbed light like a black hole, it didn't even look edgy or goth, it just looked gawdawful. Cue rounds of weeping and door slamming and bitter recriminations (I know, I know, it's not good for kids to see their mothers like that, but, it was just so, sob, UGLY ;)<br /><br /> While my daughter cried herself to sleep, I went online and researched dye lightening/reversal/howcanigetvaliumwithoutaprescription options. It became apparent there are so many people online, RIGHT NOW, looking up ways to fix their overly dark awful dye job (some home, some from salons). The message boards are full of desperate, horrified people, of all ages and genders, trying to fix their hair. There are many 'cures', from the ridiculous (pouring diluted clorox bleach on hair) to helpful (wash w/drops of Dawn dish soap mixed with Prell shampoo, rinse with hottest poss. water, condition, repeat for a month). I don't know why it took me four hours to find Color Oops, but it did, and by this time I was convinced there were no quick fixes, just tedious, somewhat useful fading techniques. That being said, however, C.O. seemed unusual enough that I began to wade through about 500 reviews on Walgreens.<br /><br /> Following the instructions is EVERYTHING with this product (I know, right? Me? Following instructions to a T? But I'm an American! I have instruction rights!) Also, it only works with hair that has gone darker, not hair that has been lightened. Be prepared to spend some quality time counting tiles in your shower; the rinsing time is critically important. The infamous smell isn't a problem, because, when you (or, say, your teen) have a wretched dye job and you are wailing \\"I'll do anything, ANYTHING to fix this, I can't live with this!\\", a temporary sulfuric, rotten egg-type smell is a small price to pay. The smell doesn't last past a day, anyway. You can always put a little perfume on to distract your nose (which fragrance notes work well with eau d'egg rot? There's gotta be something). Also extremely important: the test strand. I cut about twenty hairs for a tiny but thick enough strand to observe results. I left the solution on for the instructed 20 min, and after rinsing, it seemed too light for her original hair color.<br /><br /> For the actual process, I used a timer on my cell, which was more helpful to me than setting an alarm, because I knew precisely how much time had passed. We left the solution on for 13 minutes (I had intended to have her start rinsing at the 10 minute mark, considering how light the test strand went after 20 min, but it ended up being 13 minutes because I had a cooking interruption). She rinsed with warm, not hot, water because we didn't want the heater to run out too quickly, shampooed for 5 minutes, rinsed for 20, shampooed again for 5, rinsed for 20, shampooed a third time, rinsed for ten, and then got out of the shower. The odor was mostly gone by this time, and in point of fact, the smell wasn't as much an issue as the marathon rinsing. It really seemed endless. She had the radio on to help with the tedium, but it was a good thing we used the cell timer, as we both kept saying \\"Oh surely it's been time enough\\", and discovered to our chagrin that it wasn't.<br /><br /> I didn't have her use conditioner, as I had a packet of olive oil/orange oil deep conditioning mask for her to sleep in, under a shower cap (I use it all the time, it's lovely. $1.50 for single use packet at Walgreens). Her hair, even wet, looked almost exactly like it did back before she started ever dying it. I was amazed. I just couldn't believe such a remarkable transformation. The next morning, she rinsed off the mask, used a tiny drop of BioSilk on the ends, and blew it out with the dryer. Her hair was BEAUTIFUL. It once again looks like milk chocolate with those reddish hues when the sun hits it. A week and two shampoos later, it's still beautiful. She has only been blowing out her bangs, the rest she lets dry overnight, just to baby the hair a bit. I've read reviews about successful color reversals, but with a lot of damage, to the point where they question if they should have just let the hair fade with other timely techniques. I don't know if it's because she has only been dying her hair for a few years, but it's not terribly damaged. A little bit, yes, but not enough to merit concern. Almost certainly her hair would be more damaged if we had dyed again after the C.O. to achieve her desired shade, but we lucked out.<br /><br /> I love this product. If I had known of it when I was younger, I could have avoided a lot of my own hair drama. If possible, I'd like to implore the makers of C.O. to branch out: Marriage Oops, I Ate The Whole Box Of Fudge When My Period Started Oops, I Looked Away For Two Seconds To Snarl At My Kids And Nailed The Bumper Of The Mercedes In Front Of Me Whose Driver Turned Out To Be A Lawyer Oops. There's an untapped market here, I'm sure of it.<br /><br /> This product is cheap, simple to use, and most importantly, I am now the mother of a Happy Teen With Good Hair. Amazing.n to distract your nose (which fragrance notes work well with eau d'egg rot? There's gotta be something). Also extremely important: the test strand. I cut about twenty hairs for a tiny but thick enough strand to observe results. I left the solution on for the instructed 20 min, and after rinsing, it seemed too light for her original hair color.<br /><br /> For the actual process, I used a timer on my cell, which was more helpful to me than setting an alarm, because I knew precisely how much time had passed. There's an untapped market here, I'm sure of it.<br /><br /> This product is cheap, simple to use, and most importantly, I am now the mother of a Happy Teen With Good Hair. Amazing.

Im assuming Color Oops doesnt work well on Bleached hair that was colored after, so i dont recommend this product if youre trying to get a color that you bleached first out of your hair.   178. I am 100% satisfied with this product. A few days ago, I decided to dye my hair natural soft black. At least that's what it said on the package! My hair is very dark brown naturally so I figured it would just make it richer looking. HUGE mistake. I ended up looking like Elvira. I just couldn't stand. I looked up several home remedies like washing your hair with Dawn, baking soda, or Tide to remove the color but I couldn't imagine these things would work. After a lot of research, I decided to go with Color Oops. I am so happy with my hair color. It removed all of the black dye and returned my hair to a deep brownish color with red highlights. I was concerned that the color would be too brassy and that I would have to re-dye it but it looks really nice so I didn't re-dye it. It's a long process and you have to rinse, rinse, and rinse some more. Also make sure to use a deep conditioner afterwards. I put a deep conditioner in my hair, put on a cap, and let it sit for 30 minutes. A co-worker commented that my hair looks healthier than before. A lot of people complained about the smell. It smells like a perm from the 80's. Not great but certainly not horrible. I would definitely recommend this product. It does what it says it's going to do.
  179. Six weeks ago I let my new young hairdresser color my blondish hair a copper color with highlights. It was very copper, bordering on red. They had one! I told my friend the bartender and she told me about this stuff..<br /><br />The results are better than I could have anticipated!! When you first take off the cap, you are blondish orange and kind of freaky looking.-- For me that would have still been a better alternative to my hair color at the time... lol.. I would say you should only use this product for extreme circumstances and you can't live with what you have now.. -J

  188. I was really nervous about trying this - read hundreds of reviews before purchasing at Walgreens. I had been dyeing my naturally dark brown hair various shades of red for ten years, and in a fit of midlife crisis dyed it dark brown in an attempt to get it back to my natural color. Big mistake. Came out closer to black. Lived with it for several months, until I couldn't stand it anymore, and then attempted to go back to one of my previous shades of red. Nope, came out black with a hint of purple - think Morticia Addams. So after spending literally hours online reading reviews, I picked up color oops. A friend and I did it together, as I have super long hair (nearly to my waist) and I was worried about applying it quickly enough. We followed the instructions exactly, except during the 20 minute rinse we shampooed every five minutes (and actually added a few extra minutes of rinsing at the end, bringing us closer to 25 min. My hair came out this lovely light brown shade, with lighter streaks from former highlights YEARS ago. I absolutely love it, not even going to redye although I had purchased new color in case it came out odd after the oops. This stuff is a miracle! Oh - as for the smell. My friend and I dyed her hair after doing the oops on mine, and we both agreed that the regular dye smelled worse than this. Also used a nutrogena triple recovery hair mask afterward - no damage. My hair is actually in slightly better shape than it was before. In short - if you are reading this - BUY THIS STUFF. You won't regret it. Hope that helps! Before and after pics attached.
  189. I have only used this twice but it seems to be safer for your hair than a lot of the other color removers out there (wish I could find the ingredients though.) One thing to note is the longer you've had the color in your hair, the less it will work. It hardly made a dent in my ends, but worked well with my roots and most of the middle. Also going from an old black dye job is even harder, but it actually made an impact with mine. I am impressed with it.
  190. I think I read all of the reviews before buying this product. There is a lot of useful information from some people. I have been dying my hair brown/red for the the past 10 yrs and my hair falls past my bust almost to my waist. Since I've been dying it for so long, it seams no matter how light a color I go it always turns out a dark brown almost black. I have finally tired of it and went searching for ways to lighten it with out killing it or having to cut it all off. I have to admit my skepticism on this product and actually watched a few videos of people trying it. Its been about 2 weeks since I used it. (2 boxes) Yes it smells like lemon/egg farts (it is sulfur.) Make sure to clean your bathroom after you use it or it will smell till you do. Anyways! YES It lightened my hair! Hurray! I really like the color too. Kinda a caramel/brewed tea color. I have noticed it does seam to get darker in between showers. (Not because of oily hair.) But lightens up again after a good wash. Now for somethings I think may have helped me. One person said you need to seal the hair shaft after all that washing and heat. Someone else mentioned freezing your conditioner. So for me I washed washed washed (felt dehydrated after that shower!!) and then used my really cold conditioner, let it sit for about 15mins and rinsed in a nice cool shower. Also if you've been using any products for color treated hair I recommend buying new ones as to not re oxidized those dye molecules. People have mentioned that your hair darkens from how it looks from when you first do it. Yes mine has but not to badly ( I think its because I have made the effort to change the products I use, as mentioned above.) So I think I'm going to try it one more time too see if I can't get it a little lighter. I hope I like it as much as the first time. I'm tired of such dark hair. I also think I should mention that it had been at least a month since I last dyed my hair. And before that it had been about 6months.. So yes it works on old dye jobs. (That was something people weren't to clear on.) Good luck to all! I think it was worth a shot :)
  191. I have never written a review but had to for this amazing product. Last night I was attempting to color my hair \\"medium ash brown\\" but it came out black. I had purchased a box of Color Oops a long time ago and never ended up using it, so I skeptically pulled it out this morning to try to get the black out. It could not have been easier using this product. It is much more liquidy than boxed hair color, but I liked it because it easily spread throughout my hair quickly and evenly. I put it all over and waited the 20 minutes. You do have to spend a long time in the shower, however, I did not follow the directions exactly and it worked perfectly. It says to rinse for 15-20 minutes after the first shampoo and I lost patience after 10. I shampooed and rinsed twice more, then conditioned. The black is all GONE. My normal medium brown is back! Completely even. I can't believe how it easy it is. One note: all over the web, people go on and on about the smell of this product. Does it smell like roses? No, HOWEVER, it was truly BARELY noticeable. People are wimps because they seriously scared me about how awful this was going to smell and it didn't bother me at all!! Don't let that scare you away. It didn't stink up my bathroom or apartment at all. Once I rinsed it out it was gone. Highly recommended for anyone who accidentally goes too dark! Don't be scared of it; I am terrible at applying stuff like this and it was so simple and came out perfectly even and back to normal!
  192. After a decade of highlighting, both professional and homestyle, I decided to try all-over permanent haircolor again. (My natural color is \\"dishwater\\" blonde--light in front and browner in back--and I haven't seen it in fifty years.) Since I had a good bit of highlighting, I decided to use Ash Blonde, thinking everything would blend well with that shade. The type was either L'Oreal's \\"Preference\\" or \\"Excellence,\\" whichever one has the application nozzle like a little comb. Imagine my disappointment when my hair turned out a light pinkish brown! Rather than restoring pale highlights (back to square one), I decided to try the \\"Color Oops\\" solution. After reading the directions several times, I organized everything in my laundry room which has a untility sink and spray hose. An old terrycloth kimono, a kitchen timer, a plastic comb, several towels and \\"Oops,\\" and I was ready to go. As per the other reviews, the preparation is stinky but not unbearable. I was a bit afraid of this unfamiliar process and left the stuff on for 16 minutes rather than the full 20; a couple of tests along the way revealed that 100% of the color probably was never going to come out anyway. With the two shampooings (Pantene \\"Restorative\\" shampoo), I rinsed a total of about 25 minutes. Then I slathered on Pantene \\"Restorative\\" conditioner, covered with a towel, and left it 40 minutes. After another thorough rinse and a quick blow-dry, the resulting color is a light-to-medium goldish blonde. My hair does not seem unusually dry, but I will continue to use a rinse-out condition after shampooing and also a lightweight, leave-in conditioner the next few times I style. I'm giving only four stars because my hair did not return fully to the color it was before I used the Ash Blonde permanent color. Perhaps the full 20 minutes would have done the trick. Until the hair grows out and I resume highlighting, I can control the brassiness with an occasional application of one of the pale (bluish) \\"Born Blonde\\" shades. All in all, a pretty good rescue job.
  193. If you want to be a blond, do not let your stylist add lowlights when doing highlights! Mine did and it was terribly ugly - I purchased oops after washing my hair daily for 3 weeks hoping the lowlights would fade. They didn't. Oops worked great, I feel normal again.
  194. I am a fifty-something natural strawberry blonde whose hair is about 5% gray and actually now a brownish-dun-red color. My hair is thick but fine and I have had it home-dyed once before and salon dyed twice before. I recently had highlights and lowlights done professionally. I wanted to add some coppery sheen and minimize the gray and applied Clairol \\"Nice'n easy\\" #108, \\"Natural reddish blonde\\" for only 15 minutes. My hair came out looking like a red clown wig- orange-red- flaming- aghhhh! I wore it one day like that (mostly waiting until the sun went down to venture outside) and decided that I couldn't \\"embrace\\" the new color. I Googled \\"dyed hair too red\\" and \\"Color Oops\\" came up. Thank God! I read many wonderful reviews, some with cautions, and decided that I had little to lose. I purchased a box of Extra Strength Color Oops at CVS (the guy at the register was kind enough not to point and laugh at Bozo)and went home and followed the directions to a \\"T\\". I took a large wall clock into the bathroom with me so that I could keep time from the shower. I washed and rinsed and rinsed and rinsed and washed and rinsed- whew! I now am a peach blonde (not a bleached blonde or even a beach blonde), certainly not my original brownish-dun-red, but I have all of my gray hair back. This new weird color is a little more presentable than the Bozo red, but all in all, I say \\"NEVER AGAIN\\" WITH HOME DYES. When/if the urge to change my look comes again, I will JUST SAY NO OR GO TO A PROFESSIONAL. I am not able to do plumbing or electrical work or sew perfectly tailored clothing or repair the brakes on my car- what makes me think that I can combine strong chemicals with myriad variables and reactions and put them on my hair and get good results??? Never again! By the way, the smell of the Color Oops was bad, but I was expecting worse. It permeated everything and is still smelly a day after I applied it. I just threw the clothes that I wore and the towel that I used in the garbage. Goodluck to you all....B

  201. My natural hair color is black but I have been lightening my hair for several months to brown and red. Recently I decided to switch to a blue black color. While it was nice at first (albeit containing some red from my previous dye), the blue faded really quickly, and my hair ended up being a very dull, borderline silver black with red tints. It look unappealing. I tried to lighten my hair back to brown but the black stubbornly stuck on and only my roots changed color. I researched that a hair color remover like Color Oops would be needed to remove the black. I decided to go with Color Oops over L'Oreal Hair Color Remover. Within 15 minutes of application, BOTH the black and persistent red were stripped from my hair, leaving my hair a orangey brown color like my roots. Worked like a charm! Of course, I had to labor through the 25-minute rinsing process after (oh my god, it was SO TEDIOUS and tiring being in the shower for that long), but hey, it was worth it. My hair came out a nice brown and almost no damage was done to it at all! MAGIC.<br /><br />Yes, as the other reviews say, it smells unpleasantly strong and does reek of rotten eggs. But it's livable and you'll certainly get used to it. And yes, the rinsing process is like labor. But these are small prices to pay to getting your hair color fixed. Plus, there's no bleach in it so it won't do massive damage to your hair. The product really works! Totally recommend.
  202. Got the black out of my hair
  203. Background: Natural blonde who has been dying her hair for nearly 10 years. Was dark auburn at the time of using product.<br /><br />I decided to go back to blonde because it was too much hassle keeping up with the roots, its a normal thing that happens with me every few years, but I didn't want to wait for my hair to grow out so I did some research and found Color Oops.<br /><br />I have short, shoulder length, thick hair. I needed two boxes to fully saturate my hair. I probably could have used three but two did the job. Since my hair is so thick I let it set for about 40 minutes. If you have thick hair you need to or it won't do anything. My friend has much thinner hair and after fifteen minutes her hair was starting to lighten, just as a comparison.<br /><br />The application doesn't smell so bad but after you've washed it out there will be a lingering sulfur smell for a few days, its easily covered with another application of conditioner. The hair will feel a little dry at first, especially if you use heat on your hair so be wary.<br /><br />YOU MUST RINSE FOR TWENTY MINUTES. With the hottest water you can take. Then wash for 5 minutes. Rise for 5 minutes. And repeat 4 more times. Use a shampoo that moisturizes so your hair doesn't become like straw.<br /><br />It will get super light and then darken. You can dye if you want right after but if you let it settle for a few days it won't interfere with the dying process as much. It didn't take my hair back to my natural color, but it got close and left it with a strawberry blonde shade and I'm still deciding if I want to dye it lighter but was a much easier and cheaper process than doing it at a salon. I suggest it to anyone that wants to go back to their natural color.<br /><br />FAIR WARNING: If you have ever bleached your hair, it will not come out so nicely it will be much more like an orange color, so you might want to look into dying it afterward.
  204. This product is wonderful! I have natural red hair - the kind that does not come in a bottle. If I had a dollar for every compliment I have received on my natural hair color, I would be rich. Too bad we are never satisfied. I have colored my hair many times over the years and as soon as I dye it, I am on a mission to get my natural hair color back - because nothing ever looks right. For years I have used bleach to correct my hair color mishaps. Of course that is damaging and always leaves my hair much lighter than I prefer. So anyhow this time I used color oops and if I am dumb enough to try to achieve a better color for myself again, I will know exactly what to use to fix my mistake. This is what happened this time. And yes, I know this will make me seem extremely idiotic. But maybe it will help you! I colored my hair a chocolate cherry mousse. It came out very artificial looking. Quite disgusting in my opinion. It had a deep pink tint that I just could not handle. The next day I went to the beauty supply and got a dark auburn color thinking this would make it more of a brown. Besides, auburn was more of what I was going for in the first place. It made it even darker, but still had that pink tint. I let it sit over the the weekend. I actually got compliments on it, but felt it did not look right with my skin color. So on Monday I tried the color oops. I did exactly what it said. And btw I was not gagging over the smell - and I am 6 months pregnant. (Yes - I got the ok from my DR.) The smell is bad, but completely tolerable. Once I started rinsing I saw that my hair looked normal. I was very excited. I rinsed and rinsed and rinsed until the water ran cold. I used a crappy shampoo hoping this would help to strip my hair. By the time I finished rinsing I thought the color already looked like it had darkened back up. Boo. After I dried my hair it was lighter. Not normal, but lighter. It did look better. I was hoping it would take more out, but like I said, it was better. So a couple weeks past and the idiot strikes again. I had a box of hair color in the cabinet that was closer to my natural hair color. It showed that it would turn dark brown hair red. It didn't. Maybe because my hair was artificially brown. So there I was with darker hair again. After smacking myself a few times for not just leaving it alone, I used the highlighting kit that came with the dye. The highlights came out great. And honestly if I had just skipped the last coloring and just highlighted my hair after the last color oops, I would have been happy... I think. So another couple of weeks go by and although my hair looks much better I was still annoyed with how dark it was underneath the highlights. So I started think I might try another color oops on it. That brings us to today. I was much faster about applying the color oops today - not sure why, but I guess I am getting good at it! And it does say to apply it quickly. I used a wide tooth comb and combed through it a couple times while applying. After the time was up I put a step ladder in the shower to sit on - because like I said I am pregnant. Standing in the shower for 30+ minutes is very uncomfortable these days. I rinsed for about 5 minutes and then used head and shoulders - since I read that dandruff and clarifying shampoos help remove color. Then I rinsed for 20 minutes and washed it again. Then I rinsed for 5 more. I do have very thick and long hair so I did not want to skimp on the rinsing. The entire time I rinsed I noticed that my hair looked normal. I kept waiting for it to darken back up. I got out of the shower and towel dried my hair. It looked much lighter than before. I applied a deep conditioner that said to leave it on for 5 minutes and rinse. I didn't rinse though because my hair felt like crap. I then dried my hair with the conditioner on it. I still have not noticed it darkening and it feels soft and I look like me again. After about $80 of products I look nearly the same as I did before I started. Point being that if I had used Color Oops after the first coloring I could have saved myself a lot of time and money. Hopefully you will benefit from this. Oh and btw I picked this product up at Walgreen's for $13.99.
  205. My hair is shoulder length - thick and coarse - naturally dark brown/black but that was years ago. I've been dying my hair dark brown/black for at least 10 years. Lately, I've been trying to find a way to allow my grey (80%ish) to grow in without the skunk look. I tried the spray color to avoid dying my roots (no good) and then switched to a semi-permanent to try and even out the color while it grew out...as directed by the experts I went a shade or two lighter to gradually step-down but what I ended up with was red roots with the warm brown and yellow roots with the natural brown...also no good. So, I decided that removing the color and then re-dying a lighter brown would be the best bet. I headed to Wal-Mart and in anticipation of the amount of dye in my hair I grabbed two boxes of the OOPS ES.<br /><br />As far as the product goes, it's easy to use. Mix it just like hair dye, apply it to dry hair just like hair dye, cover and wait 20 min (just like hair dye), and rinse. It's clear and really runny (unlike hair dye) so be prepared and wear something that you can ruin. I have a special turtle neck I use just for coloring my hair (helps keep it off my neck and arms). It has a sulfur smell but no one in the house complained. I rinsed for a few minutes, washed and then rinsed for another 20, washed again and rinsed for five as the box directed.<br /><br />The first time my roots were really blonde and the rest of the hair was a dark medium brown. I did a leave in conditioner and then rinsed the next morning, my hair was a little darker but the roots were still blonde. I did a coconut oil protein treatment, rinsed and let dry. So, I did another application, same steps as above but I rinsed much longer since I know the hair darkening over time was due to color particles that were left behind and re-oxidized. This time my hair came out a beautiful and even strawberry dirty blonde from root to tip. I got lots of compliments on it all evening, it was really shiny and natural looking, I decided I wasn't even going to color over it until the grow-out was noticeable. I put a light-weight overnight conditioner in my hair to help with any damage and went to bed.<br /><br />I was really sad to wake-up and see that I was back to gold/brown roots and dark medium brown hair. Yeah, it blends in better with my eyebrows, but basically at almost $10 a box, my hair looks like it did before I started removing the color...$20 down the drain. It's not worth trying another box at that price - especially since the whole purpose of the home treatment is because I couldn't afford the professional treatment....and I've run the hot water out of the shower both time I applied the OOPS ES, so rinsing longer doesn't seem to be the answer. Either the dye in my hair is too much or the OOPS is not enough. I'm told that One and Only Color Fix by Conair is better, I will try that next but unless anyone else has any suggestions, if it doesn't work I don't know what else to do.<br /><br />This might be a good product is you are removing a light color or if you are removing a single application of color. If you are a regular dark colored dye user you might want to test it but be prepared. Also, to put a few ideas to rest...there is not a single color remover or fixer that will return you to your natural color. All dyes leave a base - usually red, orange, or yellow, though sometimes blue/purple - that's why I ended up with yellow, red, and strawberry blonde. If you don't like the results (most won't) - You will have to re-dye your hair after using the removers/fixers, just re-dye to a color a shade or two lighter than your natural color (or the desired color). Once you use a remover/fixer your hair is more porous and locks on to more color - so any color will turn out a shade or two darker than it is supposed to - use a shade or two lighter, you can always dye darker again if you need to...for most though, one dye to return you to your natural (or desired) color will be all you need.<br /><br />It recommends that you use a protein filler before coloring to help reduce the amount of color your hair soaks up. Walmart sells them by single use packets in the hair care isle, usually next to the ethnic hair care....mine was less than $2...Sally's Beauty Supply also sells them that way. I used one as a treatment to help reduce damage - I haven't colored yet.<br /><br />If anyone else has any ideas I'd love to hear them - hope this review helps!
  206. For years I had been dying my hair at home with a permanent chestnut brown or dark auburn color. A few months ago I decided to dye my hair black using L'Oreal Preference/Soft Black. It didn't look terrible but I got tired of it being so dark. I had expected it to fade but it never did.<br /><br />After reading a ton of good reviews, I decided to give Color Oops a try. It smelled like sulfur, but very subtle.<br /><br />After rinsing and shampooing I applied a deep conditioner and rinsed that out after 5 minutes. I then applied a leave-in conditioner and am now letting my hair air dry. My hair is not completely dry yet but so far I am really happy with the color and with how much lighter it is. I can still see some black here and there but it looks really nice.

  208. This stuff works nearly as well as it claims to. I had medium brown hair with highlights and tried to dye it a dark brown, but it came out utterly black. I didn't find out about Color Oops until two months later, and gave it a shot anyway. It stripped the colour out even after two months! What I got in the end was a brassier version of what I had before, which was fine because it was light enough to dye it.<br />Important tips:<br />-It will NOT remove fake colours like green, pink, blue, etc. It only removes regular colours and it says so in the directions.<br />-It can only work if you dyed your hair darker and want the light colour back. All it does is remove the dye, it can't restore colour to hair that was stripped with bleach or highlights, so don't bother unless you accidentally dyed it too dark.<br />-The smell is very strong and it will take days to rinse out.<br />-Even though it isn't bleach, it will dry out your hair so have some reparative conditioner to use after.<br />-If you want to dye it again right after, you need to buy a lighter shade than normal. The hair will be porous and will soak up a huge amount of dye, meaning you will end up with too-dark hair all over again if you aren't careful about getting a light enough colour.<br />-The mixture is thin, my hair only goes to my chin and I still used the whole bottle. You might need two bottles, or I have heard of other people mixing in a bit of shampoo to thicken it but I didn't take the risk myself so I'm not sure.<br />-The dye may have permanently stripped some colour and made it slightly orange, so it's good to have a new dye on hand just in case.

  211. A month ago, I bleached my hair for the first time. The bleach turned my light red hair a pale yellow, and then I put an ash blonde toner over it. My sister and I were working together to fix my hair, and we got the giggles when he realized it smelled like a \\"lemon fart.\\" Within minutes of putting the lemon fart in my hair, I started to notice a change... Even my roots, which had about an inch of growth after a month, are now bleached yellow/blonde. It's amazing! I would swear by this product forever!
  212. My hair was originally a nice, dark chocolate brown. For context, I'm caucasian and 31 years old. You can see a picture of my original haircolor in my profile. A few years ago, I took to experimenting with my hair and got dark blonde highlights. They looked nice, but then in the fall I longed for my darker mane, so I got dark highlights in order to start phasing out the blonde ones. That didn't work as fast as I wanted to, so I eventually just covered the whole thing over with a dark auburn color.<br /><br />That brings us to the last few months. I decided I wanted it a light copper red, so a series of disasters began with the objective of turning me into a redhead. It kinda worked... but a few months later, I was fed up with the upkeep and I wanted it brown & easy again.<br /><br />My new goal was to end up with a medium golden brown that would be a little lighter than my natural color, but hopefully blend in nicely with my new growth.<br /><br />Enter Color Oops.<br /><br />PREPARATION:<br /><br />I purchased the following products:<br /><br />- [[ASIN:B0012JY4G4 Color Oops Hair Color Remover Extra Strength 1 Application]]<br />- [[ASIN:B001HBN5JO COLORFUL Neutral Protein Filler Hairdressers Color Insurance 16 oz/473 ml]]<br />- [[ASIN:B00IB0D2Z6 Seventh Generation Dish Liquid, Free & Clear, 25 Fl Oz]]<br />- [[ASIN:B002UD52MG Loreal Series Expert Vitamino Color Masque, 6.7-Ounces Jar]]<br />- [[ASIN:B004D1R0CS Clairol Perfect 10 By Nice 'N Easy Hair Color 6.5g Lightest Golden Brown 1 Kit]]<br /><br />I have mid-back hair but it is not very thick, so I didn't think I would need more than one box of Color Oops. If you normally only need one box of dye, then one box of Color Oops will work just fine. The dish liquid soap I normally keep in stock for my kitchen, but here I decided to use it in place of regular shampoo to help get the Color Oops off my hair. I could have used clarifying shampoo, but this was a much more cost-effective solution. The Neutral Protein filler to assist with the coloring process afterwards. It's important so don't skip it! I also felt that my hair would probably need some extra love after all this, hence the L'Oreal Vitamino masque.<br /><br />Lastly, the Clairol Perfect 10 in Lightest Golden Brown to dye after the Color Oops. I chose this shade, which is a lot lighter than my intended color, because I kept reading that after the Color Oops, my hair would grab on to the color much more readily and turn it darker. Now, the Protein Filler was supposed to remedy this, but my hair always ends up much darker than the box so I thought that this would be a safe choice anyway. I reasoned that if the color really turned out too light, it is much easier to fix than if it turns out too dark.<br /><br />THE PROCESS:<br /><br />STEP 1: Stripping Color<br /><br />I brushed through my hair and quickly mixed and applied the Color Oops through my head. The smell was pretty bad and my eyes burned as I was applying it. It was tolerable, though. The consistency of the product is NOT water as other reviews have said. I'd say it's probably closer to the consistency of liquid hand soap. Once I was done applying it, I put the shower cap that came with the Color Oops on. The cap is actually pretty small... it won't fit you if you have a lot of hair.<br /><br />After 20 minutes, I returned to the bathroom. Upon inspection, my hair didn't seem to have changed that much... it went from a faded light auburn to a milk chocolate brown, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I set a kitchen timer to 30 minutes and put it by the shower so I could see it. Knowing the importance of the rinsing part of the process, I wanted to make sure that I spent enough time doing it.<br /><br />Hopped into the shower and began rinsing. Once I'd gotten most of the product out, I applied my Seventh Generation dish soap and proceeded to wash my hair thoroughly. I rinsed it all out and repeated the process three times. When the timer was down to 5 minutes, Iapplied a good amount of L'Oreal Vitamino masque and let it sit for a few minutes while I proceeded to finish my shower as normal.<br /><br />I let my hair dry naturally and immediately noticed it was orange. Not pumpkin orange but more like tree leaves in the Fall kind of orange. Very much expected, since my hair had obviously been lightened by the repeated dying processes over the last few years. This meant that Color Oops had successfully done its job! However, I couldn't keep this color.<br /><br />Now, a lot of reviews say that Color Oops did not damage their hair, and frankly, I don't know what they're talking about. My hair felt very smooth and healthy in the beginning... but even with the masque I applied, my hair did NOT feel good after Color Oops. It wasn't as bad as bleaching, but it definitely felt rough.<br /><br />It was late, so I decided to go to bed and dye my hair in the morning.<br /><br />STEP 2: Restoring your Color<br /><br />I started out by moistening my hair slightly and then combed through it and pretty much saturated it with the Neutral Protein filler. I could have applied it on dry hair, but that makes it more difficult to comb through. I let it sit for 20 minutes, which turned it to straw as it dried. This is normal.<br /><br />I proceeded to apply my dye right on top of the protein filler, Clairol Perfect 10 in Lightest Golden Brown (6.5G) and put on the shower cap included.<br /><br />At this point, I knew that I was only supposed to leave the dye for 5 minutes, according to the Color Oops box. However, considering that I had applied a protein filler and the dye was a lot lighter than I intended, I decided to leave it the full 10 minutes that this particular brand requires. This turned out to be the correct decision! Read on...<br /><br />Once the 10 minutes were up, I hopped in the shower. I added a bit of water to my head and used the dye to make lather like shampoo, then rinsed out til water ran clear. I put on another healthy dose of L'Oreal Vitamino masque and again let it sit while I finished my shower.<br /><br />Before stepping out, I rinsed out my hair with cold water. Mind you, I live in Upstate NY, so it is more like ice cold this time of the year. Good way to wake you up in the morning! It also helps close your hair cuticle and keep the color in ;) Don't miss this step! Though you may want to just invert your head into the bathtub so you don't freeze like I did.<br /><br />THE AFTERMATH:<br /><br />Right after dying my hair, I let it airdry. At this point, I thought the color turned out a little too light and too brassy. It didn't look bad at all, but it wasn't what I wanted. So, I came back to Amazon and ordered a box of [[ASIN:B001LFEVSK Clairol Perfect 10 in Medium Ash Brown (5A)]]. I figured I'd throw it on for five minutes and that would darken the color and neutralize the brassiness. It was a good plan...<br /><br />That was two days ago and I just received it. However, an interesting thing happened... My color seems to have \\"settled\\" and it now looks exactly the shade I wanted! I have not applied any shampoo yet, so this is most likely due to the previous Color Oops application. I have read this happened to other people. If you're curious, look at the box model of [[ASIN:B0015NMSHY Clairol Perfect 10 in Medium Golden Brown (5G)]] and that's exactly what my head looks like. It's the actual shade I was shooting for, and it's a tiny bit lighter than my natural color.<br /><br />My hair actually feels really good after the dye application. It is very soft and shiny, though the ends still feel a little bit rough. Overall, I am happy with the final color and feel of my hair. I don't plan to use the additional dye I purchased immediately, but I will keep it in case that it fades too much over the next few washes.<br /><br />I will update this review if any further changes occur, but for now, consider me a happy customer!as normal. I let my hair dry naturally and immediately noticed it was orange. Not pumpkin orange but more like tree leaves in the Fall kind of orange. Very much expected, since my hair had obviously been lightened by the repeated dying processes over the last few years. This meant that Color Oops had successfully done its job! However, I couldn't keep this color. Now, a lot of reviews say that Color Oops did not damage their hair, and frankly, I don't know what they're talking about. My hair felt very smooth and healthy in the beginning... but even with the masque I applied, my hair did NOT feel good after Color Oops. It wasn't as bad as bleaching, but it definitely felt rough. It was late, so I decided to go to bed and dye my hair in the morning. STEP 2: Restoring your Color I started out by moistening my hair slightly and then combed through it and pretty much saturated it with the Neutral Protein filler. I could have applied it on dry hair, but that makes it more difficult to comb through. I let it sit for 20 minutes, which turned it to straw as it dried. This is normal. I proceeded to apply my dye right on top of the protein filler, Clairol Perfect 10 in Lightest Golden Brown (6.5G) and put on the shower cap included. At this point, I knew that I was only supposed to leave the dye for 5 minutes, according to the Color Oops box. However, considering that I had applied a protein filler and the dye was a lot lighter than I intended, I decided to leave it the full 10 minutes that this particular brand requires. This turned out to be the correct decision! Read on... Once the 10 minutes were up, I hopped in the shower. I added a bit of water to my head and used the dye to make lather like shampoo, then rinsed out til water ran clear. I put on another healthy dose of L'Oreal Vitamino masque and again let it sit while I finished my shower. Before stepping out, I rinsed out my hair with cold water. Mind you, I live in Upstate NY, so it is morelike ice cold this time of the year. Good way to wake you up in the morning! It also helps close your hair cuticle and keep the color in ;) Don't miss this step! Though you may want to just invert your head into the bathtub so you don't freeze like I did. THE AFTERMATH: Right after dying my hair, I let it airdry. At this point, I thought the color turned out a little too light and too brassy. It didn't look bad at all, but it wasn't what I wanted. So, I came back to Amazon and ordered a box of [[ASIN:B001LFEVSK Clairol Perfect 10 in Medium Ash Brown (5A)]]. I figured I'd throw it on for five minutes and that would darken the color and neutralize the brassiness. It was a good plan... That was two days ago and I just received it. However, an interesting thing happened... My color seems to have \\"settled\\" and it now looks exactly the shade I wanted! I have not applied any shampoo yet, so this is most likely due to the previous Color Oops application. I have read this happened to other people. If you're curious, look at the box model of [[ASIN:B0015NMSHY Clairol Perfect 10 in Medium Golden Brown (5G)]] and that's exactly what my head looks like. It's the actual shade I was shooting for, and it's a tiny bit lighter than my natural color. My hair actually feels really good after the dye application. It is very soft and shiny, though the ends still feel a little bit rough. Overall, I am happy with the final color and feel of my hair. I don't plan to use the additional dye I purchased immediately, but I will keep it in case that it fades too much over the next few washes. I will update this review if any further changes occur, but for now, consider me a happy customer!
  213. Okay, so I'm blonde and wanted a little color for the Holidays. I bought the Paint The Town Red color (Herbal Essense??). If I lived in New York city and worked at a tatoo parlor, it was really cool...but that's not the situation. After way too much attention from strangers cuz \\"Your hair is soooo red\\" I was fed up. No really, I lost hours of sleep trying to figure out what to do. Then I found Color Oops. I used it just as it said. Washed my hair and rinsed my hair a couple times ( I think this step is key) and low and behold...my blonde was back. I found the strawberry blonde by nice and easy and did my hair with that color the same night. It turned out awesome. I was sooooo happy I could have cried. Just make sure you use a lot of conditioner (you may be alarmed how dry your hair feels after the color oops) but when I put the next color in and used the conditioner, it felt wonderful. My hair has been fine since and it's April now. Hopefully this helps as I really appreciated finding this product from someone else's post.

  225. My hair is very fine and slightly wavy. Even in my 50s, I have very little gray. I usually like to lighten it a shade or two and use a bronze type of brown. The Feria bronze browns are my favorite, and I really should have stuck with that.<br /><br />I colored my hair with a foam product by John Frieda -- a medium golden brown that looked beautiful on the box. I've been coloring my hair myself for years. I was shocked to see that my hair came out nearly black.<br /><br />I tried all the tricks to lighten it -- Prell, dish soap. It lightened very little. I thought perhaps I could manage and let it fade over time, but every time I saw myself in the mirror I just got depressed. The color was just way too dark for someone my age and skin tone.<br /><br />After reading reviews, I decided to take a chance and boy am I ever glad that I did. The only one I could find in the store was the strongest version. I did the strand test and saw that it lightened it up a great deal.<br /><br />I wanted to be prepared in case my hair came out too light. I couldn't get to the beauty supply to get protein filler to use before coloring again, so I decided to use the emergency Clairol Beautiful Brown warm golden brown I have on hand if necessary.<br /><br />I followed the instructions to the letter. I found that I only needed half the bottle, since my hair is so fine. It is long, but I never have to use a whole bottle of anything on my hair!<br /><br />I decided to process my hair for less time with the Color Oops since the test strand came out so light.<br /><br />I kept checking the color during the processing time - and when my hair lightened to the shade desired- probably around 10-12 minutes total - immediately started the washing and rinsing process.<br /><br />The key is to really follow that instruction about doing period strand tests. Don't just wait the whole 20 minutes. Depending on the type of hair you have and the dye process you used, you may not need to process the whole time. That could be why some people come out with orange hair.<br /><br />It could be that I needed less time because I was using the extra strength.<br /><br />I must say that 20 minutes of rinsing is a really, really long time. But I stuck it out to make sure all the stuff was rinsed out. My hair seemed a bit stiff. I conditioned it for 5 minutes and found that my hair is silky, a great color and seems to have more life than it did before using Color Oops.<br /><br />My old stylist taught me some tricks -- one of which is a Godsaver that I will share. If a color comes out too light -- or your hair fades too fast - use a semi-perm color such as the Clairol Beautiful products... They have all shades in the beauty supply; I use the Beautiful Browns. They may have changed the name, but it comes in a small brown bottle and costs under $4. I can get 2 uses out of one bottle.<br /><br />In my case, I did not need to recolor -- which was a relief. With my fine, thinning hair, I didn't want to be coloring it again right away.<br /><br />But if my hair continues to fade too fast, I will just use the Clairol Beautiful Browns temporarily - until I think my hair is strong enough to endure another coloring process. But this time, it will be my tried and true Feria bronze color. No more John Frieda coloring products for me.<br /><br />As for the price, it was on sale at Wags for 9.99 (regularly 14.99) - so that was great, too. Now if I would just have remembered to use the $1 off coupon I'd printed out, it would have been 8.99! Look online for coupons -- and don't forget to use them!<br /><br />Update -- I noticed that after using it, the next few times I washed my hair a lot of it fell out. Could be that I used too strong a product - I have very fine hair. I do not lighten it or use many styling products on it. I noticed that my hair was really porous and much more fragile than it was and this lasted for a while. I won't be using it again. I'll just be more careful about the colors I choose and use only the ones I'm familiar with so I don't end up too dark again.
  226. The most important thing I can say about this product is... WAIT 24 HOURS MINIMUM BEFORE REDYEING!!<br /><br />Okay, now here's my story. I have naturally golden blonde hair, think the color of wheat, and I dyed it dark brown because I broke up with my boyfriend and was feeling rebellious. After about 2.5 months (box dyeing every 3 weeks or so, due to fading), I realized that this look is too high maintence for me and I wanted my blonde locks back.<br /><br />I've had this product sitting and waiting for me since the first night that I dyed my hair, incase I absolutely hated the dark brown, so I decided to put it to use. I followed the instructions and ended up with bright orange, strawberry blond-ish hair. I was a little worried, but I didn't freak out, and instead embraced my gingerness for the day. About 24 hours after the application, the ginger/strawberry blonde color changed to a light-medium brown/reddish color. A big improvement and closer to my natural color.<br /><br />Since I've only dyed my hair about 4 times, I decided to use the product again 60 hours later (with a deep conditioning in between). Now after following the instructions again, my hair is strawberry blonde yet again, and hopefully in 24 hours will be even closer to my natural color.<br /><br />So again, if you're looking to get closer to your natural color, wait 24 hours before dyeing your hair again because the color will change over a 24 hour period.

It took out ALL THE BLACK. Seriously. My normal colour is back again! My hair smells pretty awful and seems a tiny bit distressed, but some deep conditioning and a bit of time will help that.   245. I have been coloring my hair for many, many, many years 'darkest brown,&#34; which has black in it. There for, I cannot go lighter without either growing my hair out (no thanks- too much grey!) or having it stripped out somehow. I have had this done in the salon a few times... at an extremely high cost. Simply not an option now. First I went to the beauty supply store and got a different product called Color Zapp! and it was a nightmare. It claims not to lighten your natural hair color, but it soon became apparent to me that this was basically BLEACH. When I rinsed it out, my roots were bright orange, I had huge stripes of black all over my head, and the ends were blond... not to mention fried! For two days, I had to wear a scarf on my head to hide the freak show underneath!<br /><br />In incredible distress, I looked to the internets for a solution and it was not until then that I learned of Color Oops. After reading many of the reviews here on Amazon, I was confident that this would be a gentler way to finish the job before I color it red for the summer. Well I got my box, used as directed and was very very please with the results. My hair is basically orange now because of the color zapp, but light enough that I can now recolor it a deep red. PLEASE READ: If you have not bleached your hair immediately prior to using Color Oops, your hair won't turn orange like mine did! This is all the fault of Color Zapp!<br /><br /> It is very important to take seriously the recommendation that you spend 15-20 minutes just rinsing. This is for two reasons: if you do not rinse long enough, the chemical reaction that allows the pigment to &#34;disappear&#34; can reverse itself and you will be back at some form of square one. The other reason is that this product contains high levels of sulfur, which smells nasty. I am prone to headaches from strong smells like this. Unfortunately. even with 20 minutes of rinsing, the smell is still there. I put a leave-in conditioner in that has a pleasant, mild fragrance. It is much more bearable. And it is repairing the damage done by the bleach concoction I first used.<br /><br />Needless to say, I am a happy camper now. I will use this product in the future most definitely. I have very long hair (middle of back), but thin hair (due to both genetics and a recent hypothyroid diagnosis). One bottle was more than enough for me, but thick hair may need 2-3 bottles. There are still a few small areas where the black pigment was not successfully removed, but they are so minor, they will likely not be noticeable once I color my hair to the red. Overall, a great product with better-than-expected results. Will use again and again in the future.a pleasant, mild fragrance. It is much more bearable. And it is repairing the damage done by the bleach concoction I first used.<br /><br />Needless to say, I am a happy camper now. I will use this product in the future most definitely. I have very long hair (middle of back), but thin hair (due to both genetics and a recent hypothyroid diagnosis). One bottle was more than enough for me, but thick hair may need 2-3 bottles. There are still a few small areas where the black pigment was not successfully removed, but they are so minor, they will likely not be noticeable once I color my hair to the red. Overall, a great product with better-than-expected results. Will use again and again in the future.
  246. Let me start by giving a brief history of my hair! I'm a natural dirty blonde, who grew tired of her hair color and decide to change it up. I dyed it a medium brown, which ended up turning to dark brown almost black. I lived with it for awhile, but decided that since my blonde roots were having such a hard time excepting the dark dye, that I was going to attempt to go back to blonde. My plan was always to bleach, but in an attempt to minimize the damage, I thought I would try to remove some of the color so I could use a lower developer for less time.<br />I read countless reviews on this product( some good and some bad), but I figured \\"what the hey!\\"So, I bought two boxes if color oops and tried it. Well, it did lighten up a little, but nowhere near to my natural color. So I did it again..and again...and again...and finally, again! I used this product 5 times in the course of 3 days, and I had achieved a red orange color that I was pleased with (I was gonna bleach anyway in a few weeks, and thought I would have no problem getting to a pale blonde from this stage)<br />Well a few days after the last application, I washed my hair...just regular shampoo, I had not re-dyed or put anything containing peroxide(that's a no-no after color oops) on my head. I dried my hair, and to my not-so-pleasant surprise, parts of it had re-oxidized(meaning gone back to dark, but if you're contemplating using this stuff,you've probably read about it quite a bit and knew what that meant!)<br />After 5 applications, a lot of money, and a lot of having to deal with a horrific smell, I was left with orange blonde roots, dark brown in the middle, and red orange ends.I followed the instructions to the t, and even though the instructions say you can re dye afterward, I did not...yet still ended up nearly back to where I started.<br />Had I written this review right after the applications(like I'm guessing most people do), I would've been singing its praises. However I waited, and fortunately am able to give a thorough review so others don't make the same mistake I did!<br />If you want to go lighter...deep condition and go the sure fire route...bleach. this stuff smells terrible, and is such a pain to use. Don't waste your money like I did on a product that \\"may or may not\\" work for you. Its not worth it, its been weeks and my hair still smells like sulfur! Good luck everyone, I really hope this helps!am able to give a thorough review so others don't make the same mistake I did!<br />If you want to go lighter...deep condition and go the sure fire route...bleach. this stuff smells terrible, and is such a pain to use. Don't waste your money like I did on a product that \\"may or may not\\" work for you. Its not worth it, its been weeks and my hair still smells like sulfur! Good luck everyone, I really hope this helps!

On a friend's suggestion, I got a box of Color Oops and spent 20 minutes letting it soak in then a further 30 minutes rinsing - I was doubtful but I have to say that after that time, my hair was frizzy and felt stripped but the red was back and the color was gone. I only had a small section that was colored in the front with regular medium-brown dye and a bit throughout the ends. My natural hair is still in good condition, but any areas that were previously colored are dry and brittle. I'm only praying all of those areas don't break, because that would make the whole ordeal pretty pointless.<br /><br />I wouldn't recommend this as a &#34;try just for the fun of it&#34; kind of product. If you're desperate, give it a go. If you have super-strong hair, you could probably get away with it, too, with tons of conditioning. If you have fine hair like I do, I wouldn't recommend this unless absolutely necessary.
