  258. I have naturally light blonde hair and occasionally put bright red sections ( with permanent salon dye) through my bangs and section in the back. Red does not come out easily, or cover easily, in my experience. This time when I was sick of the red, and it was fading to an icky brassy color I decided to try Color Oops because it was one of the few things I hadn't tried to remove red from my blonde hair.<br /><br />The directions were straight forward and easy to follow. The smell was gross, but bearable. The solution is pretty watery, so it was helpful for me to have someone help put it on the back sections of my hair so I didn't make a huge mess. The results were just okay. Not great, but not terrible. You have to rinse your hair for a very long time, and I actually ran out of hot water in the process. At the end of it all I had a faded pink tone where the red was. So, it faded it a significant amount, but by no means removed it. Also, as others have said it did darken some as the day went on.<br /><br />For me the biggest bummer with using this is that my hair is noticeably damaged after using it. I have fine, soft hair, and this was very drying, and caused some frizz and damage.<br /><br />Due to the damage, and just okay results this is not something I would probably use again. I have read though that it works best for &#34;natural&#34; colors, so that may be part of why I got the results I did.<br /><br />Also, just a side note for the other blondes out there who are trying to get red out, in my experience the red just has to be blended until it fades out and/or grows out and can be cut off. Most of the things I've done to try to remove the red have just fade it. I've even had a salon put brown on top to try and cover it and it didn't take completely. This last time I tried putting a dark blonde over the pink and it came out a mauve color. It's been an adventure for sure. Just remember, it's hair, it will grow out eventually.

  261. Alright so I was terrified to use this product...to start out, I got pregnant and didn't dye my hair for a year and 3 months. I was determined not to dye my hair as it was half my natural and getting really long. But it got to a point where I couldn't stand the yellow anymore. So I decided its time to change it up. Because it was either that or cutt it to where my natural color ended which wasn't an option, been growin my hair out for so long. So I wanted to get the red I had before back. But I eventually want my natural so I wanted something that I didn't think would turn to yellow so I can dye it out. So I tried a reddish auburn brown which turned my hair bright red. It was awful! I was so embarrassed to even go to the store. I read all kinda of reviews about color oops and decided I didn't have another choice. I used it and I am very glad I did. My hair is definitely not back to my natural but it faded the red so much I can dye it a light natural brown, which hopefully won't fade while I keep growin my hair out. The best advice I could give is to not dye hair. It is so much more beautiful natural whatever the color. But if you decide to and it doesn't turn out I highly recommend color oops. Just have extra hair dye on hand in case it turns out like mine, not quite your natural. And be sure to read the instructions all the way and understand them before you start. Very important! I had no hair loss problems or blotchyness as I did exactly what it said.
  262. I bought Color Oops after dying my light blonde hair a darker blonde, which turned it a terrible ashy, almost green brown as my hair was so porous. Nothing was working to help fade the color (clarifying shampoo, hot oil, etc.) I followed the directions, which instructed me to rinse my hair like crazy (15-20 minutes) followed by shampoo, more rinsing, and a good conditioner. At first my hair was back to blonde...a nice medium, almost golden blonde. Then during the past two weeks since using the treatment, it has gotten gradually darker...now settled into a dark blonde, pretty close to what was on the box of color that I had purchased. Apparently if you don't rinse away all of the shrunken color molecules, they can turn the hair darker again. At least it's not as dark as I started out with, but I wasn't about to spend an hour with my head under the bathtub faucet.<br /><br />And it stinks--literally. Like a burnt rubber/latex. It's been two weeks and I can still smell a trace of it in my hair when I wash it. At this point I plan on letting some of my natural color grow in and will let this current color fade/wash out as much as possible before going back to my lighter blonde color.<br /><br />It's my own fault for messing around with my hair color, but I'm disappointed in the product. There used to be an odorless, completely gentle, vegetable-based powder from Europe that you would mix with water, apply to hair, wrap in plastic and heat activate...but sadly, I could find NO info about it online...maybe it's not made anymore, which is a shame, as that stuff worked perfectly and left no smell whatsoever.

  265. I get my hair professionally dyed by a close friend. Problem number one. So the last two appointments I've asked for more brown to be weaved into my hair so that I could get back to my natural color and be done with all of this. Well, this time I asked to go darker...and something got lost in the communication between the two of us. I was asked to pick out a color from a swatch. I choose one and also pointed out a person in the salon with the color I really liked, a medium brown. I then told my friend that I don't want any red tones in my hair. Well, next thing I know a bottle of medium brown dye is put on all over my head, straight on, no foils. I wasn't worried cause I liked the color in the bottle and since I'm not the professional I didn't feel I need to question this new process. Problem number two. After some wait time, the next thing I know I'm rinsed out and looking at my new color in the mirror. It was sooo dark. Not the medium brown in the bottle or the color of the person's hair I picked out. I was told that it would fade with washing. This I knew was true cause my last coloring faded and that's why I wanted to go darker this time. Well, not pleased with the results at that time, but not really pleased with the NEW results when I got home. You see by the time I got home from the salon, my hair had turned BLACK! At first I thought it was the low lights in my house. Well, I noticed my head was itching. So much so that I just couldn't stand it anymore and had to wash my hair. Sure enough the water and shampoo were black! I don't know what happened, but I really believe that the product wasn't rinsed out enough at the salon. After no sleep that night and searching on the internet for advice I came across Color Oops! Yeah, I would say my color was an oops! I had my husband go tothe store the next morning and buy me the regular strength. My hair was already damaged, so I didn't want to pick the extra strength just in case it damaged it more. It didn't and it actually took the black tint out. Still really, really dark brown, but not black at least. I tried to live with that for a day. I just couldn't. Way too dark for my skin tone, looks like I'm wearing a wig. So I went to the store to buy the extra strength Color Oops. At this point I was desperate! This lightened it another shade, but now it's a very dark auburn red. Problem number three. I didn't want red! A pretty color, but not on me!!! It's been three more days and now I'm going to get some advice from a professional. Color Oops worked for me a little bit. I'm happier with this color than the black, but I wished it worked more like it claims on the box. I know black is the hardest color to remove, so I would recommend this product for that fact. Well worth the money and time. At least with this color I can leave my house and go out in public. Just as long as I don't run into anyone I know!
  266. This works great and it didnt turn my hair orange like the loreal brand did. My hair was dyed a really dark brown and this stuff was able to take it back to blonde maybe a lil bit lighter than my natural color but close enough.
  267. I had my hair dyed professionally about 6 weeks ago. She put slices of black throughout and I have absolutely hated it.   268. I'm disappointed, all that effort and I'm right back where I started. My natural hair is med ashy blonde but I've been getting low lights and high lights for 10 years. The highlighted areas were damaged, the lowlights never lasted, and I was paying a fortune at the salon so, a few months ago, I decided to take a break from the salon and go darker using a semi-perm light brown. I loved the results but the semi-perm colors faded quickly so I tried a permanent light brown a few weeks ago. It looked great at first but also faded fast and with an unflattering reddish tint. Also, it looks funny when the blonde roots grow in against the brown. So I decided going darker is just as high maintenance as blonde and want to go back to blonde but don't want to damage my hair. After reading the reviews, I bought the extra strength colors oops, read the directions thoroughly and followed them carefully. Before starting, I turned the AC off so the temperature in the bathroom was in the high 70's with no drafts. Like most people have said, the stuff smells of rotten eggs, similar in intensity to a perm, and is very watery and messy and it will spray out of the bottle if you shake it so aim away from your face. My hair is long and fine and one box was just enough to saturate it. I put a lightweight shower cap on and left it on for the full 20 minutes. When I took the cap off, it looked much lighter. I rinsed and shampooed repeatedly in very warm water for longer than the directions specified (45 mins total). By the end, I was shriveled like a prune and thought I might pass out from the heat. Then I used a deep conditioner and left it on for 15 mins while wearing another shower cap. After rinsing the conditioner out and towel drying, my hair appeared to be a nice medium blonde shade and I was thinking I might not even have to use the blonde semi-perm color I bought. My hair still felt somewhat dry so I used a hot oil treatment, followed up with another round of deep conditioner andrinsing. After all that, I let it air dry and practically cried the next time I looked in the mirror. Its exactly the same color it was before Color Oops. I wasted $20, 3 hours and stunk up my house and hair for nothing. The only positive thing I can say is that I don't think it worsened the condition of my hair and the nasty smell didn't cling to my hair...it smelled normal by the time I got out of the shower. I'm not sure why it didn't work for me. My hair is dry and has always taken color fast for what that's worth. Now I'm debating whether I should try some of the other color removers that are available or just suck it up and have it stripped at the salon. Or maybe I should stick with the sickly reddish color and freaky blonde roots until it grows out? Hmm, decisions, decisions... THE MORNING AFTER UPDATE - After sleeping on it, I've changed my review from 1 to 2 stars because, after giving it a day, my hair is now about a shade lighter than when I started. It still has a lot of color on it and is not close to what I expected or want but it is lighter. Unfortunately, now its a sickly pale red that is worse than the light brown I started with. I'm going to put on a baseball cap and head to the store for another box and I think this time I'll leave it on a bit longer and I'll rinse as long as possible. I rinsed until I ran out of hot water yesterday so I'm not sure I can do much better than that. I'll post an update after the next round. AFTER BOX #2 - I changed my review back to 1 star. The 1st box lightened my hair one shade and didn't hurt the condition of my hair so the next day I applied a 2nd box, left it on 20 minutes w/ a showercap, rinsed for an HOUR until the water ran cold. All artificial color was removed from my roots and they were the pale blonde shade I was expecting; however, the rest of my hair remained a hideous pale red, with the ends being darker than the middle. My hair was also extremely brittle. I applied two hot oil treatments hopingthat might lighten it further while restoring moisture. My hair felt better but wasn't any lighter. So I admitted defeat and started calling friends for recommendations of local colorists. First thing Monday morning I tucked my tail between my legs and went to the salon where I ended up spending plenty of time and money. I didn't want to risk breakage by using bleach so I opted to go darker than the medium blonde I was aiming for. After having a filler applied, my roots dyed darker, a medium beige blonde applied all over, a few foil highlights on top and an allover gloss, my hair is light caramel brown w/ beige blond highlights and looks very nice. I will never stray from the salon again. - BOTTOM LINE - if your hair is in really good shape and you're only looking to go a shade lighter, this stuff will probably do the trick but if you've colored your hair repeatedly or need to lighten several shades, I'd recommend going to the salon. Also, I do NOT have asthma but this stuff gave me a hacking cough and made my nose run both times that I used it even though I was in a large bathroom with an exhaust fan. I was still coughing a day later - and when I coughed, I could taste that rotten egg smell. Gross and probably not healthy so use with caution.
  269. Alright, so a little back story for ya, I'm 21 years old who has NEVER dyed her hair before. I decided, hey, time for a change! Let's try ombre. Specifically light brown(natural color) to blonde at tips. Well, my hairdresser I guess didn't get the idea i was thinking of from the 30 pictures i showed her, but that's besides the point. It ended up being basically blonde from a couple inches from my scalp to my tips so i had her re-dye it back to my natural hair color yesterday and she dyed it BLACK. Like, black as black and no offense to anyone with black hair, but that's just not me. at all. So here I am looking like a big weirdo with black hair. This product had great reviews online, some bad some good, as you could probably tell because I'm probably one of 20 you just read. My hair is long (about mid way down my back) and thick so I prepared two bottles and i ended up used 100% of one bottle and 50% of the other. Definitely do a test strand first! I cut a chunk of hair off in the middle of my head on the one side(the least obvious place) and when i was finished with the test, I was very pleased with the color. On a side note, I just left the test strand in the sink. I didn't put it in the sun or near a heater or anything. My house is probably 67-70 degrees right now. The only reason I'm sharing this is because it's VERY important that you are extremely consistent. If you leave your test strand in the sink, just bend over and leave your hair in the tub for as long as you can stand it. You WILL get different results if your test strand is in the heat, washed for 2 minutes, shampoo, etc. and then when you treat your head, it's cold water, rinse for 5 minutes, etc. so make sure if you do anything, it's stay consistent so the results you see on the test strand is exactly what your whole head will look like. Make sure you time it too! It's recommended for 20 minutes but everyone on the reviews seems to steer you away from that time. Personally, I figured I'd rather haveit in for not long enough than too long so I went with 10 minutes for the test strand and 8 minutes when I covered my entire head(left 2 minutes for application time so i stayed consistent with 10 mins). Do the skin test too! It sounds dumb, but I couldn't imagine dumping this all over my head and then having my scalp develop an allergic reaction. That just sounds like hell to me. Alright, so I dumped it all over my head and it says to use a comb to make sure it is evenly spread out, but my hair got really knotted from all that I was doing to it so I just made sure that I soaked my hair to the very core because there was no way I was getting a comb through it. All of the reviews say that rinsing is the most important part, but don't freak out if your rinsing your hair and your hot water only stays on for 10 minutes. That's what happened to me and it came out fine. Just wash it for 20 if you can or until your water gets kind of cold. As you'll probably be able to feel, your hair gets tough because of all the rinsing so I put in conditioner and let it sit in until I had hot water again (10-20 minutes). Another side note, I'm not sure if some peoples noses are just more delicate than mine, but I do not agree with what everyone is saying about the smell. Yes, it is a little overwhelming when your applying it, but that's because you're using an ENTIRE bottle of it and assuming your hair is flipped over in the tub, it's RIGHT next to your nose and eyes so it's going to be very strong. I obviously did it in my bathroom and I had the window wide open and about 5 minutes after rinsing, I couldn't smell it at all. My hair kind of smells like it, but after I shower again tomorrow, I'm 100% sure the smell will be nonexistent. End results!! My hair looks almost exactly how it looked in the good ol' days before I went on pinterest and decided that ombre was for me. I will never dye my hair again, and this product is the closest thing you will get to time-traveling back in timeand slapping yourself right in the face for ever doing whatever you did to your already perfect hair color. Good luck to your hair dying adventures and remember, Hair test, skin test, be consistent, rinse, time!

  281. After my last coloring extravaganza, the color I chose decided to turn my hair purple!! In my younger years I wouldn't have minded so much, but at 23 I need to be a little bit more professional and purple hair didn't make the cut. I stumbled across Color Oops in my local Rite Aid and decided to give it a try. Only after I purchased the product did I begin to read reviews. DEFINITELY do a strand test. I cut a tiny strand from an inconspicuous place to test. If you have colored your hair more than once Color Oops will not remove all the color, saying it will only remove the most recent application. However, I know it removed more than just the most recent color. My hair came out its natural color at the roots and a medium to light auburn on the length. (Probably since most of the colors I choose have a lot of red in them.) Your hair WILL darken in the first 24 hours after use. So don't freak out if it's too light right after like I did. This is not a miracle product but did work as stated on the box. It does dry out your hair, but not nearly as bad as going to a pro and having it stripped or bleached. A heavy conditioner and a good leave-in are essential to have after application. I actually like the color it came out and do not plan on re-dying for a while. Would definitely use this product again if needed.
  282. This works, but be sure to follow the directions EXACTLY... for example, if it tells you to RINSE your hair in the shower for 20 minutes, RINSE IT FOR 20 MINUTES.. not 18 minutes, etc.. this is a very important step, because when you are in the shower rinsing this stuff out of your hair, THATS when its really doing its job, and the cuticle of your hair is open, and THATS when all of the MOLECULES OF COLOR ( the color you hate and are trying to get rid of ) are being washed out of your hair.. so if you just give it a half hearted rinse, it may look ok for a day or two, but then, by the 3rd day, your hair will start to somewhat darken again because the cuticle has closed back up-- closed back up around those molecules of color that you hated and wanted to get rid of -- because you didnt spend enough time rinsing your hair. Follow the directions *EXACTLY*, even if some of the steps seem un-needed, and you should be happy with the results. It worked great for me, and I would definitely recommend this product.
  283. I have naturally medium brown hair, but I've been dying it dark brown/black for at least a year now. This week I noticed that my roots were starting to come in, but I was getting tired of black hair, so I decided to go red. In order to do this I had to strip out all of the black hair dye build up. I wasn't sure if this would work, but I figured I'd try it since it got good reviews. It smelled like rotten eggs [there's some kind of sulfate in it], but my hair is back to a color I haven't seen since high school. There's no damage to speak of, my hair feels like it always does. I definitely recommend it, even if you've had dye in your hair for a really long time like I did.

  288. I used this product over henna and indigo (hendigo). This product IS NOT technically meant for this type of a dye. However, quite a few users on various hair forums had attempted it in order to try to get out their henna or hendigo, so I tried it as well. But I want to be clear that the product outright states that it is not for this type of colorant.<br /><br />It did get out some of the color. My hair was a darkest brown/black (not blue-black). It lifted to a medium brown and was not patchy or odd-looking at all. BEWARE hendigo users: I can clearly see that it lifted much more of the henna than the indigo. If I were to repeat applications I believe I'd wind up with bluish or greenish hair, as there would be more indigo left than henna (or perhaps no henna, and just indigo). Indigo is just the color it says, indigo. :D purplish-blue. If you're going to attempt something like this as I did, you could wind up with bluish, bluish-gray or greenish hair, so be ready for that. The usual fix would be to apply yellow-toned color if your hair turns blue, or reddish-toned color if your hair turns green (go opposite on the color wheel to tone down any given color).<br /><br />The stars off are not for the fact that it didn't remove all of my color. That would be unfair as the product was not meant for this type of color in the first place. Rather, the stars off are for:<br /><br />* The smell. I understand that it's a sulfur-based product, but I'm surprised that, given the technology it took to make this product, there couldn't also be some technology to tone down the smell. The smell remained in my house for several days even with all my windows open, and was overpowering. DON'T throw away the bottles, cap, etc. inside the house. Take them right out of the house and dispose of them in your outdoor garbage can. These WILL NOT tone down in smell over time and if you get them on your garbage can, you'll have to wash out your garbage can. The smell remained strong in my hair until my first COing (conditioner-only washing), then reappeared each time I wet my hair for about a month.<br /><br />* Burning/irritation. I definitely got burning using this product. I literally had red burns on my ears and on my neck. I don't know if I technically have any burns on my scalp but I know that I have a burning feeling overall on my scalp.<br /><br />* The rinse time. Again, given that some technology went into making this product, I'm wondering why there hasn't been some advance in how long the hair must be rinsed. Even if it's literally impossible to accomplish such a thing, I feel a star off is in order as the rinsing time will definitely get on some people's nerves and will use up A LOT of water, so be warned.<br /><br />Overall, I don't regret using the product. I would recommend it to the next person, with caution. Proceed carefully and good luck!

  293. My hair is thin/fine, but very long - halfway down my rear end. It is naturally dark chocolate, with reddish glints in sunlight. However, my roots have gotten more ashy like a dark mousy brown since the birth of my son a couple years ago, and it looks like I am getting two streaks of white just above each temple. I have colored my hair with deep brown to black temporary box color (Natural Instincts 10 minute, Perfect 10, etc) and most recently with a violet tinted black from Zotos Age Beautiful (1V Plum Black), which used a 10 volume developer. The bottom half of my hair seemed much darker(makes sense), and I wondered if the white streaks were longer than just the couple inches of new growth, so I decided to try Color Oops, intending to recolor later, and maybe do something fun with the streaks.<br /><br />Since my hair is so long, I used 2 boxes - 1 would not have been enough. I made 2 pony tails and put the first box on that part for 10 minutes, then applied box 2 to the rest, put on the shower cap and stood outside in the Texas sun for the rest of the 20 minutes. I expected a nasty smell, but frankly, it barely had a scent at all as far as I'm concerned. Kind of like a perm solution smell, but very faint. I used shampoo 5 times and rinsed, taking 30-35 minutes total rinse time, using hot water. I then applied conditioner (Zotos Age Beautiful Intense Strengthening all over and Loreal Healthy Look conditioner - left over after a recent hair coloring - just on the ends), put on a fresh shower cap, waited 5 minutes, then rinsed, cooling the water to cold at end and rinsing a good 5 minutes total with the cold water. My hair felt stiff at first, but I Applied Zotos Hairtrition color protect/detangler liberally before drying, and that seemed to help seal it. I dried with the hair dryer, then used the cool setting on the hair dryer to thoroughly cool hair after it was dry. Cooling your hair helps seal the cuticle back up. It feels no more damaged than before, so I'm pretty pleased.<br /><br />My hair did not have any breakage at all. Color clearly came out, and it went from black with a hint of brown to warm chestnut brown with a strong hint of red (but not brassy - its a nice natural looking shade). It is lighter at roots than ends, but I expected that, and it blends nicely. I was going to recolor the next day, but I am going to leave it for a while and see what the new growth looks like, as well as see how it looks in a couple weeks.
  294. I am a professional hair stylist and I am very pleased with the results of this color remover. I don't enjoy stripping color out of hair--it's so damaging. But this Color Oops left minimal damage, and I was very impressed. I only needed one box for shoulder-length hair. I followed the instructions on the box. I was removing demi-permanent color, and this really did the trick. My client's hair had a nice warm brown tone to it, close to her natural color, and we didn't tone afterwards because it looked quite pretty. We didn't do any other processing afterwards, just a protein filler to counteract any porosity damage (which you will get when doing any type of chemical treatment) and we then highlighted with a toned bleach (Kaleidocolor) 2-3 weeks afterwards, which turned out great. All in all, I am satisfied with the results of this Color Oops and I will use it again in a heartbeat if I need to.

I already had a box of color! Lucky me, right? :/<br /><br />I dyed my medium brown hair using a dark brown dye. My hair always grabs color, so this came out seriously dark brown. Almost black, Goth dark brown. I didn't have any tones and highlights, it looked like a wig.<br /><br />Color Oops worked like a charm. I put it on quickly, and after 20 minutes headed to the shower. Bring a radio and a timer. This takes FOREVER. I washed my hair, lathering for 5 minutes. Rinsed for 10 minutes. Rewashed my hair, lathering for 5 minute. Rinsed for 10 minutes. Rewashed my hair, lathering for 5 minutes. Rinsed again. Got out of the shower, towel-dried my hair, and added a thick protein-based conditioner. Left the conditioner on for 20 minutes. Got back in the shower and rinsed out the conditioner for 5 minutes. Then I used the conditioner that came with my box of hair dye, and left that on for 5 minutes. Rinsed for several minutes once again.<br /><br />Most of the dark brown dye was removed from my hair leaving my hair a standard medium brown. My hair does feel terrible, and I had the worst rats-nests and tangles I've had since I was a little girl. I used a leave-in conditioner to help me slide the tangles out, and my hair looks and feels pretty good. In fact, I probably won't re-dye it again right away. It looks just fine.<br /><br />Cons:<br />This stuff stinks. Make sure you have a good bathroom fan.<br />This takes forever to work. Bring some entertainment. I listened to podcasts.<br />This stuff is a bit runny. Be careful, it burns/itches a bit when it's on your skin.<br />Whether or not this works for you is based a bit on how well you wash and rinse your hair. It shrinks the color molecules, you have to physically wash them out.<br />This stuff will make your hair feel like straw. Be prepared with a thick protein conditioner, or two, or three.<br /><br />Pros:<br />IT WORKS! This stuff just saved me a $150 trip to the salon!<br /><br />To address some comments: I used this product exactly for what it was intended, lightening too-dark permanent hair color. It says in the box that it doesn't work on direct dyes like Manic Panic and it's not for semi-permanent color, and it won't put your hair back the way it was before you bleached it. I believe it works like a charm if you use it for what it was intended. Based on a lot of comments, if you try to make it do something it wasn't formulated for, you'll have bad results.ared with a thick protein conditioner, or two, or three.<br /><br />Pros:<br />IT WORKS! This stuff just saved me a $150 trip to the salon!<br /><br />To address some comments: I used this product exactly for what it was intended, lightening too-dark permanent hair color. It says in the box that it doesn't work on direct dyes like Manic Panic and it's not for semi-permanent color, and it won't put your hair back the way it was before you bleached it. I believe it works like a charm if you use it for what it was intended. Based on a lot of comments, if you try to make it do something it wasn't formulated for, you'll have bad results.
  296. Okay so yesterday I had my naturally dark brown hair (between 3 and 4) dyed a shade darker, and it was way too dark and severe looking on me! I immediately began looking for solutions and found Color Oops and read all the rave reviews and saw all the youtube videos, so today I went and did my hair and it worked great for me. My hair is about shoulder length and very thick but one box was more than enough, I had quite a bit left over. Yes it smells pretty bad - exactly like rotten eggs - but it was easily bearable so who cares? Oh and have some scissors or something to cut the tip of the squirt top off! It is very runny and hard to apply as it drips, so I squirted some in my hand and rubbed it in. That worked well just make sure to apply evenly. I could tell when it was in the shower cap that it was working. My hair is pretty dark and looks almost black when wet, but it has a soft brown tone to it, and I could see that slight brown tone was returning before even starting to shampoo and rinse. And oh the rinsing! I did it for 25 minutes to be safe - I set a timer on my phone and placed it on the window by the shower where I could see it. I also had my laptop and played music the whole time, which I definitely recommend. It was almost relaxing ... well it would be if it was not so tedious! The hot water never ran out even 25 minutes later, perhaps we just have a good water heater haha When I had it in the shower cap I could see the roots in the middle of my head were almost a caramely type color, and the rest looked like my normal hair when wet. I think I applied it a bit too much to the top part of my head and was a little worried it would be uneven. When I got out my hair looked normal, and the whole top was slightly lighter/caramely than my natural hair, and I mean the whole top not just the roots so it looked good. But now a couple hours later it is not really any lighter than normal, which I am frankly disappointed about because I really liked it, perhaps I will use the rest of it or get another box and try it again to see if it will stick. My hair now has a pronounced coppery/red tint that looks nice (my hair naturally has a very very very slight coppery tint to it). Overall this product worked very well and was cheap ($9 something at Wal-Mart)and so I am very happy. I am the ideal candidate for this product though, having my virgin hair gone darker less than 24 hours ago, so it might not work as well for others. I am not planning to dye my hair again, but will probably use the rest of the Color Oops tonight or tomorrow but for now I need a break from my hair ... plus I want to see what it looks like completely dry - I hate blow drying - and give it a chance to settle as I hear that it can darken over the next day or two.<br /><br />Oh and it did not damage my hair at all. While rinsing it felt dry but only from the prell shampoo I used and as soon as I put conditioner in it was smooth as silk. I got a deep conditioner but did not use it because my hair felt fine. I will probably use it next time though cause I have it. Feel free to ask me if you have any questions! I put a pic in the images so you can see what my hair looked like throughout this journey.

My roots are almost completely white. I've been dyeing it fairly dark brown for several years and wanted to soften it a bit as I've gotten older. Since color, won't lighten color, I had to get rid of the previous color first. I followed the directions carefully and after using Color Oops my hair was a lovely brownish-yellow color. I didn't panic since everything said that was to be expected. 20 minutes seemed like forever to rinse, but I wasn't going to cut corners at that point. My hair felt very dry after rinsing out the Color Oops, but I put some heavy duty condition on it and then some Frizz-ease on my damp hair and it actually felt very good after that. I waited until the next morning to dye again and first used a bottle of protein hair filler on it (small bottle, ~$2 at Sally's Beauty Supply). I don't know if that made a difference, but several people had recommended it and it definitely didn't seem to hurt. Then, the part that made me the most nervous since I was very unsure of what color to try. I only went from a 6 to a 6 1/2 even though the directions said it would dye darker. I left the dye on for about 5 minutes since I could tell it was taking the color very quickly and amazingly enough I got a color very close the color on the box. I am very happy - I have a color a shade lighter that what I was using with no ill effects!

Just as the other reviewer experienced it did not dye my hair the color it was intended (dark ash brown). Instead, it came out black and spotty in some areas! I read all the reviews, rushed to CVS picked up a box and took the plunge last night as soon as I got home from work. I must say that 20 is quite a long time to stand/sit in a shower and rinse your hair. The last few minutes I was really getting impatient... Its not like you can read a book in the shower! LOL. However, whatever it took I was willing. I then washed my hair and rinsed for 5 minutes and repeated the process a second time. If I had more patience I would have rinsed my hair for another 20 minutes. I have two hot water heaters in my house and I had used up all the hot water by the time I was finished! I then conditioned my hair for 5 minutes, rinsed again and let it air dry. The dark hue isn't completely gone, but it (as my husband says) is 100% better than it was. Instead of a dull black on the tips of my hair I can see the natural red undertones in my hair again. which, I've never been happier to see! It now looks like I have deep brown low lights in my hair with copper highlights. My husband even said my hair is closer to the color it was when we first started dating... much of a relief to me. The product also left my hair looking shiny. Probably mostly due to the conditioner, but I don't feel my hair is damaged in anyway. I also wanted to comment about the smell that so many reviewers mentioned. Honestly, I don't know how some people color their hair if they thought this product smelled awful. There is a smell (a very diluted mild sulfur smell), but perms smell more overwhelming. Hope this helped!

  308. I have been coloring and treating my own hair for about a year now. Before that, I worked in the salon industry and was very conscientious about my hair. Yes, it is a little orange, and it's not my natural color. But for the time I spent using the product, it was completely worth it. I followed the directions well, although I didn't patch or strand test. But I applied it from the back to the front, ensuring my highlighted pieces were the last to get the product. I kept it on the full 20 minutes. I then rinsed for 15, washed, rinsed for another 10, washed again and rinsed for another 5, conditioned and rinsed for 10, then washed, rinsed, and conditioned again. I know it seems excessive on washing and conditioning, but rinsing gets boring and the hair feels like straw. The conditioning I did (using moisturizing masks and leaving on for 3-5 minutes) really helped my hair go through this process- it came out even softer and healthier than before, I also did a coconut oil treatment the same morning before using Color Oops. The color came out light, and continued to lighten over the evening! The next step for me is to tone it using blue food coloring and vinegar. Just be smart and take care of your hair, and this product is great!

A few days ago I had the day off and I was bored so on an impulse (as bad decisions often are) I decided to dye my hair a light auburn red color. It came out awful. Seriously terrible. Very fiery orange and completely wrong for my skin tone. I was going to make a salon appointment to fix asap, but instead, decided to give Color Oops a whirl. As I have bleached my hair at home before and ended up with yellow/brassy hair, I also purchased a box of light ash blonde to tone afterwards, since I assumed that Color Oops would turn my hair yellow or orange. BUT IT DIDN'T. I didn't need the box dye. Color Oops lifted the red out completely and brought my hair to a really nice blonde (evenly, too!) I did, however, shampoo and rinse like crazy. Overall, I spent 30 minutes in the shower rinsing/shampooing/rinsing etc. I think this is a really vital step to how successful your results are.<br /><br />Regarding the smell: it's not as bad as I thought it would be. A little like rotten eggs, but nothing intolerable.<br /><br />Regarding the damage: unfortunately, my hair didn't come out damage-free. It doesn't look quite as raggedy as it might have if I'd bleached it, but it does feel dry right now. However, this might have been due to the red dye, and maybe the cheap shampoo I used on it (I read that cheap shampoo has more detergents, so it helps strip the color). It's probably nothing some deep conditioning wont solve, however.<br /><br />I cannot stress enough how much of a miracle this product is. I was so skeptical going in, but my results were fantastic.
  315. I just used this product yesterday and it worked great! I've been dying my hair black for the last several months and finally decided it was time for a change so I purchased this product. Although the smell was really strong and made me feel a little sick, the product works really well and the smell doesn't linger after you wash it out. The product removed all the black dye from my hair and brought it back to its natural medium brown shade. I recommend it.

My hair is at least 3 shades lighter and back to (what I'm pretty sure is) my natural color!

  319. My hair is naturally a golden strawberry blonde but in the past 6 months I've dyed my hair dark brown three times.   320. I have been coloring my own hair at home for about 12 years. I mean marathon coloring. I've had every color under the sun except for platinum. Over the last 2-3 years I like to think my taste in color has somewhat matured. I generally stick to rich dark browns and red browns (barring the brief fire engine red phase). I got home yesterday from a beach vacation and decided to refresh my color after my several days in the sun, saltwater, and chlorine. As usual, I opted for a rich reddish brown. Unfortunately, I used a new brand of color and to my horror, my hair was almost black even after blow drying. Being a seasoned veteran of the hair catastrophe clan, I rushed out to get some Color Oops. My hair isn't particularly long but it's ridiculously thick so I bought two boxes at Walmart for about $9-$10 each. I came home and followed the instructions to a T. (OK, so maybe I didn't quite hit the exact goals on the rinsing time. But I still rinsed like crazy!) I was left with this super awesome (read awful) brassy orange color. I was not shocked, I knew what to expect. But at least now I had a lighter color to work with. As soon as it was dry, I followed it with my regular brand of dark reddish brown. And this is the tricky part. I know from previous experience how quickly your hair will darken when recoloring after Color Oops. I've never applied color to my hair faster than I did today. And literally as soon as I stepped away from the mirror where I applied the color, I stepped to the faucet to rinse it out. Due to my haste, I do think I missed a few spots here and there but overall I was left with a color similar to my original goal color. I do feel like the final color is not quite as vibrant as I'd like. Call it &#34;ashy&#34; if you will. However, if you actually read the instructions, this is to be expected. Bottom line, I'm left with a color very similar to what I wanted originally and in time I'll be able to color it again to get exactly what I want. Much better than the black that I ended up with after the first round of color! Therefore, the Color Oops did exactly what it was supposed to do and for that I'm grateful. Again, for me, the biggest concern is making sure that you don't leave the 2nd round of color on too long or you'll end up right back where you started. Thank you Color Oops for another saved hair botch. Until next time....
  321. (Just for some background, as every person's hair color and dying experience will be different) I have the following colors on my shoulder-length Caucasian hair: Henna (ends to midway, not boxed stuff either, 100% natural BAQ henna), chemical BOX dyes going back from Nov-Dec 2014 (red, then black), removed using Color B4 and now mid 2015 med browns at hairdresser to mask the inevitable resulting orange). I have used both Color B4 (English equiv to Color Oops - or so I thought!) and Color Oops several times over the past 4 or 5 years with no trouble or affect on the natural color. Perhaps 4-5 times each brand! The stuff has been a miracle for me in the past. (Bye bye to my Morticia hair!)<br /><br />Onto this week. Imagine my confusion when in one dose of Color Oops I not only end up with the brassiness that I was expecting (happens every time, hair colorants = bleach, except for with henna)... but with almost 8 MONTHS of root growth suddenly lightened as surely as if I'd used a bleach product!<br /><br />So, breathe, chill, I'm trying to go back to natural color anyway, spilt milk and all, so I go to Sally's to pick up some demi permanents to try getting back to my natural 6 warm color so I can leave the world (wait, no, prison) of hair coloring, roots and damage behind me. I ask the lady who owns the store for Color Oops I realized there's still some darker deposits waiting to oxidize in my hair. She tells me &#34;Don't use that - it contains bleach or something. Another customer came in last week with the same problem you have and we decided something's going on there&#34;. She recommended Color Fix instead which I used and it worked well. I can't attest to whether it would have done the same lightening effect on my hard-earned roots as Color Oops. I'm probably scared off of these products for life, perhaps not Color B4 -- that's never failed for me.<br /><br />In short, if you decide to use this to get rid of OLD color, perhaps have someone capable ofapplying the product with a tint brush and mixing bowl to only hit the dyed ends. Don't just slather it all over like some kinda hair mask. Also, Color FIX came with a lotion to rinse after the washing process, so you can test if any residual colors are lurking within that will interfere with a corrective or additional color you plan on doing later on. I feel like I can get 2 uses from the Color Fix product, but you'll only get 1 use out of Color Oops unless you have short or super thin hair. Color Fix also doesn't ask for like 30 minutes of rinsing, just 3-5 (I did about 15 though, then shampoo'd THEN used the lotion)<br /><br />Some tips, if you're looking into the product for the first time, or any of the removers for that matter. Not a pro but I've been doing this with myself as a guinea pig for a while.<br />- LEAVE OFF YOUR JEWELRY. This stuff turned one of my rings the same orange it turned my hair. It's just doing what it does.<br />- Whether you went black, red or bleach blonde, your natural color has almost certainly be altered by the developer, esp with gross box dyes.<br />- i.e. You will likely have a brassy result even if your hair was once ash. It's worse if you're a dark/warm/golden/red haired person though, i.e. if your hair naturally glows reddish or looks a &#34;warm&#34; color in the sun. I think dying exposes that pigment and Color Oops shows that up.<br />- I have never encountered any damage from this process. Some people do though. But most importantly DO NOT add conditioners or anything else straight after using except for a clarifying shampoo for the initial rinsing process. I wait about 3-4 days before using any oil or conditioning products on my hair to avoid &#34;trapping&#34; any unwanted residual dye molecules in the hair cuticles. So: Wash, wash, wash, THEN shampoo, then like 3 days of just combing and scraping your hair back into whatever style it agrees with.<br />- I do not think it works well on stain dyes such as Manic Panic, Directions or even demi dyes, but I have successfully gotten one color out so it is worth a try if you're desperate. You might want to try a salon in this case.<br />- Do the process in a warm room to speed it up or get the most from it. You must RINSE well. Otherwise the old shrunken dye molecules will bounce right back with oxidization. Happens to me all the time with this specific color remover, which is partly why I dislike it so much compared to the others I've used, RE-OXIDIZATION.<br />- Avoid using this process twice in a row. If you can, wait a few days in-between if you really must, for condition AND for your poor hair's sake.<br /><br />I regret ever dying my hair or using sulfate shampoos. If you've never dyed your hair and are looking into it -- at least do your research into demi dyes or think long and hard. Maintenance, roots and damage are certainly not worth it, at least for me. I would love to get back my pre-raphaelite hair! Natural hair is awesome.<br /><br />Tips even if they help just one person out there<br />- Good professionals. (Correction, demi jobs)<br />- If you're after change, maybe try changing hair STYLE, not color.<br />- Avoid permanent box dyes, or box dyes in general. You cannot control the strength of the developer in these. Look into getting a developer and the color to do yourself, as you can control the results much better! (Only took me 5 years + like 30 dyes to figure this one out!)<br />- If you're impatient, slow-grower or dislike the same color, avoid henna or any super dark colors -- good luck getting rid of true BAQ henna.<br />- After using every brand and product like this under the sun, I'm becoming sensitive to the nasty hair chemicals, Color Oops included. This product left me with a rash on my left ear where I have a piercing, and no it wasn't the earrings. My arms also itched that day and the day after, which is a new thing.
  322. I just want to really really let everyone know that color oops actually works!!! I had my hair bleached blonde for over summer, and my stylist was supposed to just darken my hair closer to my natural hair color--medium soft brown. She turned my hair jet black and when I asked her to fix it, she put little high lights in my jet black hair. Two days have passed and today I used two boxes of color oops in my hair. I followed the directions and used for only 20 mins. The next thing it says is to rinse and repeat. Ladies and gentlemen, please actually do that! It makes all the difference. My hair looks so beautiful, the jet black hair is gone! What is here is some of my highlights and my medium brown hair with the slightest hint of red. I think what is important is not to wait longer than 72 hours to put the product on and to actually take the time to follow the directions.

I am probably 75% gray, but it didn't take the color all the way to the grey, and I don't think it ever would.<br /><br />Because I had a lot of grey roots already growing out, I used a &#34;protein filler&#34; (aka, protein conditioner, color filler), which you must use if you plan on coloring it right after you use color oops. If you don't use it, the next color will grab to dark, and uneven. It doesn't come with the oops, so you'll need to purchase it separately. I got mine at 'Sally's salon supplies'. Put it on damp hair, let sit 20 minutes, and blot with towel...don't rinse, and color as normal. (this is all listed in the 'tips' section of the oops directions for recoloring.)<br /><br />This product is excellent for restoring a dark color to a lighter brown/dark blond. Which is what it did for me. It is smelly, but no worse than a 'perm' smell, and you have to wash & rinse your hair so much, that it smells normal by the time you're done. It didn't damage my hair, and I don't have any red highlights left in it. It's a natural even light brown. LOVE IT!<br /><br />*(all the constant washing & rinsing did eventually make my scalp sore, and when I put the color on my roots, my scalp did burn a little, but not terrible. I only put the color on my grey roots. I didn't pull it through to the ends because I didn't want to damage my ends with excessive treatments, and I really like the color that was left behind with the oops anyway. The root color matched perfectly.)

  328. I have naturally light strawberry blonde hair. I hated it from the time I was young due to the fact I was the only one with that hair color. It came out dark dark brown, almost black, and it did not look good with my skin tone AT ALL. I left it on for 20 minutes, got in the shower, rinsed and shampooed, rinsed for 15 minutes, shampooed, rinsed for 5 additional minutes, shampooed two more times. At this point I could feel that my hair was very dry, so I put in a deep conditioner and got out of the shower. I put a cap over my head and left the conditioner in (olive oil based) for 45 minutes. I rinsed, towel dried, and then blow dried my hair. I was very surprised at what I saw. Keep in mind the directions said it could not remove bleach or a light color, only darker colors. Also I had about 1/2 inch roots of my natural strawberry blonde. Well, my hair is now my natural color-it matches my roots PERFECTLY. There is no brown whatsoever. It is a light strawberry blonde with blonde and red highlights, as it was when I was younger. I have no idea how this happened, but it was quite amazing. I haven't seen my hair this way for over 8 years. And ironically I love my hair color now, and I'm very grateful for this product for allowing me to see it again. My hair feels great and I won't be damaging it anymore with bleaches and dye. I can't think of anything bad to say about this product, other then the smell. However, it wasn't even that bad (All dyes and products smell bad in my opinion). I used the product 3 hours ago, and with all the shampooing and the deep conditioning my hair does not smell like the product anymore. I would highly recommend Color Oops!

I can live with this color.<br /><br />It does smell, but not as bad as you might think. You must rinse it for at least 20 minutes or the dye molecules may not all be washed out and can reappear in your hair. It takes a long time, but is worth it.   333. I've been dying my hair for years, and anytime I've wanted to make a change, I've used Color Oops, and it's worked! After years of dying my hair black, I used color oops and it lifted all of the black dye out, leaving the processed hair behind, which was now a lovely orangey color instead of my natural brown.<br /><br />Tips:<br />Don't expect to be able to use this product and NOT dye your hair. If you're stripping out color and leaving behing processed hair, it will have a weird tone. The chemicals don't magically know what your original hair color is and return it.<br />This product WILL NOT WORK on a non oxidative hair color like Manic Panic or other vegetable based demi-perm dyes.<br />RINSE. This product works by shrinking the oxidative hair dye molecules so they can be rinsed out of your hair. If you don't rinse well, they will reoxidize and your hair will get darker again. Also, if you don't rinse, when you recolor your hair, those shrunken molecules will reoxidize and redeposit in your hair.<br /><br />You can recolor right away, but the color will come out several shades darker. If you wait overnight and treat with a deep conditioner the new color will be much more true.<br /><br />If you want to get your current permenant color out, or you want to go from dyed black to blond without frying your hair, this is a great product. I was able to get all the black dye out and bleach part of my hair to almost platnium in a single day without damaging my hair.

Waited the times in the shower for rinsing...followed the shampooing instructions... The smell wasn't too bad but it does linger so it begins to get bad because you get sick of it.   335. I was very skeptical before using this product, as I've used other color removers before. Previous products I've tried have left my hair very brittle, dry, and various shades of peach (none of which are desirable). My hair was most recently supposed to be a warm dark brown, but the end result was black. Black black. I tried to reason with the darkness for a while, but decided I couldn't live with it any longer. I got Color Oops and a box of medium-light brown color to use after Color Oops. Here goes nothing, I thought. Color Oops is runny, smells like a mix of rotten eggs and cow patties, and explodes when you open it after shaking the mixture (of the two ingredients). It does, however, really work. I used half a bottle on my head (I have long hair) and followed the instructions to rinse, rinse, shampoo, rinse, and shampoo and rinse again. Hesitant, I looked in the mirror... and it was pretty! Brown! Not black! Due to the success of attempt number one, I used the rest of the bottle on my head (dry) and let it sit for another 20 minutes. Then, back in the shower for another thirty minute wash-and-rinse fest. Out I came the second time with really lovely medium brown hair with lots of shine, thought the rest of the family was out of hot water for the night. It worked well enough I didn't need to use the box of color I purchased along with the Color Oops. I'm pleased with the nice warm brown it left my hair. My hair, even after two processes and all that shampooing, feels soft and healthy - I detect no damage from Color Oops. I'm very impressed with this product, and the value is superb. I highly recommend! Notes - Really follow the directions with shampooing and rinsing, even though it will take you some time. Do it right. - If your hair was bleached PRIOR to being colored, or if you color had a 'lift' element to it (any type of bleach/peroxide), your hair WILL NOT go back to your natural color by using Color Oops - it will go back to the lifted/bleached/peroxided color. - It, apparently, doesn't work on bright rainbow colors - only shades of natural hair color. - I did strand test a piece of my hair (post Color Oops) with the box of color I purchased, just to see... and the instructions in Color Oops don't lie! It WILL color DARKER than what your color box shows. It really, really will. Be aware of that and purchase a much lighter color than you'd like the results to be, if you plan to color after Color Oops. - Did I mention it smells? Open a window.

The top of my hair was a funky reddish purple and the bottom half was jet black. I read the reviews on here and I figured I would give it a try. I bought it at my local Walmart. I applied it to my hair and left it on for more than the allotted time, as I wanted to make sure the black and red were completely gone. I left it on for an extra ten minutes. I did follow directions closely when washing and rinsing. I washed and rinsed for the complete time stated. I used a clarifying shampoo. In the shower it did feel like a big clump of straw. After I finished washing and rinsing I immediately used conditioner. My hair came out great!!!! No more black or red. It is not my original color which is a dirty blond,it's more of a strawberry blond. My hair did not turn out a funky color, and I am extremely satisfied with the end result!!!!! ************ UPDATE*********** Jan. 29 2012 My hair has went back to the original color it was before I used the Color OOPS.
  342. I used this product once before on brown hair that had been dyed for years and hated the results I got, but then again attempted to use it a couple hours ago on freshly dyed brown hair and LOVED IT so heres the deal:<br />(by the way this is for people going from brown to blonde, sorry..)<br /><br />The first time I tried color oops I had already had brown hair for about a little more than a year and had used it for about 15 minutes . When I rinsed and dried my hair I did achieve the blonde look I was going for unfortunately it was orange and yellow and I REALLY wish I knew about toner but hey, so thats that.<br /><br />I have been blonde for years after that and LOVE IT I was always a natural blonde so my complexion is perfect for it and brown hair just washes me out and makes me look eternally sad, now I went to Supercuts today and asked for a glaze, they misunderstood me and gave me a demi permanent color WHATEVER NOT A BIG DEAL yeah thats what I thought, I originally picked a color that was IDENTICAL to that of my honey light blonde hair, even having the highlighted look I was going for but unfortunately once she washed my hair and dried it for me it was an ugly reddish brown color and I was in complete shock. I have never really had an emotional attachment to my hair since it is always changing but this was just gross. I panicked. Bought dandruff shampoo which made my hair a little lighter and literally shampooed my hair like 8 times finally i gave up and did the color oops knowing that it was the most damaging besides bleach. I brushed it through and waited for 10 minutes only to be surprised with a LOVELY honey blonde (although I did use purple shampoo to rinse I must admit, and I must also recommend for people with brassy orangey red tones in their hair or from hair dye, my hair picks up on that very harshly) My hair color now is even better than the blonde I had before and I am really wanting to call up the makers of this fabulous brand find them and give them a hug because this was truly a lifesaver.   343. This product works really well. The smell isn't great but I didn't have as extreme of an aversion to it as some reviewers did. It removed my dark-dark brown hair color, my hair is now a warm light brown. If you've ever lightened your hair or if your dye had any bleaching agents (a lot do) it won't go back to your natural color. However, it isn't orange or anything and I can wear it down in public no problem.<br /><br />Tips: you have to shampoo and rinse for at least 20 minutes or else it won't work. I set an alarm on my phone and it's a bit tiring, so make sure you leave yourself enough time. Also, get a good deep conditioner 'cause this will dry out your hair a bit. I put the deep conditioner on with a shower cap (plastic bag will also work) for 40 minutes after I finished rinsing and my hair is soft now.

  346. Overall, Color Oops does the job.<br /><br />However, if you skip/ don't complete the rinse cycles then be prepared for your newly removed color to reappear!<br />The rinsing is what gets the color out and if you don't remove all the color... your hair will oxidize back to the color you were removing!<br /><br />I recently tried removing my black hair dye, but did not remove the color molecules enough during my rinse cycle. So, I ended up with a pretty dark auburn color, but when I tried to apply a new hair dye... my hair grabbed the new color and turned black in (what seemed like) seconds! I waited and tried a second Color Oops process, with the same auburn results. This time, I used a protein filler afterwards then tried bleaching my hair a bit lighter with a bleach wash. The bleach wash was tinted with blue to help combat brassiness, but the blue in the bleach turned my hair back to black instead! Not a single hair lightened from the bleach! So now I am left with black hair again that is a whole lot worse off than before I started. My hair is not fried or dead from all this... but it is not as soft as usual. So it's safe to say I can restore my hair even after all this.<br /><br />Take my advice, be prepared to take a chance when using Color Oops.<br />Be prepared to rinse, rinse, rinse, and rinse for almost 30 mins! You will be a raisin after being in the shower that long!<br />Be prepared that your hair can darken even days after you remove your color. Color molecules not fully removed can come back and bite you in the butt!<br />Be prepared that if you re-dye afterwards (or bleach like in my case) your hair can turn darker again!<br /><br />I have decided to wait a long while before attempting to remove my black dye again. Lots of deep conditioning with virgin coconut oil and keratin treatments in my future.<br />I don't think I hate Color Oops, but I do not think it is the color remover for me. I will be using a different color remover that does not use the same process as Color Oops in the future.

After seeeing what others did to REMOVE the henna - I got the required products/stuff to do this with: Bottled lemon juice and Color Oops. I soaked my hennaed hair in lemon juice with 2 plastic shower hats and left it on a 1-hour (with towel to catch drips). I did this 3 times in one week and this visibly faded the henna. Then on a Friday I applied the Color Oops on my dry hair. I followed the insructions. But I rinsed w/warm water then soaped it up with dish soap! Then rinsed another 15 minutes. The henna is gone and im left with a &#34;after you bleached&#34; color.
  351. I'm a natural blonde who'd been dying my hair red (Loreal Excellence 8RB in case anyone cares) for about a year and a half. While I loved the red color, I got tired of all the work to keep it up, and shelling out money for it. After doing a search on color removal products, I settled on this one since it seemed to have the best reviews.<br /><br />To start with, I got a bit nervous because the instructions inside the box said if you have thick or long hair, you might need two bottles-worth to get out all the color (which it did NOT say anywhere on the Amazon page, grr), and I'd only purchased one (I have an overabundance of hair that reaches the middle of my back). But, I pressed on since I figured I'd be able to sneak out the next day and buy more if need be.<br /><br />I followed the instructions, and waited around 20 min before washing it out, making sure to strand check often. I became a little more nervous because it didn't seem like the color was coming out at all, and every time I reached under the shower cap to pull out a strand to check, the pungent smell of rotten eggs hit my nostrils. Then, when I got into the shower and started rinsing out my hair, I didn't see any color going down the drain, just clear water. The texture of my hair was also really bad (I think hay might have felt like silk in comparison).<br /><br />HOWEVER, when I checked some of the hair at this point, it did look blonde. So, as per the instructions (and especially since other reviewers highly insisted the instructions be followed precisely) I rinsed my hair out for the entire length of time I was supposed to and lo-and-behold, when I dried my hair and had a chance to inspect it - it was blonde!<br /><br />I ended up putting around a giant palmful of Argon Oil into my hair to combat the dryness, and it's still somewhat dry the next day. I also neglected to remove the trash with all the different items from the Color Oops bottle, and boy does my bathroom smell bad the next day because of it!<br /><br />All-in-all, if you want an effective color remover, this is the product for you. Just be sure to have a super strong conditioning agent on hand for afterward, and be prepared to toss out the trash that very same day.<br /><br />And really do follow the instructions about rinsing time - even after all that time, I still have a faint smell of rotten eggs in my hair...
  352. First; many thanks to all those who took the time to review Color Oops in detail - that was very helpful for me to decide to try it.<br /><br />I am, lets say, &#34;getting older&#34; and got an awful lot of those &#34;platinum blonde&#34; (I refuse to call them &#34;gray!&#34;) hairs making their own highlights in my otherwise light brown with natural red highlights, medium shoulder length hair. I usually only color my hair twice, maybe three times, a year - at home as a single mom who has time or money for the salon when there's kids to feed and bills to pay!<br /><br />Well, having a few days off but not a lot of money; decided to &#34;treat&#34; myself to my Spring-time coloring; had chosen what I thought was a nice shade of medium auburn. Turned out; for whatever reason - the color I ended up with was a dark brown, almost straight black, with burgundy tint! And as much I as love the color purple - in my hair for other than a holiday - NOT so much! It might have looked lovely on someone else; but was 1) entirely too much burgundy in it for my taste; 2) entirely too dark and drastic a change; and 3) worse; a horrible waste of money!<br /><br />I was very disappointed, not to mention horrified every time I looked in the mirror. I tried shampooing my hair several times; no use; that purple didn't want to go anywhere!<br /><br />Not wanting to go back to work and have to face the (well meant) teasing of turning myself into an aging Snow White; and with few hopes of finding any help other than Time - I did an online search; and found reviews on an amazing product: Color Oops!<br /><br />Hesitant to &#34;throw good money after bad&#34;; I read reviews; watched YouTube videos; and thanks especially to the reviewers here who gave such good details of their experiences (and RoseRed; bless you for your honesty and humor!); I trundled out to the local store; still rather un-sure after some of the reviews if one box would be enough. Since funds are limited; I boughtjust the one box and hoped it would be enough. It was! My hair was thoroughly saturated with it. It is; as others have said; very &#34;thin&#34; consistency; so be careful to avoid drips. Maybe I have a cold; or a poor sense of smell; as it wasn't nearly as stinky as had expected it to be.<br /><br />I thoroughly read the directions - and YES you MUST do a strand test to determine the amount of time to leave the C.O. on your hair! Mine was 12 minutes; and actually I think if I'd only left the C.O. on for 9 or 10 it would have been perfect &#34;as is&#34;; as with the natural reddish I have to my hair anyway; slightly less time I would have had the light auburn I'd wanted to begin with! But; with only one bathroom in a full house; had to wait that extra 3 minutes for the room to open; so ended up with a little too light, almost bordering on strawberry blonde. So if you are NOT wanting to go reddish-blonde you will probably need to purchase another - LIGHTER than you want - hair dye.<br /><br />I was amazed how well it took out the brown/black, and thank the Heavens - the purple! I actually sat and debated on re-coloring; let my hair dry naturally and decided though I didn't mind the reddish-blonde; it was just a hint *too* blonde for my coloring; so used a box of the lightest &#34;neutral&#34; brown I could find.<br /><br />When I re-colored; I only used half the colorant in the bottle added to the developer; and; having read reviews cautioning against leaving the new color on too long (your hair is really porous after using the C.O., so will take a new color &#34;faster&#34;; pay attention in the instructions on the C.O. - it says don't leave the new color on the ends for longer than 5 minutes). I started the new color on the top of my head (all those &#34;platinum blonde&#34; streaks were back in full force) and worked towards the ends; being mindful of the caution about not leaving new color on too long or it'd be too dark; and could tell by looking; by the time I'd finished the ends; the top of my head was &#34;done&#34; - so I don't think I left the new color on for more than 5 minutes total.<br /><br />I washed the new color out; rinsed well; and repeated - followed with the included conditioner I left on for 5 minutes; rinsed thoroughly again for another 5 minutes; towel dried and combed. I didn't notice any breakage or major damage; though the ends looked a little &#34;dry&#34;, so I sprayed on some leave-in conditioner on them.<br /><br />The final result: woohoo and a huge &#34;thank you!&#34; to Color Oops for getting rid of the &#34;oops!&#34; in my hair - and thanks to the new color (I used &#34;Nice n Easy&#34;, light neutral brown); my hair is much more back to normal - just looks like I touched it up a bit to get rid of the &#34;blondes&#34; but has nice highlights and just enough of a hint of my natural red to it.<br /><br />So my experience is a positive one too with Color Oops - and will definitely keep it in mind if in future there's another &#34;oops&#34; moment!

  356. I got a bit carried away on this review, so if you don't really care about the background story, skip down to the \\"COLOR OOPS\\" Heading.<br /><br />Background:<br />I have been coloring my hair for the last eight years, at least. It started when my sister was going to Cosmetology school and needed a guinea pig for jobs post-graduation. It started small, with blonde and brown and red highlights. (My hair is naturally medium brown with red lights in it and also lightens a bit in the sun). Then it got bigger. I dyed my hair many times, anywhere from brown to red. Then I wanted black.<br />The first time I dyed it black I let it grow out. I experimented (I was 16 at the time) with a ton of box dyes, such as auburns and dark browns, and eventually went back to jet black. I liked the jet black and thought it looked good on me (it actually paled me out, in retrospect), so I kept it until I was almost 17. Then I wanted it out, because summer was approaching. I used a hair color remover kit from the store, by myself (I think it was L'Oreal Haircolor Remover). I didn't apply it evenly, so I ended up with bright red hair at the roots (like I was supposed to) and jet black hair from the ears down. I tried dying over it and it failed miserably. Finally, after a few weeks of this freakish hair, I called my sister.<br />She chided me for using box dye, and over the next several months, we tried using Salon quality \\"color correction\\". Each time we used it, my hair got even more damaged and lightened only a very little bit. Finally I let her cut off several inches of my precious long hair as she said the only way I was going to get out the black was to let it grow out. So I began the process of growing it out. Periodically over the next two years, we added some brown and red highlights to try and lighten it up. I also experimented with a semi-permanent brown dye, which I found out permanently darkened my ends. However, I finally got to the point, after a year or two, where my hair was a little multi-colored, but it was a lot more brown/red, like my natural color.<br /><br />THE MISTAKE:<br />A few months ago, I took the nostalgia-related plunge to dye my hair dark again. Not black, but dark brown. (I know, I know, after everything I went through!). My hair was finally healthy again, since I stopped abusing it with all-over color. So, I went to my local salon and had my hair dyed (a level 3, I think). It came out darker than I expected, but I just shrugged my shoulders, knowing it would lighten up a few days after the salon. However, a couple weeks later, I saw that it was still super dark. It seriously paled me out. To boot, my hair was also damaged and breaking once again!<br /><br />THE DECISION:<br />One night, I was laying in bed unable to fall asleep. I decided that I really wanted my hair back to its natural state. My boyfriend agreed, saying, \\"As long as I've known you, I've never really seen your natural hair color.\\" I got up, went on the computer, and researched my options. I only wanted to use bleach as a last resort, and I didn't want to spend the money on the salon \\"attempt\\" to correct my color (since it failed so miserably in the past). I also didn't want to contact my sister, who hadn't known I had dyed my hair dark again, because I knew she'd berate me for making the mistake. Finally I read the reviews for both ColorZap and ColorOops. There were more good reviews for ColorOops, so at 3:30 in the morning, I headed to Walmart.<br /><br />COLOR OOPS:<br />I bought two boxes because I have hair down to my breasts and it's pretty thick. However, I only ended up using one because I felt my hair was saturated enough and wanted to minimize damage. People are right, it DOES stink like rotten eggs...but that is bearable. I also did a strand test and decided that 20 minutes would be an appropriate time to let the product sit. I found the application to be a little messy, but then again I applied it myself. I also bought a wide-toothed combto make sure it was distributed evenly, AND Aussie's 3 Minute Miracle (always, ALWAYS my deep conditioner of choice).<br />I let the product sit for twenty minutes, after I made sure it was properly rubbed into my ends. I shampooed for about 3 minutes straight and rinsed for twenty. Then shampooed again for another 3 minutes and rinsed for another 5-7 minutes (these are approximates). I got out of the shower, and even when my hair was sopping wet, I could tell it was lighter. I let it air-dry to minimize damage. I was SURPRISED!<br />The color had completely drained out of my ends (a miracle considering all the abuse they took over the last few years). My hair looked like it was indeed my natural hair color, or close to it. Although, it DID turn out a little brassy, but that was OK with me. My hair didn't feel like it was damaged much more, but I could tell some of my hair did break off. However, I do have impatience and a heavy hand with a comb.<br /><br />All in all, I am VERY pleased with this product. I feel like it removed years of hair color, even though it said it wouldn't. I didn't even have to use the second box, although I waited a few days before making that decision. People warned that hair darkened up after a few days...my hair didn't seem to darken up very much at all. I didn't dye over it, because I feel my hair color now is fabulous.<br /><br />Also, I vow that I will never dye my hair again. Highlights are a miniscule possibility. I just want my normal, healthy hair back. I believe that, with Color Oops, I am a lot closer to achieving that.<br /><br />***EDIT***<br />After a week or two I did notice that my hair darkened back up a little bit, so I repeated the process with the second box of Color Oops. My hair was lighter again and it did darken up again a bit more. However, that's expected since I played around a lot with black hair dye prior to using this product. I feel like it took out the majority of the dye but NOT all of it. Still pleased though - it's not a miracle but it still does a great job.

I watched a few videos and debated on it for a few hours because I was scared that the patches of redish brown would still be lighter on top of the rest of my mostly black hair...<br /><br />I thought well just try it and if it's that bad, go get it fixed professionally. Lets just say I'm SO glad I tried this before going to a salon. It STRIPPED ALL of my JET BLACK hair which accumulated in the last 6-7 years AND there were NO PATCHES OF MISMATCHED COLORS from a bad hair dye job done just HOURS before Color Oops!!<br /><br />I read and watched in the reviews that it is lighter on the top and gradually gets darker towards the end, but if you dye it, the color attaches so well that it'll be a great fix (which is what I did in high school and I personally found that to be TRUE, I re-dyed my hair after color oops in high school and it worked AMAZING. My hair turned out even) BUT THIS TIME .. I will NOT be dying it. It did something REALLY cool to my hair where it REVERSE OMBRE my hair!! I love it. Lighter brown at the top and it EVENLY and GRADUALLY gets into this really pretty medium brown.<br /><br />Overall, what they say is true. Mix your bottles, put it on your hair EVENLY and take it upon yourself to make sure your hair is fully covered, wait 20 minutes (i was told by a friend to wait for as long as you like the shade..but i didn't see the need to test the instructions) and make sure you wash and shampoo your hair out 3-4 times for 5 minutes or so at a time because if you don't your hair will darken (those bad review people should have read the entire instructions sheet) I blow dried AND straightened my hair after the bad dye job AND color oops and my hair is still VERY healthy. No breakage or split ends!!
