Ill just go straight for the stripper.
  362. Most of the negative reviews I have read seem to be due to a misunderstanding of what they are getting as well as a lack of general knowledge as to how the coloring process affects your hair in general. If you dye your blonde hair darker, and then use this product,you most likely are not going to end up back you your pre dyed hair. It doesn't work like that.Dye that uses a developer (as most dyes do) actually lifts your hair to open the shaft for the molecules to penetrate and thus deposit color,, so it usually is not back to &#34;normal&#34;, just whatever the result is from the process minus the pigment..so not your natural hair, and possibly not even something that looks like your natural hair. Don't expect to rinse it and have a beautiful color, as this usually isn't the case either..it is a color remover, it does not tint your hair to a more acceptable shade suited more to your tastes..that is what you do after this remover does it's job with additional dye. It is simply removes the color. Even with a ton of rinsing (which you HAVE to do), if you are trying to rid yourself of a dark base, it will darken slightly, as it is next to impossible to remove all color (no matter what product you use!) unless you bleach it out, which is a whole different process. As for the smell, well that is simply chemistry, it is a sulfur based, and sulfur is what actually deoxidizes the pigment, so yes, it smells bad, but is necessary, so honestly, I don't see it as a negative as opposed to a necessary evil .It does not linger much longer then 24 hours, usually. (those of us who have used perms in the past..it is no where near as strong as that smell, thank goodness!) It is watery, but I feel like knowing this ahead of time is winning the battle, as I really didn't have an issue applying it to my hair at all without dripping it everywhere. Lastly, use caution when re applying dye, and try for 1-2 shades lighter than your desired shade, as well as really keeping an eye on the development, as it takes significantly less time to develop then usual. A warmer color is generally recommended, as hair treated with oops tends to pull ash, or cool..so I would really recommend a strand test before applying more color to your whole head, just in case. This is a wonderful product, but one must really be realistic and have some working knowledge of how hair coloring and processing works to prevent disappointment.velopment, as it takes significantly less time to develop then usual. A warmer color is generally recommended, as hair treated with oops tends to pull ash, or cool..so I would really recommend a strand test before applying more color to your whole head, just in case. This is a wonderful product, but one must really be realistic and have some working knowledge of how hair coloring and processing works to prevent disappointment.

  364. Didn't do what I needed, I needed it to help remove blue, but the instructions do say it's not intended for purple, blue, or green type colors. Would have been helpful if sellers would have included that.
  365. Decided to darken my blonde summer hair after the blonde turned brassy and almost yellow in color. I decided to go with a dark blonde color. After coloring it my hair turned black but it wasn't all black it was patchy some light colors and some black colors. So I figured I would recolor my hair to a medium blonde. Did that and it was a little lighter but still on the black side. Again I went and bought a Medium blonde and after that color was finished I still was not happy.<br /><br />I decided to research the internet to see if there was a product out there to remove the black from my hair. I came across this product and thank god I did. After using it my color returned to my natural hair color. Very happy with this product I would definetly recommend.

  367. So, my 19 year old daughter decided to dye her hair. To set up the scene: She has/had beautiful long (mid back), thick natural blonde hair with many colours of natural highlights ranging from ultra blonde to golden brown. She has had the bottom layer of hair at the back dyed black for several years and loves it that way. A friend of hers graduated from Beauty school and my daughter asked her to dye her hair. Long story short...it did not turn out as expected. The result was an unnatural dark purple that did not suit her skin colouring at all. Some mothers out there will know how this feels and when my daughter said, \\"Mom, it's only hair.\\" I nearly broke down and cried. All these years of babying this blonde mass of hair with expensive conditioners and salon treatments...out the door. Since the girl who did it is trained, she was able to obtain full strength professional oxidative (not direct)hair dye and mixed it herself. So, I started to do the research. I found Color Oops and researched some more. I made calls to salons and was prepared to spend a lot of money ($200-300) to have the color removed. None of the salons I called used a product such as Color Oops and altho they claimed their process was peroxide/bleach free, it would still wreak havoc on her hair and would have to be re-dyed. Not all of the reviews indicated that Color Oops worked, but I could not find any that actualy said it damaged the hair. I found an article that explained the difference between all of the procedures and decided to try Color Oops at home. Hopefully amazon won't remove this link... [...] After reading all the reviews and the info on the Developlus website, this is how we proceeded: 1) Purchased 2 boxes of Color Oops (since this was an emergency, couldn't order from Amazon. In Canada, the most common store to find the product is Rexall or PharmaPlus. The Extra Strength was 12.99 CAD), detangling wide tooth comb, protein rich conditioner (Bed Head) and just in case, a clairol hair dye, As recommended, a shade lighter than her original hair colour and in a Warm/Neutral shade. (sorry, another side note...did this on a Saturday. Called the Hair Colour hotlines from the pharmacy to figure out what colour I would need. The only one open was Clairol! Garnier and L'Oreal seem to be closed on weekends) 2) Convinced my daughter that we had to do this...by now it was 5 days after the dye job. - Prepped the hair by combing the knots out, got everything ready - Mixed the first box and started applying from the roots quickly and evenly and used the comb to make sure the stuff was well distributed. It does stink, but it is not overwhelming. -She has too much hair for 1 box, so I mixed the next formula and continued applying -Loosely knotted her hair under the enclosed shower cap and started timing for 20 minutes (max recommended). We warmed up the house and stayed away from drafts. BTW, we did not do strand tests since my daughter is a little stubborn that way. I would not recommend this; we were extremely lucky. - She stepped in the shower, rinsed, shampooed and rinsed for ALMOST 20 minutes. I wanted her to do another shampoo and 5 minute rinse and she claimed she had, but only 4 minutes elapsed from the time of the first rinse and her stepping out of the shower stall, claiming impatience. Her hair felt quite swollen at that point and appeared almost white. - Applied protein rich conditioner and put her hair under the shower cap for about an hour. - Rinsed once again and the colour had darkened slightly, to what looked like a strawberry blonde. -Several days later...her hair looks almost as it did before she dyed it. There is a slight strawberry tinge but no one has even noticed it. Even some of her highlights are back. The protein conditioner seemed to do the trick and her hair does not appear dry at all. She has not washed it since the reversal so that her hair can heal a bit. I am simply amazed with the results. She has no need to re-dye it at all. The portion of her hair that was dyed black, is a warm brown colour, but blends with the rest of the hair. She will re-dye it black soon, so it`s not an issue. I would definitely use this product again. But I hope I don`t have to.
  368. Normally, I don't write reviews but I was so amazed from the results, I just had to share them. The History: I had wanted to go a little darker and ended up dying my hair a natural black using Revlon Colorsilk. Big Mistake. Don't get me wrong, It's a great product but for some reason it looked like I dyed my hair with a black shoe polish. It was so dark it looked fake..not to mention I'm over 30 and Jet black over 30 yrs old is a big no-no it made me look older and tired looking. The color I had prior to the black dye was like a washed up brown (from a previous dye). I elected to go darker because from my experience dark hair looks healthier. Three weeks later, I was desperate to reverse the black dye and couldn't afford to use a bleach because I have limp, weak,very thin and even thinning hair. So after doing research and reading all the mixed reviews, Scared and all I took a chance on Color Oops because of the advertised no bleach or ammonia ingredients. Yes, it has a funky odor and it lingers in your hair until the 2nd wash but the smell is really not that serious as some people claim and its worth enduring for the results. You have to follow the instructions on the box to the T and that includes rinsing your hair for 20 minutes. I used clarifying shampoo and a deep conditioner because I read on a few reviews it tends to leave your hair dry. THE RESULTS: Shocked! My hair is in better condition than before and it looks healthier..and possibly even a little thicker and stronger than before!! As for the color, My hair turned into a color I cant describe... a Light- warm-brown-with hints of caramel color through out my hair. I love the new color and It brightens my face. I didn't need to dye my hair again. People have commented on how good the color looks on me and how rejuvenated I look. The results might be different for other hair colors like blue, purple, pink.. but I highly recommend Color Oops for black hair removal.

  371. A few days before, I had made a terrible mistake and attempted an at home highlight job. Needless to say, my highlights came out orange, so I dyed my hair a medium brown to cover over the terrible mess. Unfortunately, the color came out Black and I was horrified. I tried everything to fade the color, ranging from a dozen showers and loads of Prell shampoo. Nothing helped. As a last ditch attempt, I purchased 2 bottles of the Extra Strength Color Oops for my fairly long hair (that hits a few inches below the shoulders.) I followed the directions, left it on for 20 minutes, washed my hair for 25 minutes, and hopped out of the shower. I didn't care about getting my hair back to its original color at this point, which obviously couldn't be done because of my \\"highlights.\\" I just wanted to be able to redye my hair a medium brown color like I originally intended. So, after the shower, the top half of my hair was orange all over, and the bottom was a deep dark brown. Almost in tears, I ran Color Filler throughout my hair and let it set for 20 mins. I then applied demi-permanent dark blonde heavily on my roots and lightly throughout the ends of my hair. After 3 minutes I jumped in the shower. I was terrified to come out, but low and behold, my hair was the medium brown color I intended it to be all over. Pretty evenly. My hair is still severally shades darker than my natural color, but several shades lighter than the original pitch black. Color Oops helped me---It didn't get all of the dye out of my hair, especially at the ends, but it was better than nothing. I have learned that I will never color my hair at home again, and am saving it to the professionals! But, thanks Color Oops. You helped my hair look normal. Here's hoping my hair can be natural once again in a year or so.

  375. So I had been dyeing my hair black for almost two years and started to get sick of it. IT WORKED! It smells awful and kinda dried out my hair a little, but it pulled the black ALL the way out..... But one thing that kinda sucked was that I had SO many layers of black on my hair as you got towards the ends of my hair that the ends were a DARK brown and as you went up to my roots it faded to a lighter brown....... so it wasn't an even color..... but I'm adventurous and didn't really mind it (I ended up JUST dyeing my roots a medium blonde so my hair went from dark brown at the tips, medium in the middle to light brown/blonde at my roots)....... I got a lot of compliments with that hair color! :P One thing I'd say is it DOESN'T bring your hair TOTALLY back to it's normal color....... but it DOES lift DARK colors out pretty well. If you have black in your hair, expect to see some shade of brown........ This will give you a nice palette to start fresh with. I'd say after you use it let your hair \\"Rest\\" for a couple of days (maybe even a whole week) before you do anything else to it! AND, RINSE RINSE RINSE RINSE! (your hair is guna smell either way, but if you rinse enough it won't be that bad!)

  380. I want to warn everyone that this is not a miracle treatment, especially if you have layers and layers of dark dye that you've built up over time. However it does lighten your hair up a shade or two.<br /><br /> I have been dying my hair a dark brown for over a year (I have naturally light brown hair) and it has always turned out VERY dark, almost black. I have also been dying color over color. I decided recently that I wanted my natural color back. Of course I wanted to avoid bleach, so at first I tried the DIY vitamin C paste that you can find on the Internet. That worked to some extent but I wasn't getting enough color out. So I decided to try this.<br /><br />When you first mix the treatment together, it doesn't really smell. But when you put it on your hair? It smells like something died. I don't know what that smells like but I'm sure it smells equivalent. However, the smell fades quickly and you won't smell it after you wash in a few days. Just to be safe, don't do this treatment if you have house guests coming the same day because your house will stink like rotten eggs.<br /><br />The important part about the rinsing process is keeping the water hot so your hair cuticles stay open (I believe that's the right terminology) and rinse, rinse, rinse! I rinsed for 25 minutes and shampooed 4 times total, every 5 minutes or so. Afterwards your hair will be crinkly and dry but it's nothing a good conditioner can't fix. Leave the conditioner in for 30 minutes and your hair will feel great again.<br /><br />As for the results, yes it pulled a good deal of color out. However my hair is still dark. I would have to do this several times to get close to my natural color.
  381. I have long thick hair (mid of shoulder blade). My original hair color is a shade of black but I've been lightening my color in all shades of brown for 15 years. I decided to dye my hair black again and it came out like a wig. It was horrible. I decide to try Color Oops. I waited two weeks, but after reading the reviews, I decided to buy two extra strength boxes (smart move because I ended up using both). I followed the directions to the T, making sure to wash out my hair for the full time limit (extremely important). I expected the water to run black but it ran clear. For the first two days my hair color was a dark brown with tints of red. Don't freak out! Try not to dye hair right after. Go several days and use a high protein conditioner and leave in hair for 30 mins to fill the pores so when you dye it it's closer to the box results. It fills the pores and gets rid of the redness. If you do decide to dye your hair right after using the product, go with a shade lighter than intended to get the intended result. The product reaks of sulfur, but goes away several days. Btw...there was NO damage to my hair. Apparently the product only attaches itself to the hair dye and shrinks the dye color. This product is amazing!!!
  382. I dye my hair frequently - naturally it is a medium, mousy brown, but I color it a medium golden brown and have been for years. I decided I wanted to dry a little darker for fall, but it came out a purple-y black. A friend of mine recommended Color Oops. I will say this. It absolutely took the dark dye out of my hair. However, it did leave me with brassy blonde hair. Never in my life have I been blonde, and this is NOT a good look on me! I was prepared for this though, and had a box of light brown dye on standby. I left the brown dye in for only 5 minutes (your hair gets very porous after using Oops) and after rinsing, I was pretty much back to normal. The roots of my hair are a little lighter, but at least I don't have pitch black or brassy blonde hair anymore! Overall, I suppose I would recommend Oops as long as you understand that it very much has the potential to turn your hair brassy blonde and you should probably have a box of dye ready for after you wash the old color out! My hair does not feel damaged at all, it's very soft, but I did condition like crazy after removing the color and adding the new color.
  383. I am a hair coloring addict. I constantly change my color, from blonde to red to brown and back again. When I started dying my hair over 10 years ago, the only way you could go from dark to light was my bleaching you hair. Not anymore! When I want to go from red or brown back to blonde (usually my color of choice) I turn to Color Oops. It has never failed me!! Depending on your starting shade, the color you end up with after Color Oops will be anything from brassy blonde to strawberry to light golden blonde. Either way, the color is easy to cover over. It does stink, but it's a small price to pay for what you get! It is also extremely important that you rinse your hair for the required 15-20 minutes, or your hair might darken over the next few days. All in all, color oops is a miracle!
  384. My hair history: I have been dying my hair black since I was probably 15, I am now 26. I have used many different brands and many shades of black, as well as some crazy urges where I bleached out my hair and dyed it red, only to dye it black again. My hair has gone through the wringer, and after reading about the loop holes in the FDA the hair dye companies weasel thru and how unsafe and cancer causing the stuff is, I am done with commercial hair dyes. Nothing but henna now. My experience with Color OOPs: My results were minimal, though for me, satisfactory. It only stripped the most recent dye job that was done within about 4 months prior. The old hair dye was woefully untouched, though I could see it had been lightened. The stuff that was stripped away though had turned a pretty vibrant coppery red color. Lucky for me it is a flattering color and I like it, but for someone who doesn't make a good red head, this can be potentially distressing. Bleaching with blonde dye however will net the same result on initial application, so at least color oops is less harmful. Really though, old black hair dye is going to be really hard to remove and it will take several applications. Some things I really didn't like: The smell. This has a god awful smell to it, like the bowels of Hell, all sulphur and sickly chemical smell. I could NOT get the smell out of my hair to save my life and my whole place smelled strongly of it even after opening all the windows to air the stench out. I am not a big baby about smells either, but this was very strong and very hard to get rid of. Even after washing my hair several times over the course of a week I still ended up getting whiffs of it's sulpheric smell day to day. I think it took about two weeks before I stopped smelling it altogether. Needless to say, even though it fades, your hair will not smell the best for a couple days. Conclusion: After seeing what little this did for my hair, I just decided to let it grow out. Sad to say, unless you are willing to subject your hair to numerous bleachings and turning it carrot red, it's best to just let nature take her course in growing it. I had to dye my hair a brown as close to my natural as possible to blend the red spots back in, thus defeating the purpose. I do not recommend this to old dyers, but if your black hair dye was very recent and you don't have old dye in your hair, you probably will get much better results.

  387. I just wanted to see if I could remove several years of color build-up. I chose Color Oops over a similar product because the Color Oops had better reviews.<br /><br />Be sure to plan this for a day when you can be at home all day-put dinner in the crock pot so you don't have to worry about that! I started the process at 12:50pm and finished at about 2:45 pm-and have not yet dried my hair.<br /><br />Since I have used products lighter than my natural color, I did not expect to see a big difference. However, once I started rinsing, the water was running dark red. I rinsed for 20 minutes and then shampooed and rinsed for another 5 minutes as directed. Still the water had color so I shampooed and rinsed again. The water seemed pretty clear, so I put on conditioner. I left my regular conditioner on for 5 minutes-when I rinsed, the water was again dark red. So I must have rinsed for another 10 minutes and then conditioned again for 2 minutes. Again, red water. Conditioned again and rinsed. The water was still a little red but I was just DONE. I was in the shower and my skin was turning to prunes, so I just decided enough was enough.<br /><br />I must say, my hair looks pretty good. My regular hair dresser had told me to be careful about re-coloring as the hair will be very porous and the directions do include this information. I have decided not to re-color now but will wait a week or so. My hair looks fine enough to go out in public and when I do re-color, I may just use one of the gray root touch-up products, as the main part of my hair is just fine as it is. The Color Oops seemed to remove a lot ofthe reddish color that had built up in my hair (altho I usually use an ash or neutral color when I color).<br /><br />I have very very thick hair. For others with this type of hair, here are some tips:<br /><br />1. You may want to buy 2 boxes of the product to be sure you can completely saturate your hair with the solution.<br /><br />2. Take a comb into the shower anduse it to part your hair to make sure you are getting the inner stands of hair rinsed thoroughly.<br /><br />3. Rinse from all sides-lean back into the shower and rinse from your forehead back. Lean to both sides and rinse from the sides. Also lean over and rinse from the bak of your neck. Keep rotating these positions as you rinse.<br /><br />4. Condition condition condition.<br /><br />And a final tip for everyone: Be sure your timer is working and has fresh batteries (if it is battery operated). My timer died about 1/2 way through the first 20-minute rinse so I was reduced to the \\"one thousand one, one thousand two...\\" method of timing for the rest of the process. That was NOT FUN!

I was terrified my hair would turn orange, but figured if it came out bad I'd hang my head and go to the salon and deal with the snarkyness of a \\"professional.\\"<br /><br />I read the directions,ignored strand test, mixed it in a bowl, and slopped it on with my gloved hands. It is runny, and stinky (but not as bad as others said). The 20 minutes of waiting and 20 minute shower was agonizing....but the results were great. My hair is back to its normal medium brownish, a very slight reddish hue in certain light, one color throughout (no evidence of the growing out highlights). My roots are a little darker, but not too noticeable. I used an expensive salon high intensity conditioner after and my hair feels very soft and silky.<br /><br />Color oops definitely saved me!
  397. I foolishly decided to darken my nice blonde (bleached/highlighted) hair to look more like Eva Mendes. The (professional) color job came out dreadfully ashy. None of the home remedies that I tried worked very well (coconut oil, clarifying shampoo and dandruff shampoo), so I took a chance on Color Oops.<br />Note: I also had some grays.<br />Results: My hair came out a darker blonde than the original shade, but I am pleased with it. It is a world better than the mousy brown I sported for a month. Perhaps because I was so ashen before using the Color Oops, there was NO BRASSINESS, which was a relief because that seems to happen to a lot of people who post reviews here. My grays returned to the previous blonde, with a bit of gold, but no brass. There was also NO ADDITIONAL DAMAGE to my already roughed up hair. This product says what it says it will do, so long as you follow the instructions precisely. Rinse, rinse, rinse.<br />The one crazy caveat to this effective treatment is its vile smell; it smells of sewage! You have it on your head for twenty long minutes, then rinse it for twenty (minimum, or your hair may return to it's darker, not-so-hot shade) and I tell you, the smell lingers in your drainage system. Overnight. It stinks so bad that my husband was googling ways to remove the smell... but it can works wonders in restoring your previous hair color. The steeenk may be worth it! Besides, it costs a LOT less than a professional color correction. Amen.
  398. Yes, this got the black out finally. People. Sad sad people who dyed their hair black and got sick of it. Let me share my wisdom. You don't have to bleach you're hair. This will do the trick . Dying your hair black is like drawing with a black coloured pencil. It's not going to come off if you try to dye it another color. It may work after a week but not at all. You'll just be breaking up your hair worst by trying all these different colours. So just use this and then dye it over and your worries will wash away. Don't say I never warned you.

  405. Several people have said this, but i want to emphasize it. I didn't know enough about hair treatments to understand this at first, so excuse my ignorance, but maybe this will help another novice like me.<br /><br />If you are using oops to lighten dark hair, and if you end up with a frizzy, uneven, orange.red.yellow mess, and you want to put color back in to get to a medium color (and to smooth it out), you need to dye it twice. Here's why. Once you have used oops, you hair will grab any dye put on it. A light brown dye will give you almost black hair. A dark blond dye will also give you almost black hair. Many people here call this \\"porous.\\" What I finally figured out is you can get around this problem by using a light blond dye first. Let your hair grab that. It kind-of seals your hungry hair, without turning it a dark color, so that you can then follow with a medium color like light brown or dark blond. So plan on buying oops, light ash blond, and whatever color you hope to get, preferably also in an ash shade to cut the yellow.<br /><br />I still don't understand the other options people here talk about, like protein sealers and stuff, but i guess it's the same principle.<br /><br />I have found the same approach works for me after a strong bleaching-stripping.<br /><br />Oh yeah. Don't plan to stop at the ash blond stage. My hair was still uneven and yellow after the light blond dying and definitely needed the darker color to even it out.
  406. Last time I dyed my hair I made the mistake of impulse purchasing a new type of dye. My hair is naturally red, and this new box appeared just a bit darker than what I normally do. Despite using two boxes, it took unevenly and to my dismay, it was much darker and more vibrant than I expected where it did take(read - very unnatural looking). Needless to say, I was very unhappy.<br /><br />After much research, I opted to buy and use Color Oops. My experience mirrored the majority of (positive) reviews. It went in clear and smelled awful, with a consistency slightly thicker than water. I left it in for the full 20 minutes, then shampooed, rinsed, rinsed, shampooed, rinsed, and rinsed some more while applying protein conditioner. I applied the conditioner 3 or 4 times, because I planned on redying my hair right away. When I dried my hair, all of the horrible red was gone and it wasn't any drier/more damaged than before! My hair must have been somewhat damaged from the dyes, as it was slightly lighter than I remember my natural color being. I applied the dye as usual, and it turned out fabulous! It turned out a bit more brown than it usually does, but it's a million times better than it was before and I'm so glad I did it.<br /><br />I don't ever want to have to do this again, but at least I know there is a product out there that can fix color mistakes. Additionally, someone asked in another review about this removing pink/purple/etc. There is a disclaimer in the instructions that says the product isn't meant to remove these types of colors.<br /><br />Also - if you need two boxes of dye, you'll probably need two boxes of Color Oops. I made the mistake of only purchasing one, which didn't saturate all my hair, but it ended up alright because the color was concentrated near my scalp.

  408. I had been dying my hair red for years, I decided to go back to my natural color and used color oops to remove the red. It worked great, took the red out and I was able to dye my hair a nice light brown the next day. Don't expect your hair to go back to your natural color, because permanent hair dye strips your natural color, so after color opps you are left with a not so nice orangey-blonde color, you will have to re-dye with your desired color. I didn't notice any damage but the smell is quite awful. Also the 20 minute rinse seems like forever but I read if you don't do it your hair could re-darken because you didn't rinse all the dye out. I shampooed then rinsed for 20 minutes then shampooed again and rinsed for another 10 just to be sure and my hair didn't darken at all. So be sure to rinse!
  409. color oops is a miracle worker! I dyed my medium blonde hair True Red from Garnier Nutriesse. I ended up with magenta hair that was speckled with blonde. It looked hideous. I was very apprehensive to use the color oops because I assumed it would be orange afterwards but after reading reviews I went for it. How could it be worse?! I used two boxes because my hair is very long. The application process is actually very easy and as everyone said it does smell a lot like rotten eggs but I didn't find it overpowering. I left it for he 20 minutes as directed and rinsed for then washed 4x over 20 minutes continuously rinsing. Then I deep conditioned. The results are insane! I wouldn't say that its anywhere close to my original color but it was a normal medium blonde with huat a little reddish tinge at the roots but it's not bad enough I had to dye it again. I would strongly recommend this to anyone with a bad hair dye experience. thank you color oops for saving my fair from having it bleached in a salon!

  416. I purchased this at a local store so my review is for the product itself and not the seller.<br /><br />I've used this a few times in my life and it really does work well for removing color as long as your expectations are reasonable. My natural haircolor is a light brown/dirty blonde and for awhile i had highlights which I then colored with what was supposed to be a light brown permanent haircolor, but it came out way too dark, plus i really started to miss the blonde. Since I've had my hair lightened and then darkened, i knew that the end result was going to be a very brassy blonde, almost orange. I am ok with that as I will be recoloring my hair after a couple of days. I want to warn those people who are expecting this to bring their color back to their original: it is not very likely to happen. If you've ever used box color or had your color done with anything over a vol. 10 developer, chances are, you're not getting back to your natural/original haircolor. This thing is supposed to and is very good at stripping your hair of artificial color.<br /><br />pros:<br />- this is significantly gentler than using bleach or many other hair color removers. it is not supposed to lift your natural color. I have not colored my hair in about a month and after using this product i can clearly see about a centimeter of regrowth. Yes, my hair is a bit dry, but I expected that.<br />- this is a lot cheaper than going to a salon for color correction<br />- fairly easy to use. Mix the 2 parts together, apply. I find that the runny consistency makes for a quick application. I've read some reviews stating that if you want it to be less runny, you could simply mix in some hair conditioner, but I have not tried that method myself.<br />- quick. I only needed about 15 minutes after i applied it until i could see the hair turning yellow/gold color<br /><br />cons:<br />- stinky. oh so very stinky. you could open the window but only if it's warm outside, since you're supposed to keep your head in a warm-ish room while this is processing<br />- annoying to wash out: they recommend that you wash it once with shampoo, keep washing it for 15-20 minutes (not seconds!) then condition, wash again, etc. 2-3 times.<br /><br />Overall, I would definitely recommend this for removal of color that is too dark. I have not had experience with removing bright colors or demi-permanent color using this. Get ready, chances are, your hair will be orange or have an orange tint, but the nice thing about this is that it's gentle enough that you should be able to color soon after using this. Good luck!

  420. My natural hair color is medium/dark brown, and I haven't seen my natural hair color in years. Just in the past year, I spent the first six months dying my hair a dark brown-black, and then switched to a dark black/red for 4 months, and most recently a burgundy for a month and a half. Tired of reds and blacks, reluctant to use bleach, and just curious to see what my hair would look like sans-dye, I decided to give Color Oops Extra Strength a try.<br /><br />After reading the reviews I was expecting the product to stink worse than a backed-up sewer pipe, but after mixing parts 1 and 2, I noticed more of a metallic chemical smell with just a hint of sulfur undertones - it wasn't roses, but it was very bearable and I didn't feel like gagging or lighting a scented candle to ward off the smell. If you're a child of the 80's and ever got a perm, this smell is definitely nowhere near as stinky as perm chemicals.<br /><br />One thing I did notice was how runny it was... compared to most boxed hair dyes anyway. I used a bowl and a hair dye application brush to apply the mixture, so I was able to keep the dripping to a minimum. It didn't seem to bother my skin any, which is good since I have sensitive skin and bleach always irritates my scalp. The kit comes with a little disposable shower cap as well as gloves, so I was also happy to have something to wrap my hair in once I was done applying.<br /><br />I left the product on for 20 minutes. I was tempted to leave it on longer, but the directions specifically say not to go past 20. The directions also tell you to wash your hair 3-4 times or at least for 5 minutes to rinse. I decided to wash 5 times in a row and then apply a conditioning hair mask to address any stress my hair had just experienced. It doesn't have to be a super fancy hair conditioner. I used Neutrogena's Triple Moisture hair mask and it left my hair very soft when I was done.<br /><br />I was surprised at how well the product worked. I could see my natural brown on the ends of my hair where there had been months of residual black hair dye, and closer to my roots it was lighter (where the red hair dyes had bleached out my natural color slightly). I knew I wouldn't be able to fix any lightening effects from the red hair dyes, but I was very impressed about the removal of all the darkness and red tones. It's like I'm starting from scratch again. I will note that the bathroom had a faint lingering chemical smell to it, but it was easy to get rid of by burning a little scented Febreze candle for a couple of hours. Thankfully, there is no lingering scent in my hair. I am very glad I gave Color Oops a chance. Especially since $12 beats $100 at the salon any day!n on the ends of my hair where there had been months of residual black hair dye, and closer to my roots it was lighter (where the red hair dyes had bleached out my natural color slightly). I knew I wouldn't be able to fix any lightening effects from the red hair dyes, but I was very impressed about the removal of all the darkness and red tones. It's like I'm starting from scratch again. I will note that the bathroom had a faint lingering chemical smell to it, but it was easy to get rid of by burning a little scented Febreze candle for a couple of hours. Thankfully, there is no lingering scent in my hair. I am very glad I gave Color Oops a chance. Especially since $12 beats $100 at the salon any day!

  423. Alright. I'm going to make this as straightforward and painless as possible. Let's start with what everyone else seems to complain about - the smell.<br /><br />It honestly wasn't that bad. The sulfur smell was apparent, but no more than a blown-out match - and not even that strong. It lasted longer, obviously, but it wasn't too noticeable. Once you shower/rinse your hair, it's really subtle. It doesn't burn your nose like hair dye/hair bleach does, so I'd consider that a plus. And just FYI - I used the whole bottle on my boob-length hair, and I've got an incredibly sensitive nose.<br /><br />Anyway, with that covered, here's the deal.<br /><br />Box comes with 'little bottle 1' and 'larger bottle 2,' as well as instructions, gloves, and a shower cap.<br /><br />I'm a natural strawberry-blonde, and I've been dyeing my hair the darkest black I could find since I was 17. Bare minimum of twice a year - often 3 or 4 times a year. Sunday (01.20.13) I decided to try red. I found a deep red that wasn't too coppery or burgundy, and, after checking the box to see if I'd need to bleach first, saw that it appeared to dye over dark-to-medium brown hair (I'd gone about 8 months without dyeing my hair, and the black had started fading pretty badly).<br /><br />Yay! No harsh bleach! My hair had stayed in pretty good shape for all these years, and I hadn't been looking forward to frying it.<br /><br />Well, the box color (one of those Feria Intense Reds) DID dye my hair. It dyed my roots that perfect shade of red...and the rest of my hair just took on a red sheen. I basically had a red skunk stripe. But I was determined to be red. True, I could've just gone black over the top...but no.<br /><br />Anyway, I got online, and for close to 4 hours, pored over every review and possibility - then decided to run down to WalMart and get some 'Color Oops.'<br /><br />So on Monday (01.21.13, the day after I dyed my hair red), I decided to go for it. I read the instructions TWICE -(c'mon, people. I know we aren't going to read the 'Terms and Conditions' of anything, but WHY wouldn't you read the instructions to something like this? It's not anything you use on a regular basis, and I GUARANTEE the reason you had 1-star outcomes is because you half-assed it) - then did a strand test from the CROWN OF MY HEAD. The base of my neck isn't constantly exposed to sun damage, friction while sleeping, and the first/longest strains of dye like the crown of my head is. The crown of your head will be the most difficult to strip, other than your roots. Strand test that.<br /><br />But I got impatient with the strand test. Though I read that Feria uses metallic salts, shouldn't use Color Oops, blah, blah, blah, (BS, just so you know) I figured that since my strand test didn't start smoking after 5 minutes, I'd be okay... so on I went.<br /><br />Took me about 15 minutes to thoroughly coat my thick hair. I could see almost-immediate (by the time I'd gotten done coating all of my hair) lightening to my roots, but I figured since it was one layer of color, it'd be pretty easy to lift. I tucked my hair under the shower cap, wrapped an old shirt around it (to keep it warm, since apparently warmth is key to processing/lifting), and went outside for about 15 minutes.<br /><br />I had the Color Oops on for a start-to-rinse total of approximately 30 minutes. It says 20, but... I'm stubborn and I know my hair.<br /><br />Shower time. I'm not about to bend over a sink or tub for 40 minutes while rinsing this crap out. I used the hottest water I could stand combined with a glob of Dove shampoo. Scrubbed my hair/scalp, then rinsed for about 5 minutes (I used my iTunes as a timer, and after 1 1/2 songs, I'd add more shampoo to my hair, scrub til that 1/2 song was finished, then rinse for 1 1/2 more songs). So many reviews say 'rinsing is key,' and I believe that's right. After all that was said and done, I used a huge dollop of conditioner and let it sit for 5 minutes before rinsingthat out, too.<br /><br />While rinsing, I noticed the water wasn't tinged with any color, so I started getting nervous. I figured if the color was going to 'rinse out,' then my water should be pretty funky-colored, right? But nope. My hair also didn't feel fried, rough, or stranger-than-usual. It actually felt pretty silky. True, it got a little drier the more I rinsed, but never anything as bad as it does when it's been bleached.<br /><br />I was in the shower until my hot water ran out - about 40 minutes No messing around and washing my body, shaving my legs, etc. I lathered, rinsed, and repeated. Sure, I danced around and sang to myself, but you can only count tiles so many times, dangit!<br /><br />End result -<br /><br />I went from red-fading-to-black to blonde-fading-to-auburn. I didn't expect such noticeable results - especially not where my hair was still super dark brown/black, but I couldn't've been more wrong. HUGE results. Completely and utterly different.<br /><br />Not only did it remove the red, but it removed YEARS of black dye. My hair isn't completely fried, nor is it orange. It may need some TLC, but it's nowhere near as horrible as it would've been, had I bleached it.<br /><br />I'm so happy with my results. I'd recommend this to everyone that's had a 'color oops.'<br /><br />Long story short:<br /><br />READ the instructions.<br />RINSE repeatedly in the hottest water you can stand.<br /><br />Pretty straightforward.

  428. I am always dying my hair different colors but the dye I use bleaches my hair. This is fine for when I dye it bright red, deep blue, or even purple. Other dye removers strip the color to a brassy orange but this take out all of the color so that it goes back to the blonde base. It is also a lot safer on hair and doesn't cause the damage the the strippers do. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to remove the color from their hair safely with minimal damage. You may need more than one treatment to remove all the color but it is well worth it. You can do multiple treatments a day to remove all the color.

Also if you used a dye other than semi-permanent it had have a bleaching agent for the dye to penetrate... Therefore making the hair slightly lighter. I rinsed the color oops out and my hair was slightly orange but I actually loved the color. But of course you can always re color afterwards

  433. I used this product yesterday and I have to say it is amazing. At first, I have read a few reviews that talked about hair loss and damage and I was a little scared to try this product because since it had no ammonia and bleach it was too good to be true. After having the courage to buy it I woke up really early yesterday to do a strand test, which I think is very important to first see how the hair reacts, because everyone's different. And after I decided to give it a shot and I used it in my whole head, not expecting much difference because I kept taking off the cap to see if my hair changed but it was still dark, but once I rinsed for 15 mins and I blowdried my hair, I begin to see a huge difference, my hair was very close to my natural color with orange tones. Which is perfectly normal since my hair has been dyed black constantly for about 5 years. Even though, when I woke up today some of the orange tones dissappeared and I was left with beautiful light/medium brown hair. I have been trying to change my hair from black to red for a month with loreal hicolor highlights in magenta, and the color was only visible in the sun, and in very bright lights. So I needed to get rid of the black first and this product was my only option because I refused to use bleach on my already damaged by heat and fine hair. Now I can easily dye my hair to the color I want. P.S the smell is really really bad, that's the only thing I did not like and it will stay for a while, but today when I woke up it was almost gone, so it wasn't that bad. I washed my hair twice with a lot of shampoo and at the end deep conditioned my hair with a coconut oil deep conditioning mask and it made my hair smell much better and it feels really smooth and silky. I did not get damage at all with this product!!!!
  434. I purchased mine from Bed Bath and Beyond. I had a few years worth of black (which I think I removed most of with a Vitamin C treatment at home - google it), dark browns and reds. So I decided to &#34;treat&#34; myself to the salon. I wanted to go a dark auburn and took the box in and asked the stylist to make me that color. And this would be up to $250 for the first treatment. She also said if I used the Color Oops at home that I would look like a cheetah. So, I left, went straight home and used the color oops :). It lightened me quite a bit and took all the &#34;100 colors&#34; I had in my hair (per the stylist). I picked a bright red to recolor with, knowing it would &#34;grab dark&#34;, per the Color Oops instructions, and only left it on for 5 minutes. Even though it's not as auburn as I wanted it to be, I'm very happy with the results. I do not look like a cheetah and it only cost me $20. And I can maintain it at home, which was the most important to me. And let's face it - 4 hours at the salon is not pampering... it's torture :)
  435. This is nothing more than bleach! It's super damaging to delicate strands and doesn't always remove the color completely. This has been my experience. While all color removers leave hair orange to some degree, this one left my hair as orange as Bozo the clown! I would never use this again. I have no earthly idea why it has so many good reviews on Amazon! It astounds me that people would actually think this is a good product. It left my hair as damaged as if I had bleached it ten times in a row. I have since found two much better products. For slight lifting of color (a level too dark perhaps) Malibu Color Corrector packets are a godsend. In about 15 minutes, it lifts permanent color one level and completely removes demi permanent formulas. It comes in packets that are mixed with water to form a soapy mixture that is applied to shampooed hair. For shoulder length hair, you'll need three packets. After waiting about 5-15 minutes, the color is lifted out with no strange orange tones. A big difference from Color Oops! And Malibu is available on Amazon. For permanent color removal, there's Vanish, which works by simply shrinking the color molecules so that they simply slip out of the hair. There are two steps and Vanish is used with heat but it's super gentle and will not damage the hair at all. Yes, your hair will still be orange and you may need more than one treatment of Vanish, but you won't be sacrificing your hair. One package works on shoulder length hair as long as it's not too thick. Vanish is available on Amazon and although it's more expensive, you won't be sacrificing the health of your hair. After using Vanish, you'll need to neutralize the orange tones with a blue based color (blue neutralizes orange). You might want to look into using Wella Koleston Perfect. A 2 or an 8 to the right of the slash mark indicates a blue base. Just FYI. I definitely don't recommend Color Oops. Based on my own experience, this is a terrible, awful product. I hate to cut my hair short after using it and it's taken years to grow back. I strongly urge you to use one of the products I've mentioned, which I've discovered through trial and error. Your hair will thank you.t. I hate to cut my hair short after using it and it's taken years to grow back. I strongly urge you to use one of the products I've mentioned, which I've discovered through trial and error. Your hair will thank you.
  436. I've done some pretty stupid things with haircolor in the past year, and if I mess up bad, this stuff REALLY WORKS. It can't take out deep turquoise or purple, hot pink etc completely, but it doesn't further lighten your hair. It leaves it feeling soft and ready to recolor, and really does take out your OOPS. If you've lightened and toned your hair it will only take out the toner. Nothing can restore your original color after bleaching, and MOST permanent haircolors (even dark browns and blacks) contain some bleach/peroxide to help set the color. You could still have a surprise in that your hair is lighter than you thought, but this is NOT the Color Oops - it's more likely the color you put in your hair to start with.<br /><br />Be prepared to re-tone afterward, especially if your hair goes orange/yellow after lightening like mine does. Don't panic after rinsing! What you see is your &#34;colorless&#34; hair, and it will be ready for and take your new tone pretty well. Whatever you did to damage your hair will increase its porosity and so it can STILL grab color very fast.<br /><br />If you have color on top of color on top of color, you may need to repeat the process, or buy two boxes.<br /><br />You'll be in the shower a LONG time rinsing the Oops out -- but the chemistry involved WORKS. It shrinks the color molecules so they can exit the hair shaft. So yes. RINSE RINSE RINSE. Run the hot water out! But if you're about to cry looking in the mirror at what you just did to your hair? YES. Make sure you keep this fantastic miracle worker on-hand to rescue you from yourself. :)
  437. i read hundreds of reviews on here and on walgreens to determine if i wanted to use this product. originally my hair was bleach blonde, then dyed over that a light auburn, and then a darker brown, and then a really rich, deep red. i am naturally a blonde, and didn't feel like having blonde roots and bright red hair, so i decided to give this product a try.<br /><br />first of all, it doesn't even smell that bad. if you have used regular hair dye, which can smell really harsh, this product certainly doesn't smell worse than that. if you use the hair cap it came with, throw the bottles away after using them, and shampoo and condition your hair, it's really not as awful as everyone has claimed.<br /><br />i would highly suggest doing the strand test before using the product because it gave me a really accurate representation of what my final color was going to be like. the rinsing is tedious, but it wasn't the end of the world. my hair was not that dry after using it, and certainly very soft and back to normal after conditioning. this product did not damage my hair the way that bleach would have, and for that i am really glad that i used it.<br /><br />as far as the color goes.... it came out a very natural looking red. think a 13 year old lindsay lohan. the shade and tone are very even. the color is slightly brassy, but my hair was also a dark red before i used this product. it lightened my hair about 4-5 shades. originally i was going to dye it a very dark blonde so that i would have a final color of light brown, but this color is actually so unique and cute that i am going to keep it.<br /><br />i would recommend using this product, and i am kind of sad i didn't find it sooner. it definitely beats using harsh bleach on your hair.

I didn't do a strand test because I was so unhappy with the color I thought even brassy was better than this!<br />So yeah, the rinsing was horrible!! I almost passed out but it was totally worth it. I rinsed for a couple minutes, Shampooed, rinsed for 20 minutes, Shampooed, rinsed another 5 minutes then conditioned and rinsed some more. I then put some leave-in conditioner on my hair. I felt completely the same! hardly any damage at all!! And all the gray and golden color was gone! Before all this happened, I would leave the dye in my hair for close to an hour.   442. Since I like may of the reviewers here read about others experience before taking the plunge and I thought I add my experience to possibly guide others as well.<br /><br />I have naturally dark brown hair, between level 2 and 3. I stopped plucking the grays when they ganged up one me any started to dye my hair. I've been happily using Perfect 10 darkest brown and dark brown for a couple years. Recently I felt the bottom portion (dyed who know how many times) looked dull black. I was thinking of stepping to the medium ash, lightening up a little for summer (the ash to counter the natural red/coppery effect my hair can get) but noticed the 1/2 up to dark brown did not lighten my hair it just kept adding pigment so enter oops.<br /><br />I did a strand test and it looked like it was just going to lift the darkest, leaving me with pretty darn close to my natural shade. I was ready to go with all the necessary tools (opps kit, wide tooth comb, protein conditioner - I had some Bumble and Bumble Deep - and a box of dark brown dye in case it was scary)<br /><br />Yes, the smell has been covered. It's not pleasant but not a deal breaker. I left it for 20 minutes just as I did my strand test. Yes, rinse, shampoo and repeat until the water runs cold...that long. During rinsing my hair started to feel straw like and matted but kept rinsing adding some conditioner as I went. After rinsing I towel dried my hair added a healthy amount of protein conditioner and some left over conditioner from my last dye box put on a shower cap and hung out for 15-20 minutes and rinsed again.<br /><br />Results...coppery reddish medium brown (all but the roots that were overdue). My hair does not feel dry or brittle as I feared during the rinse process so maybe the heavy conditioning helped. My hair was fair before the process, not in perfect health shape but not overly dry either. It actually feels quite soft - and it's shiny!! possibly the protein conditioner while the hair shaftswere still vulnerable and removing years of dye.<br /><br />I read it so I was prepared - but want to reiterate it. Because I don't want people thinking they will get their old hair back. Since all permanent dyes have peroxide to aid in binding to your hair it will not come out your virgin/natural color especially if you've dyed repeatedly. Your hair has been changed. Even if you've just gone darker like in my case oops will just remove the old darker dye and unmask what is left from the processing.<br /><br />I'm happy enough and it did what I expected. Do plan several hours and I'd recommend using some protein conditioner (filler) and have a box of color just in case.

  445. I've been dyeing my hair a blend of half dark brown, half natural black for about 10 years, and decided I wanted to go lighter. Maybe red? I just used this product for the first time, following directions carefully. It is very watery, compared to hair dye consistency. Yes, the smell is odd. I kept it on for 20 minutes, after a 10-minute-long application on my long hair. My hair is fine, so I did have a tiny bit left over, even after re-dabbing my whole head with the solution. You will need to rinse for a long time: 15-20 minutes, as the directions say. I shampooed 3 times during the rinse, and started noticing my hair feeling less slippery, like it needed a deep conditioning. That, to me, indicated that the rinsing was done, as the water is carrying away the color residue (I didn't notice the water being any color other than clear, by the way.) I deep conditioned afterward, then added lots of leave-in hair oil, and used a blow dryer. My hair, surprisingly, after years of build-up, is pretty evenly the same tone of medium reddish brown. I am impressed. It says that you can color right away, but I think I want to acclimate to having lighter hair. I highly recommend.

  450. Like others who resorted to using Color Oops, I read every single review on Amazon and Walgreens before buying a box from the drugstore. I found the customer feedback so helpful that I have to return the favor on the off chance that someone with a similar hair saga may get something out of it.<br /><br />I have ash blonde hair with salon highlights. My stylist dyed it brown with a red tone (to prevent it from turning green). After a few months, the brunette diminished and the ugly matte red tone remained. It was lifeless and dull, similar to the color of an unvarnished clay pot. Yes, it was truly hideous. I tried multiple natural remedies with disappointing results. Then I caved and did Color Oops.<br /><br />Other reviewers have covered the wretched sewer smell and the grueling rinsing process, so I don't need to. The process is an ordeal and takes at least two hours from start to finish. Reading the directions is imperative. It's helpful to use a timer at every stage of the process because it's easy to underestimate how much time you're spending in the shower.<br /><br />I did a strand test beforehand, so I was prepared for Color Oops to fail. The difference in the strand was miniscule, but I fancied that I saw a slight lightening and went ahead with the full application. After twenty minutes, I imagined that I could see faint ghosts of my highlights peeking through. Overall, my hair color was unchanged. I left it in for an additional 5 minutes to see if more time would help. If there was change, it was very subtle. Fearing that my hair would disintegrate if I left this crap on my head any longer, I started rinsing. And rinsing. And rinsing.<br /><br />When I stepped out of the shower and blotted off my fragile, yarn-like hair, I noticed that it was slightly lighter. I examined my roots and still saw a clear demarcation where ash blonde meets obnoxious red, but it was a little less pronounced. After deep conditioning, rinsing again, and applying another leave-in conditioner, my hair looked a little fried but not too bad. As it dried out, the color seemed to improve even more and turn into a warm light brown that I thought was alright. I didn't dye over it.<br /><br />Over the next couple of days, it darkened significantly and the overall change was very slight. And three weeks later, the smell emerges whenever my hair is wet or my body temperature goes up (while I am working out). I have washed it many many times with scented shampoo, so the leftover Color Oops smell is like candied farts. Sweet but sickeningly sulpherous. I am sad that I did this to my hair because it seems like it will never lose this cursed stench. It smells fine while it is dry, thank god, but that's a small comfort. I think the smell has been an issue for me because I did not dye it again.<br /><br />I don't know what chemical process made my hair so resistant to giving up all of its dye, but whatever it was could not be completely done by Color Oops. I regret trying this product every time my hair gets damp. For me, the barely noticeable results are not worth the trouble and the lingering stink.onditioner, my hair looked a little fried but not too bad. As it dried out, the color seemed to improve even more and turn into a warm light brown that I thought was alright. I didn't dye over it.<br /><br />Over the next couple of days, it darkened significantly and the overall change was very slight. And three weeks later, the smell emerges whenever my hair is wet or my body temperature goes up (while I am working out). I have washed it many many times with scented shampoo, so the leftover Color Oops smell is like candied farts. Sweet but sickeningly sulpherous.   454. I just used this on my hair about 20 minutes ago, to get rid of some brown hair dye I had used on previously hennaed hair. I have been using henna on my hair for about two years, but two months ago wanted to go back to my natural brunette color. I ended up hating it - the color was fine, but because of the henna, washed out easily. I was having to redye it every three weeks or so, and it was starting to affect the health of my hair. I used Clairol Perfect 10 Dark Brown dye.<br /><br />Not only was the box dye affecting my ends (I had to have an inch of broken ends cut off), but I came to realize that I simply love being a redhead, so wished to go back to henna, which is far healthier than box dyes. I bought the Color Oops to remove the brown dye so that I could apply henna again.<br /><br />This does work on hennaed hair, but not to remove the henna. The directions indicate that you should not use this product on hennaed hair. That is true only in the sense that this will not remove the henna. If you hennaed your hair and don't like it, sorry, you're stuck. It will have to grow out. I was concerned that my hair would turn an odd shade because of the henna, but that did not happen. The henna is still present in my hair except for the top two inches or so, as I had not used more henna in the last couple of months. I will be re-hennaeing my hair when I finish this review.<br /><br />The rest of my hair, perhaps 10 or 12 inches, is the beautiful red color I always got with henna - perhaps a little brighter, in fact. The top two inches of roots are an odd, bronze-yellow color, because the brown dye is gone but there is no henna. I will assume that upon re-hennaeing my hair, the roots will be a brighter shade than the rest of my hair. I'm not really worried about that; for one thing, I'd like brighter highlights in my hair, and for another, I wear my hair up at work so most people aren't likely to notice.<br /><br />The product is safe to use if you hennaed your hair BEFORE you dyed it another color. It will simply not get rid of the henna, it will only eliminate the boxed dye. I followed the directions closely and definitely rinsed my hair for a solid 20 minutes - do NOT skimp on this. I shampooed three times and used conditioner twice. I have not noticed any breakage - in fact, my hair feels very soft. That said, my hair is quite healthy. If you have dyed your hair to the breaking point, you will likely not have the same result. I wouldn't use Color Oops twice unless I had to, though, for my hair's sake.<br /><br />If any of you have used henna in the past and are concerned about a strange reaction, don't be. I have not noticed one. If you want to eliminate henna by using this, it will not work - unless what you used was not real henna, which is possible if you are not careful about the source of your henna. True henna will not be affected by this product at all.<br /><br />Good luck.
  455. This stuff works so well! Heres the story: My hair is naturally a medium brown but I dyed it pitch black a few months ago. It took ALL the red and black out. My hair is still slightly darker than my roots but its so close, nobody can tell. It says right on the box but just incase anyone doesnt know- this stuff doesnt work if you have lightened your hair. The salon had to bleach the streaks in my hair before they put the red dye in it so now I have blonde highlights. Oh! and I was freaking out about how bad the smell was going to be in my one room apartment. But it actually wasnt too bad. The at home hair dying kits smell SO MUCH worse!! The bathroom kinda smelled like crap for a little while....but its a bathroom. Thats what its for, right? And the consistency of the dye remover could definitely be worse. Think about it as having a squeeze bottle full of water...thats pretty much what it was like. This was all a few weeks ago. I waited a while before posting a review because I was really paranoid about the black coming back like some other reviews had said. But......nope! Im so happy my hair is back!!!! This product is the best thing ever invented.

Then changed her mind again and wanted it all out, so with a tearful adolescent in tow, I got this right before the drugstore closed. It was amazing: ALL the dye seemed to wash out, leaving her hair an appealing strawberry blond, lighter than her natural color. But now ALL THE COLOR IS BACK! It doesn't look like we used ANYTHING AT ALL. \\"Can that happen?\\" I asked myself, but I see from other reviews that it can and does. Truly weird, and a complete waste of money.
  457. Do not buy! Did absolutely nothing to my hair except make it smell and feel weird.
  458. Have thick, shoulder length naturally dirty blonde hair that I have been dying a level 3 (darkest brown) for 3+ years. Knew there was no way that this would remove ALL of the color, but thought if I could get myself a few shades lighter, then I could redye to a lighter brown. (think medium brown, level 5). Followed directions to a T the first time, but felt like I didnt have enough product to saturate my hair completely. It lifted my roots to nearly my natural color, but the ends really only went up to a dark brown. I filled with a protein filler, and then redyed with a level 5. Sure enough my hair went right back to brown/black and I was back where I started. Decided to give it a second go, ordering 2 boxes this time. Followed directions to a T again (RINSE RINSE RINSE)...but My roots actually turned RED this time, and again my ends barely lifted, maybe to a dark 4? Again I used a protein filler, let air dry, and re dyed immediately. I couldnt walk around with those hot roots...no ma'am! I tried again to use the level 5 medium borwn, but my ends went straight back to almost black and my roots to dark brown. I think I'll just shell out the money to have this done proffessionally. I actually think this product would work for someone who literally JUST dyed their hair and wants to remove, but for soemone like me who has been depositing color in it for so long, an at home remedy is just not going to do the trick.
  459. After reading TONS of reviews on this product and a few more like it with no bleach..... I went with two boxes of this. I have naturally very dark hair, with a yet unknown amount of gray. After 13 years of coloring my hair every three weeks, I decided I was going to go natural. I talked to two different hair dressers who WOULD NOT DO IT for me!!!! Not sure if they knew what was going to happen for sure, or just had a conflict of interest.<br /><br />BUT, this takes the color out of your hair, no doubt. But you will end up NOT your original color. Do not be deceived by other reviews, or optimistic. Many of the warnings inside the product (not on the outside of the box mind you) say that you will not get back your natural color, particularly if you have dark hair. What I have learned is that even if you dye dark hair dark, as I had done to cover gray. The dark DYE actually uses peroxide to lighten your hair first and then deposits the color molecules on your hair and the developer 'expands' them to stay in your hair shaft. That is how they 'know' what color your hair will be when done, otherwise it would be a little different for everyone depending on your original hair color, right? SO, if you had dark hair going into ANY other color, it will be coppery when you remove all that color. FOR SURE. (I'll try and find the right after photos and add to this). If you have gray or light colored hair, you will also end up with some off color, but it will depend more on what color you had colored it and I cannot speak to that... my grays are just a lighter shade of the copper than my darks are apparently. It will take a couple months for it to grow out and know for sure.<br /><br />SO, if you are 'going natural' to salt and pepper after coloring your hair dark for many years my advice to you is this. Let it grow out as much as you can stand it after you stop coloring before you do ANYTHING. I had longer than shoulder length hair... and I now have very short hair except for on top, and that is going shorter before I&#34;m done!! Remember, it will grow back.. but I could not stand the idea of just suddenly having salt and pepper roots with dark brown everything else and let that grow out that way. SO, this will lighten it and give you and in between stage. OR you can have the salon do highlights to start blending it in as you transition. THERE IS NO GRACEFUL, QUICK, one step solution to this objective. This worked out OK for me, people just thought I was doing another odd color job, I have varied between auburn and dark brown over the years, but ALWAYS colored before my roots would be obvious... Now in the back, all the colored hair is cut off and the shaved/taper neck is mostly dark brown and the longer stuff looks copper, it is 60% the dyed shaft in length and 40% grown out. At my next cut in a couple weeks it would be at least 75% natural with just the ends being coppery on the top half of my head and might look like that style they have now where you color the ends a different color!! who knows, but it is a good transition for me! GOOD LUCK TO YOU if this is what you are trying to accomplish! I think 3 months of patience is the only real solution!except for on top, and that is going shorter before I&#34;m done!! Remember, it will grow back.. but I could not stand the idea of just suddenly having salt and pepper roots with dark brown everything else and let that grow out that way. SO, this will lighten it and give you and in between stage. OR you can have the salon do highlights to start blending it in as you transition. THERE IS NO GRACEFUL, QUICK, one step solution to this objective. This worked out OK for me, people just thought I was doing another odd color job, I have varied between auburn and dark brown over the years, but ALWAYS colored before my roots would be obvious... Now in the back, all the colored hair is cut off and the shaved/taper neck is mostly dark brown and the longer stuff looks copper, it is 60% the dyed shaft in length and 40% grown out. At my next cut in a couple weeks it would be at least 75% natural with just the ends being coppery on the top half of my head and might look like that style they have now where you color the ends a different color!! who knows, but it is a good transition for me! GOOD LUCK TO YOU if this is what you are trying to accomplish! I think 3 months of patience is the only real solution!

  464. I purchased this product because I wanted to attempt to remove red permanent color from my hair. I want to note that I am not a hairdresser. Additionally, before I continue, there are a couple things to note about red dye and hair color removers in general:<br /><br />1. Red dye has the smallest pigments and is therefore the hardest to remove.<br />2. All hair color removers, no matter the brand, typically leave your hair a brassy goldish-orange color.<br /><br />What you get in this kit resembles what you'd get in boxed hair dye. You'll get an applicator bottle with developer in it and a bottle of the remover. You mix them and then apply it just like you would boxed dye. Word of warning though, it's very watery so it will drip if you're not careful. I applied a clear plastic shower cap while I waited just so I wouldn't accidentally get it on any clothes or furniture. It's not necessay but if you get it on fabric it does seem to leave a mark similar to that of a bleached spot on it.<br /><br />You don't have to wait the full 20 minutes until rinsing. In fact, the instructions recommend checking on it every couple minutes to see if you've reached your desired results yet. I left it in the full 20 minutes. Next - rinsing. All in all you're going to be rinsing for at least 20-30 minutes. You may think this is excessive but it's the most important part. Don't try to cut corners here. Additionally, make sure you get a REALLY good conditioner to use on your hair. No matter what these hair color remover boxes tell you, they are all rough on your hair.<br /><br />So I followed all the instructions. The end result? As expected it left my hair a brassy orange-blonde color. The instructions state that you can dye your hair immediately - don't. Your hair will tend to darken for the first 24 hours or so. I consulted a couple friends who were hairdressers on how best to get back to a medium brown taking into account the brassiness. this is SO IMPORTANT - DO NOT PURCHASE A COLOR WITH ANY AMOUNT OF WARMTH IN IT. NONE. Both my friends recommended staying around a 6. So I bought a 6A which is a light ash brown. Coloring my hair was somewhat painful at this point (lots of chemicals on my scalp recently). Additionally, because of the remover it processed more quickly. My final result was a nice medium brown. There's still some brassiness to it, but the ash color masked most of it.<br /><br />Overall, I'm satisfied with my results and would recommend this product.
  465. Okay so I dyed my hair almost jet black about six weeks ago, and about three days ago I used color oops and I am thrilled with the results! It took the color out of my hair with some damage, but that is expected so PLEASE deep condition your hair after use! Make sure you follow the directions in the box to a T! Rinse your hair very thoroughly, you don't want the results to revere because you didn't wash your hair out enough! But besides the rotten egg smell and the few days of brittle hair, I am SO happy with the results!

  469. Pros: easy to use, removes color successfully, inexpensive (in comparison to going to a salon), does not damage hair hardly at all.<br />Cons: smells like sulfur and fruit, slight difficulty breathing when applying the product (fumes?), unpredictable end results, although I got lucky.<br /><br />This product is truly fantastic and does it's job if you follow the instructions, yet the end color truly is all luck. Here's why:<br />Natural hair color: Dark dark chocolate brown<br />End hair color: light auburn chestnut brown<br />Most recent dye: Black, although I tried to dye it a light brown a day ago.<br />Type of hair: 3-4 inches past my shoulder, thick and coarse.<br />For the past year and a half I've dyed my hair burgundy brownish, then bright ariel red, then black.<br />I've had my hair dyed black for the past 3 months. One application lasted a long time, although the roots were starting to grow in and it looked strange, so silly me I thought I could just dye it brown. So I bought a light golden brown and applied it on my hair. Of course, my virgin roots came out that nice golden light brown color, but the rest of my hair was black, with maybe a tiny brown tint. My hair looked like a mess. So I purchased two boxes of color oops and did as it instructed. I thoroughly covered my hair, then pinned it up and put it in a shower cap for 20 minutes. I then shampooed and washed it for 20-25 minutes shampooing it 4 times. I put a moisturizing damage repairing conditioner on my hair and put a cap over it and left the conditioner on for ten minutes before rinsing out. I then blow dryed my hair.<br />Result: A light auburn chestnut brown all throughout my hair. I'm pretty sure because I used a lot of developer on my hair to lighten it (from when I dyed it ariel red) my natural hair color could never be achieved, I lightened it away. However, what I was left with was very very beautiful! I love this color, it was almost exactly what I was going to dye it after using this product, but decided not to when I saw these nice results! Now, because of these sort of unpredictable color results I would recommend anyone buy hair color prior to using this product because you may get a color you do not like....<br />Now, one last thing, as far as the smell goes, ya it's bad, but if you're used to using semi-permanent dyes on your hair than having slightly off smelling hair for a couple days is no new experience, so I didn't really mind.

  471. This is by far the best color remover on the market. Loreal and all the others put peroxide in their removers, leaving you with weird orange tints and hair that feels dry and crispy. Color Oops lets you lift as much color as possible without peroxide (no damage, way less weird orange tint) and if once you've used it's still not as light as you would like, your hair is bleach-ready right away, but YOU get to choose.<br /><br />I dye my hair at home often, and I keep 1-3 boxes of Color Oops in my bathroom at all times. I would never use anything else.<br /><br />Definitely rinse for as long as the directions say - maybe a little longer.
