  472. I'm a 14 year old girl writing a review of the product with my mother's acount.<br />To start off with the history of my hair color, I want to say that this product DOES get unnatural colors out of hair, even though it says it doesn't! When my hair-coloring journey began, I got Manic Panic Voodoo Blue hair dye. Since I didn't want to damage my hair forever until I cut it off, I decided not to bleach it. My hair is a medium blonde, about a shade of 7 or so. I dyed my hair and it turned out a turquoise blue which I loved, but wasn't the color of the bottle. When it faded, it faded into green because of my natural yellow pigment.<br />So I then redyed more of that same blue over the green, but it color-blended to a shade of dark blue-green. About after 3 months, the dark blue-green faded to green, and I didn't like it, plus I wanted to dye it purple. I started looking into products that get hair dye out of hair without bleaching. Most of the products were for people who had gone from blonde to a dark color that didn't turn out well, and for your whole head, but I just needed something that gets unnatural colors out of the ends of hair, and the green wasn't a ton darker than my natural shade.<br />First, I started with crushed Vitamin C tablets and dandruff shampoo, several times. Didn't do anything. Then I tried baking soda and dandruff shampoo. Didn't do anything. Then I heard about Color Zap, but the reviews said it damaged hair, so that was a no-go.<br />Finally, I found a product called Color Oops, and the situation turned from seemingly hopeless to entirely possible. So I bought it, but then I read a label on the side: DOES NOT WORK ON UNNATURAL COLORS, LIKE BLUES, GREENS, ETC. OR GOING FROM LIGHT HAIR TO DARK. My heart sank, but I though to try it anyway because, hey, what if it worked?<br />I comb my hair well, and apply it. Now, I've read reviews that say the smell absolutely sucks, but that's not entirely true, at least in my case. When I first put it on, it almost smelled a bit like citrus, but then after letting it sit, it did smell kinda gross and like rotten eggs. When I washed it off, the green had gone away dramatically! IT WAS AMAZING AND I WAS SOO HAPPY!!<br />So, I rinsed it out and it looked soooo much better, but there was still green left. I wanted it all out, so I waited for my hair to dry and repeated the process. That second time, the green was pretty much gone, accept for a light tint because my hair is permanently stained now, since it's such a light color. But the green was finally gone!<br />After much rejoicing, and a lot of conditioner, I waited for my hair to dry for about 4 or 5 hours. Then I dyed my hair Manic Panic Ultra Violet Purple, and the little green tint didn't effect the color. It turned out beautiful! So now my hair is an amazing shade of purple that I didn't need bleach for, and my hair isn't damaged.<br />As for the smell, it wasn't that big of a problem. Yes, it smelled bad, but only when I put the hair against my nose did I actually smell it.<br />Good luck to all of you during your hair journey!
  473. I read over 50 reviews before using this product tonight. I am 54, I have been dying my hair since I was 30. For the past 20 yrs, my color has been medium to dark mahagony brown. At the beginning my roots would be my reddish brown hair, then I started noticing some gray roots. Now the roots are completely white and I had to dye my roots every 3 weeks when that terrible line between white and dark brown made it look as if my hair was thin and or non existent at the scalp.<br />Well, tonight I used Color Oops and I am so happy with the results. My ends went from dark brown to dark blonde, mid way down the hair it's a med. blonde and my roots are still white. Even with the white roots, you don't see any \\"line\\". This is what I wanted to accomplish, I don't want to have to dye my obvious roots every 3 weeks. Tomorrow I will be dying the roots Champagne blonde.<br />The process was practically effortless. Yes, it smells odd. Worse than regular hair dye and not as bad as bleach. Yes, it was not a creme or mouse, it is a liquide and you have to saturate you hair, put on the cap and roll a towel up and wrap it around the cap to catch any dripping. 20 minutes on 20 minutes in the shower doing all the rinsing and shampooing. I cannot believe it actually removed the dark brown. Once around 12 yrs ago I went to a salon and tried to have them remove the color so I could go lighter, they used bleach, it turned out brassy and orangy and they had a hard time coloring over that.<br />Most of the negative things I read are about people tryig to fix a black hair dye.   485. I came back two years later to say I still love this product. After going back to blond, I went back to red again for my wedding, remembered how much work it was and decided to go blonde again. This time around I probably should have done two treatments to get back to my natural color, but the one got most of the color out and didn't leave me with a terrible color so I decided to give my hair a break. See my original review below and added pictures of the difference in color :) (P.S. this product still smells, but that goes away!)<br /><br /> I usually don't review products (which is bad because I always rely heavily on reading reviews before I purchase anything) but I had to for this one.<br /><br />Anyway, here's my color backstory: I've been dying my hair dark red (and I mean RED) with Ion Color Brilliance, L'Oreal HiColor, and various boxed dyes at least once a month (sometimes twice because red is a pain in the butt to maintain) for over two years now. I've also had a professional dye my hair twice. My hair is naturally a light-medium blonde with plenty of highlights. Back in January I decided I wanted to go back to blonde and took my head to a high-end professional because I didn't want to fry my hair since I know how hard it is to get red out. The stylist told me I wouldn't be able to get my hair back to it's natural color on that visit as it would be too damaging on my hair. I had told her to take the process as slow as necessary to keep my hair as healthy as possible and that I'd come back for multiple treatments, if needed. I didn't care that it would be darker than my desired shade, I just wanted to begin the process of removing the red. We decided to go the route of highlighting my hair back to blonde (as it would be the least damaging to all my strands). I ended up being at the salon for 9 hours, five of which I spent with 40 volume bleach on half of my hair. I assumed this wasn't a concern, as the stylist kept returning to check on my hair and saying &#34;just a little longer, it's not the color I want it, yet.&#34; Once she was finished and began washing the bleach from my hair I could just FEEL how damaged it was. She was completely unable to run her hands through my hair until she conditioned it 4 times...and even then it was rough. Once I returned to the chair I saw my hair. Half of it was platinum blonde and half of it was orange. It was awful. I pride myself on having beautiful, long hair and the ends were just fried. She had tried to cut them off before I noticed, but it was too late. She ended up needing to remove about 3 inches of my hair and what was left was still severely damaged. My hair was falling out and breaking for weeks no matter how much care and treatments I gave it. It cost me hundreds of dollars to damage my hair (almost)beyond repair. She also ruined the shirt I was wearing by getting bleach all over it. After I deemed my hair healthy enough to redye it I decided to go back to red and just live with it.<br /><br />My Color Oops Experience: This past weekend I decided I really wanted to go back to blonde, my hair was still pretty damaged from the salon experience and having to dye it red so often wasn't helping anything. I found Color Oops online and began reading reviews. It seemed worth a shot (my hair was ruined, anyway) so I decided to buy some and see what happened. I also had my deep conditioner and some smoothing serum, just in case. The entire process, from the start of application to the finished product took about 2 hours. I have medium-thick hair that goes about 4 inches below the shoulders and I only used one bottle, but I had to stretch it at the end. I did a test strip for the first time in my life and determined I should leave it on for the full 20 minutes. After playing with the test strand a bit once it was dry and determining my hair was no worse for wear, I gathered up the courage to put it all over my head. After my 20 minutes were up I jumped in the shower and shampooedand rinsed my hair for the recommended 20 minutes (and was a little worried to not notice any color running out), shampooed again and rinsed for 10. My hair felt a little rough so I applied my deep conditioner all over my head twice, then did an extra time on the ends (my hair was pretty damaged from the start, so those with healthier hair probably won't need to do that). After I was satisfied with the feel of my hair I got out of the shower, towel blotted my hair and applied the smoothing serum. I let my hair air dry overnight and when I woke up I looked in the mirror and...my hair was blonde, and it wasn't any more damaged than before. In fact, it seemed more shiny and healthy than I'd seen it in over a year (I always apply deep conditioner and a smoothing serum after coloring my hair to try and curb the damage, but it doesn't work as well as I'd like it to). Now, my hair isn't COMPLETELY back to it's natural color, it's more of a strawberry blonde, but it's definitely blonde, which is impressive coming from dark red. Color Oops does say if you are trying to get rid of more than one layer of color you will have to do multiple applications. You can do it right away or you can wait, as I am. Either way, I give this product 5 stars. It removed RED from my blonde hair without noticeable damage and without breaking the bank.<br /><br />My tips:<br />1. Do a test strand. It will help you determine how long to leave the product on your hair and how it will handle it, as well.<br />2. Wear a shirt you don't care about if you're as clumsy with dye as I am. It's got a very slick consistency and I was getting droplets everywhere.<br />3. Have some nice smelling hair product to put on afterward. The smell is awful, but it fades quickly after the first few hours and it's totally worth it. If you have some product to mask the smell (as I did) use it. You won't be able to smell your hair unless it's up against your face.<br />4. Make sure to have a back up (whether it be another box of Color Oops or some hair dye) around, just in case the color you end up with isn't attractive. If you're going to add color back into your hair make sure to have a protein filler, as well. Your hair will darken QUICKLY. I didn't need either, but some people might. I recommend a second box of Color Oops, but it's whatever feels right to you.<br />5. Be patient while rinsing your hair. It takes a long time, but the more you rinse, the better your results. I was in the shower for an hour rinsing and conditioning.<br />6. Have a deep conditioner ready. If you have brittle hair like me, it's worth it. I'm not sure how healthy hair will feel, but better safe than sorry, right?commended 20 minutes (and was a little worried to not notice any color running out), shampooed again and rinsed for 10. My hair felt a little rough so I applied my deep conditioner all over my head twice, then did an extra time on the ends (my hair was pretty damaged from the start, so those with healthier hair probably won't need to do that). After I was satisfied with the feel of my hair I got out of the shower, towel blotted my hair and applied the smoothing serum. I let my hair air dry overnight and when I woke up I looked in the mirror and...my hair was blonde, and it wasn't any more damaged than before. In fact, it seemed more shiny and healthy than I'd seen it in over a year (I always apply deep conditioner and a smoothing serum after coloring my hair to try and curb the damage, but it doesn't work as well as I'd like it to). Now, my hair isn't COMPLETELY back to it's natural color, it's more of a strawberry blonde, but it's definitely blonde, which is impressive coming from dark red. Color Oops does say if you are trying to get rid of more than one layer of color you will have to do multiple applications. You can do it right away or you can wait, as I am. Either way, I give this product 5 stars. It removed RED from my blonde hair without noticeable damage and without breaking the bank. My tips: 1. Do a test strand. It will help you determine how long to leave the product on your hair and how it will handle it, as well. 2. Wear a shirt you don't care about if you're as clumsy with dye as I am. It's got a very slick consistency and I was getting droplets everywhere. 3. Have some nice smelling hair product to put on afterward. The smell is awful, but it fades quickly after the first few hours and it's totally worth it. If you have some product to mask the smell (as I did) use it. You won't be able to smell your hair unless it's up against your face. 4. Make sure to have a back up (whether it be another box of Color Oops or some hair dye) around, just in casethe color you end up with isn't attractive. If you're going to add color back into your hair make sure to have a protein filler, as well. Your hair will darken QUICKLY. I didn't need either, but some people might. I recommend a second box of Color Oops, but it's whatever feels right to you. 5. Be patient while rinsing your hair. It takes a long time, but the more you rinse, the better your results. I was in the shower for an hour rinsing and conditioning. 6. Have a deep conditioner ready. If you have brittle hair like me, it's worth it. I'm not sure how healthy hair will feel, but better safe than sorry, right?
  486. It worked. I did exactly as it said. I left it on the full time, I rinsed and rinsed and rinsed. I put a very good quality conditioner in my hair and waited until the next evening to recolor. I am quite pleased. I had dark brown hair that was taking too much color at the ends. When I re-dyed I used a very light shade of brown. I didn't leave it on for more than 5 minutes. Unfortunately, I didn't get the best gray coverage when recoloring but I am going to try to frost it to make up for that. All in all, Color Oops did what it was supposed to do. It removed the old color and left me with a fresh slate. Regaring the smell. I guess most people here have never had an old fashioned hair permanent which always smelled that way and you could NOT wash it out and had to live with that smell for a few days.
  487. Oops didn't do much for my hair, but I'm dealing with 10+ years of dye over henna over dye, so I wasn't actually expecting miracles! I am hoping a second application will pull more. What I DID want to say is that the smell isn't nearly as awful as so many other reviews had led me to believe. It wasn't too strong going on and once I rinsed (and rinsed and rinsed and rinsed!) it out, it was just a very faint sulfur-y smell. Not great, but like I said, not horrible.<br /><br />I conditioned as usual and felt no ill effects. Probably for people with more normal dye issues it would work better ;-) Going back to lemon juice and vitamin C which has worked miracles (okay, lightened it about 2 shades, but given my hair, that's a miracle!) I love my henna, but it's gotten very dark over the years.<br /><br />I would most definitely recommend Oops to a friend who had a dye mishap or was just sick of their color and wanted a change.

So i figd i would leave a review here for the new box (i like the regular too) Unlike most products that make claims that seem too good to be true, this stuff will not let its consumer down...I'm telling you ladies, my hair is way over processed and I was sooo nervous about putting any other chemicals on my waist length hair, my next move was going to be chopping it coz I absolutely hated my latest color foul. But I took a chance, I saw this stuff while looking for the regular color oops, this was $2 less than the regular kind and i must say it is much better!! Its foams as you rub into the hair has the consistency of a shampoo and allows it to work well into the hair shaft. Aside from an unpleasant odor tthis stuff is A-mazing!! Did no further damage to my hair whatsoever.
  491. Saved me! I don't usually color my own hair, but I got in a &#34;mood&#34; this past Saturday and decided to dye my normally golden brown hair what I thought would be a hint of red. Nope. My hair was almost PURPLE. I died. I was out of town on vacation so going to my hairstylist wasn't going to happen. I decided to try Color Oops. The pharmacy only had the Extra Strength, which I understand is really for older colorings and the regular strength is for newer colorings (within 48 hrs) ~ anyhoo I had no choice in the matter since they only carried the extra strength.<br /><br />FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS! FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS! I cannot express this enough. After the initial 20 minutes, I stepped in the shower and my hair rinsed clear, so I thought ok, cool. I'm done. I did not shampoo the first go round. NOPE! I got out of the shower after rinsing for about ten minutes and thought I was ok. I looked in the mirror and my hair was blonde. Whoops. Thankfully, I went on Amazon and read the reviews and suggestions. I put my conditioner in the refrigerator and hopped back in the shower. I shampooed and rinsed and shampooed and rinsed until I was pruny. But you have to do this! It is essential. Then I slathered on the chilled conditioner and let it sit for 20 minutes.<br /><br />Anyone who says this stuff doesn't work most likely did not follow the directions and did not have the patience to do it right. I posted pics below, but I wasn't thinking about posting on Amazon when I took them, so they don't really do the results justice. Didn't take close ups of my hair before and after, but take my word for it, my hair was almost purple in the first pic! I have not recolored yet either - FYI. I hope this helps!

My pillow smells like it so I had trouble sleeping. I'm not normally someone who cares about the smell of products - I've been dyeing my hair for years and not much bothers me in general.   493. I have been dying my hair dark for years from a dish water blonde but every time I washed my hair I would watch my investment being washed down the drain. So I went to Sally's and they gave me an Ion hair remover. I had to do it twice. It left me a orangey red. I then decided to go a bright strawberry blonde. It turned out almost black with a red hue to it. NOTHING like the color swatch. The color was all wrong for my skin tone so when I came across Color Opps on the Internet I decided to give it a try. I applied the Opps and within no time I could see the color changing. My bang area was starting to turn yellow and looking way lighter then the rest of the hair. I rinsed as directed, applied a protein conditioner, sat for 1 hour and rinsed again. Over the next 20-30 minutes the hair color evened out and the bangs matched the rest of the hair. The color I have now is exactly as the color swatch. How is this possible! As I read other testimonials they seem to have similar experiences. I have no idea how to touch up the roots but will cross that bridge later. Needless to say I like the color and am very pleased I decided to do the Opps. My hair was not that dry considering all the processing. Nice to know there's a life saver out there that saves me especially from spending a fortune on color repair at the salon.

  498. So, my hair has been several different colors over the course of a year or so. My hair is healthy and it was dyed a dark red-brown shade. Nice color, but I had blonde Hilights underneath along with my natural color and I decided to go back to that. I did my research. Countless youtube videos as well as a lot of other online reviews and tips. I went to walmart and got a box, and went home and promptly applied it and waiting the full 20 minutes because I had a couple layers of hair dye already in my hair. I rinsed. And rinsed. And rinsed. Through the course of the rinsing (about 25 minutes in total), I shampooed about 7 times (with a cheap shampoo with lots of detergents to help better break down the color), and then conditioned. I got out of the shower, wiped the mirror, and looked up in horror as I had carrot-orange hair. After calling my mom and having her make an emergency run to walmart to get a box of light brown hair dye (I used Clairol Natural Instincts in 11g, Light Golden Brown...an ammonia and bleach free semi-permanent dye that conditions and deposits color without lightening the color underneath). I dyed my hair, and it turned out well. The color is perfectly even. Back to my natural color, which is what I was going for. I don't blame the color oops for my hair turning orange, because it was just an old permanent box dye that lightened my natural color.<br /> In hindsight, I don't regret anything because I'm back to my natural color even though I had to take an extra step to get there. Just remember to condition, and use an ammonia free dye (Demi permanent if your mixing your own color...just don't go above a 3% (10 volume) peroxide). My hair is perfectly healthy, and still looks and feels great. I would typically use a professional Demi permanent dye, but since my mom knows nothing about hair, I just had her get the most gentle and effective box dye possible.<br /> Hope my review helped. Good luck!

  502.   504. I read the reviews here then ran to walmart to purchase it. Walmart is slightly cheaper.. 9.99 a bottle. First, my hair is thick and bra strap length. I had dark brown hair and I used a Loreal ombr&eacute; (red) on the bottom 1/2 of my hair which was a total disaster which is what lead me to use this product. Make sure you follow all instructions and cautions on the instruction pamphlet. You will want to purchase gloves in addition because the gloves that come with it tore on both hands for me. Luckily I had additional gloves. I purchased two oops because of my length and thickness. I also purchased a hair color for recolor purposes (Loreal 7 1/2 A medium ash brown). Oops has a very strong odor - to me it smells like a new perm odor. You will want to work quickly. If you have medium to long length hair you will want to make sure you follow the instruction to comb through your hair with a wide tooth comb before applying the shower cap. This is important because you want to make sure every inch of your hair has absorbed the product. I purchased two thinking one wouldn't cover all my hair. But it did. I waited the full 20 minutes then got in the shower. You will want to do this because the rinse is the most important part. I washed and conditioned my hair with Loreal total extreme repair 5. If you have a good conditioner great but if not you will want to purchase one to avoid damaging your hair with this product. I washed and conditioned twice after rinsing out oops. I let my hair air dry and awaited the results. As I had feared the top half was red (previously dark brown) and lower 1/2 was blonde (previously red). So for me I was glad I purchased two Oops. Second box following same instructions resulted in more even blonde throughout. Slightly more blonde on the bottom 1/2. I again waited for it to dry then recolored. As with other warnings in the reviews DO NOT leave on the full time. Your hair has been stripped so it picks up the new color quickly! I took approx 2 minutes to apply then left on for an additional 2 minutes. Checked a strip and it was time to rinse! End result is a ash brown with a few blonde strips which looks great because it looks like highlights. Hair damage-- NONE! My hair is soft and looks great -- but smells like a new perm.. Only downside.s to apply then left on for an additional 2 minutes. Checked a strip and it was time to rinse! End result is a ash brown with a few blonde strips which looks great because it looks like highlights. Hair damage-- NONE! My hair is soft and looks great -- but smells like a new perm..   511. Does a REALLY GOOD job stripping the red out of blonde hair. For the past two winters, I have dyed my very light, golden blonde hair a deep shade of red. One application of this is enough to mostly strip all the red out, leaving me with a more or less yellow-y blonde left. The yellow-blonde is kind of highlighter-eqsue, so I stopped by CVS to grab a shade of dirty blonde to put over, and I was super happy with the results. From previous experience, if you use two applications, this generally does a better job getting all the color out, though I still have to put a dark blonde dye over it, which washes out soon enough, leaving you with a nice blonde, almost a hint of red. Took about 3 months after applying this to fully get my normal shade of blonde back, which is very impressive considering how much red sticks to blonde hair.

Added a deep conditioner and the smell went away in about a day or two. The smell isn't strong, but does smell a bit like old tuna fish. Would suggest keeping your bathroom fan on and door open. I also used Febreeze in my bathroom afterwards and lit a candle. Would also suggest washing your hair the next day if you do not dye it right away to get any additional smells out. I used the protein color filler and then immediately mixed and applied the toner. At about 10 minutes, my hair had achieved its light brown, so I rinsed and conditioned. When I dried my hair, it was a nice variegated light brown, a little warmer than my natural color but fine. Lessons: Toner is a good idea to adjust for brassiness after removing the bad dye; toner, like regular dye, will be absorbed quickly after using Color Oops. My hair after this whole process is shiny and healthy-looking. I am grateful for this product and pleased that I could get a nice result from just a toner afterward.

The only cons I can think of is the smell and the texture it leaves the hair. Coconut oil will help with conditioning.
  519. I followed directions which were a pain. Old color jobs from months ago were left after the treatment. Terrible, difficult to use product.
  520. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY! After reading all the reviews on here I thought I would give it a try. My hair is normally light brown and I dyed it dark brown almost black. I put this on 3 times in 2 days and it didn't lighten it at all. And yes, I followed the directions.
  521. I have gone from my natural medium brown with red highlights to black for years. I've wanted to go back but everything I tried failed. This DID work to a degree but it is not a straightforward process.firstly it would be nice if they STATE blatantly on the box: THICK AND LONG HAIR MAY REQUIRE TWO BOXES. This made for a last minute run back to the store as I was ready to apply this. On areas that had less exposure to the color, roots for example, the hair literally turns color showing it is working. The problem is that it is also a very lengthy process to do it right, they tell you to stand under warm/hot water for 20-25 minutes-that is hard. I did it all right-my hair is two tone now-the more built up areas of color will need minimally one more treatment but honestly I think it will have to grow out-even salons tell you it is a long hard process.
  522. Its good remove my black hair safely but it dried my ends a bit but it does work would purchase again
  523. For some silly reason I decided to go black. Wow did I look ridiculous. I thought I was stuck with it but then learned you can strip it out. This product was awesome. It took me right back to normal brown.
  524. I have highlights and wanted to cover them so I bought a medium golden brown to use on my dark brown hair. My hair ended up looking inky with red undertones. I hated it. I saw this in CVS and decided to give it a try. The product REALLY stinks and the rinsing part is labor intensive, but it is all worth it. My hair came out exactly the way it looked before I dyed it. I still have my highlights. Thank you thank you thank you!!!!!!!!!!
  525. if I could give it zero stars I would...this doesn't work don't waste your money.
  526. I used color oops to remove an uneven dark burgundy from my hair, and I was suprised at how well it worked. Instead of an orange color, color oops left a soft golden blonde, with no damage at all too my hair. The only downside was the smell, but it was barely noticeable with a few open windows.
  527. Took some really old black hair dye off! This is like magic.
  528. This is a detailed review because I think I have finally figured out the best way to use this, with a few additional steps that are not in the instructions. They make a very big difference. I have used this on myself and others with great results and have been coloring hair for 30 years. I really hope this helps others. These sulfur-based color removers are great but there are some things you need to know. If you are clear on what to expect from Oops and follow a few additional steps, Oops can be a lifesaver.<br /><br />Here's a quick description of my starting hair color & condition, this last time around: Long, thick, very processed hair, bleached completely in the past two months, color removed previously, bleached again, then various colors put on by a colorist at a salon, from blonde to red, all with bad results. In the end I was left with the front of my hair looking ashy green/silver and the back looking red/pink. Disaster. Horribly uneven and wrong in every way. I figured I would fix it myself and start all over. I rarely see professionals for color and I regret doing so now; I get better results on my own as long as I'm careful.<br /><br />Two things that make a huge difference in achieving great results with Oops (especially if you have several layers of dye on your hair, or a very dark dye): 1) a heating cap, and 2) a \\"bleach wash\\" at the end, also known as a \\"soap cap.\\"<br /><br />For the whole process, you will need the following:<br />-2 boxes of Oops (3 or 4 if you have tons of hair)<br />-1 or 2 packets lightening bleach powder (from beauty supply store)<br />-1 small bottle 10 volume developer (from beauty supply store)<br />-clarifying (anti-residue) shampoo or dandruff shampoo<br />-a small non-metallic bowl and mixing utensil (it's essential that these not be metal)<br />-a heating cap (sold on this site and some beauty supply stores)<br />-several processing caps (basically just sheer shower caps like they give you in hotels)<br />-re-usable latex gloves or several pairs of disposable<br />-Neutral Protein Filler (beauty supply store)<br />-spray bottle (optional)<br />-Bragg's apple cider vinegar (optional)<br /><br />Mix up the Oops per directions. Put vaseline around your hairline because it can burn. Use the gloves they give you, and wear something that protects your upper back and shoulders. Put Oops all over your dry hair, working it in well. Then put on the processing cap (the Oops package comes with one.) Put a heating cap over this. This makes a HUGE difference to results on difficult or heavily dyed hair. It is also a great thing to have for using with deep conditioning treatments. I have the Thermal Spa Professional Conditioning Heat Cap from this site and my hair can't live without it! It will open the cuticle shaft and allow for deeper penetration; for me, this made all the difference in results.<br /><br />While you are mixing up the Oops, plug in the heat cap on High, to pre-heat. Once you have the Oops and processing/shower cap on, reduce the heating cap to level 2 (Medium) and put it on your head, over the shower cap. Wait 20 minutes. Unlike what some reviewers say, leaving the product longer will NOT help: it has a short life once it is mixed and will just stop working after 20 minutes. Then rinse like crazy. Yes, you need to rinse for 15 minutes. Set a timer in the bathroom. Do it. Shampoo with clarifying shampoo and rinse for another few minutes. Do NOT condition afterwards!!<br /><br />At this point, many of us need to do a second application of Oops. If your hair now looks orange (dark, medium, or light), which it almost certainly will, do a second application --- as long as you hair is not breaking off, which it should not be. Just mix up the second Oops box. No one has more processed hair than I do, and it was fine. You can do the second application on damp, towel-tried hair. Do not worry. It's better than baking in the new color with your dryer. Put the Oops on again, with processing cap, and sit with your heat cap on one more time for 15-20 minutes. This time rinse for about 10 minutes. That will be enough. Depending on the color of your starting hair dye, result will be some shade of orange or yellow. This is normal and the best Oops or any sulfur-based remover can do. This is the whole idea, so be happy with it --- Oops will not turn your hair back to your original color. It can't. The developers in hair dye lift molecules out of your hair so you won't get the exact original color back. And needless to say it can't lift out bleach if you bleached your hair previously. The idea of Oops is to either get you to a color you like enough to keep, or prepare for a new dye job by taking out old color pigment. The orange is NOT brassiness (like you can get from warm-toned hair dye), so don't think for a second that you should put on an ash-toned color. More on that later.<br /><br />Here is the interesting part. After doing your Oops treatment, some people say to put on a developer (10 volume) to activate any remaining color pigment after you're done rinsing. I did that once, and sure enough, my hair got darker. Darker orange, that is. When this happens you have to keep using more color remover, which you are not going to feel like doing after all that rinsing. Believe me. After much trial and error, I've found the perfect final step. For me and my friends who have used it, it is brilliant. INSTEAD of using a developer, do a 'bleach wash', also known as a 'soap cap.' This does the trick for me EVERY time. This last time was no exception. Here is how.<br /><br />Get our your non-metallic mixing bowl and utensil. Mix up 1 oz of powder bleach lightener with two ounces 10 volume developer (20 volume if your hair is dark and not too damaged). For medium to light orange hair, or fragile hair, 10 is more than adequate. When this is mixed, add about 2-3 ounces clarifying or dandruff shampoo. Mix it all up well. Put on gloves! Massage this mixture into your DAMP hair. Add a little water and keep lathering until your hair is saturated. Throw a shower/processing cap on again but this time do NOT use heat. Check your hair every 5 minutes. Rinse out when you see a satisfactory color, or hair that is light enough that you don't want to go lighter or cause breakage. You will be able to tell. Don't let it sit longer than 20 minutes.<br /><br />The bleach wash can work miracles: on me it gets rid of the ugly ashy, yellow, AND orange tones left over from both old dye molecules and the Oops. It also spares you from reactivating the color left in your hair all the time with a developer, and having to use remover over and over and over. The bleach wash gently strips and takes out the remaining dye molecules for you.<br /><br />I thought that the bleach wash would lighten me to the point where I could recolor, but I did not have to color over it at all. The bleach wash was all that was needed to neutralize the weird tones, and leave me with medium blonde hair with the old bleached highlights showing through nicely. No ash. No orange. Everything is even!<br /><br />Note: After you rinse out your bleach wash, don't condition just yet. You want to first check the color in the mirror to make sure you can live with it and do not plan to dye your hair right away.<br /><br />About re-coloring after Oops and a bleach wash:<br /><br />If you want to re-dye your hair right away, do not condition just now; instead, mix 1 part Bragg's apple cider vinegar with 2 parts water, pour over your hair, then rinse that out after a minute. This restores the hair's PH balance, which will be seriously disrupted by the Oops. Follow the vinegar rinse with a neutral protein filler. This is essential if you plan to re-color your hair, and the Oops package even tells you so. You can buy Neutral Protein Filler online or at a beauty supply. The best way to apply the protein filler is with a spray bottle. Be generous with it. After letting the filler sit on your hair for 20 minutes, blot excess, then go ahead and color right over it. Do NOT rinse the filler out and do NOT dry your hair. Just color over it, damp and with the filler on it. However, for the love of God do a strand test with whatever color you plan to use. After all this corrective work, you don't want to mess up. Do not use an ash-based color. It will be a disaster: dark green/purple/silver. Try a gold and go up 2 levels! If you want a level 7 blonde get a level 9 dye. If you want medium neutral blonde go with light or very light golden blonde. Just do a strand test.<br /><br />If you were originally blonde and you are light orange after your Oops and bleach wash, or are 'almost' back to your blonde, and you think a toner will fix that and bring it to blonde, all I can say is: DON'T. Do NOT use a toner like Wella Color Charm toners that start with the letter T (T14, T10, T28 etc.). Your hair is now so porous due to the Oops and bleach wash that it will suck up the toner and turn dark dark grey or greenish/purple. All these toners that are meant for use on bleached hair are based on blue or violet or green, and are meant to \\"ash\\" up the color. That's because a normal bleach job will bring out orange/brassy tones. These are NOT the same kinds of orange/brassy tones created by color removers and a bleach wash!!! Post-bleach toners will look so dark and ugly after color remover. Trust me: I've done it. Then you are back to square one.<br /><br />If you are happy with the bleach wash result and will not be coloring right away, then do a Bragg's rinse as described above, followed by a protein reconstructor (you can use the Neutral Protein Filler diluted with water: 1 part Protein Filler, 2 parts distilled water) or Joico K-Pak Reconstructor, and let that sit 15 minutes, preferably under your heating cap. Rinse that out and do a deep moisturizing mask. Don't do an oil treatment since that requires another round of shampoo to wash out, and you want a break from shampoo right now.<br /><br />Don't use more protein after this for a week. It can make fragile hair really brittle if used more often. That means avoiding hair products with Keratin or anything else that is protein.<br /><br />This whole Oops/bleach wash process can take half a day but it is worth it to do it right.<br /><br />I apologize to those who did not need this amount of detail.cap on again but this time do NOT use heat. Check your hair every 5 minutes. Rinse out when you see a satisfactory color, or hair that is light enough that you don't want to go lighter or cause breakage. You will be able to tell. Don't let it sit longer than 20 minutes. The bleach wash can work miracles: on me it gets rid of the ugly ashy, yellow, AND orange tones left over from both old dye molecules and the Oops. It also spares you from reactivating the color left in your hair all the time with a developer, and having to use remover over and over and over. The bleach wash gently strips and takes out the remaining dye molecules for you. I thought that the bleach wash would lighten me to the point where I could recolor, but I did not have to color over it at all. The bleach wash was all that was needed to neutralize the weird tones, and leave me with medium blonde hair with the old bleached highlights showing through nicely. No ash. No orange. Everything is even! Note: After you rinse out your bleach wash, don't condition just yet. You want to first check the color in the mirror to make sure you can live with it and do not plan to dye your hair right away. About re-coloring after Oops and a bleach wash: If you want to re-dye your hair right away, do not condition just now; instead, mix 1 part Bragg's apple cider vinegar with 2 parts water, pour over your hair, then rinse that out after a minute. This restores the hair's PH balance, which will be seriously disrupted by the Oops. Follow the vinegar rinse with a neutral protein filler. This is essential if you plan to re-color your hair, and the Oops package even tells you so. You can buy Neutral Protein Filler online or at a beauty supply. The best way to apply the protein filler is with a spray bottle. Be generous with it. After letting the filler sit on your hair for 20 minutes, blot excess, then go ahead and color right over it. Do NOT rinse the filler out and do NOT dry your hair. Just color overit, damp and with the filler on it. However, for the love of God do a strand test with whatever color you plan to use. After all this corrective work, you don't want to mess up. Do not use an ash-based color. It will be a disaster: dark green/purple/silver. Try a gold and go up 2 levels! If you want a level 7 blonde get a level 9 dye. If you want medium neutral blonde go with light or very light golden blonde. Just do a strand test. If you were originally blonde and you are light orange after your Oops and bleach wash, or are 'almost' back to your blonde, and you think a toner will fix that and bring it to blonde, all I can say is: DON'T. Do NOT use a toner like Wella Color Charm toners that start with the letter T (T14, T10, T28 etc.). Your hair is now so porous due to the Oops and bleach wash that it will suck up the toner and turn dark dark grey or greenish/purple. All these toners that are meant for use on bleached hair are based on blue or violet or green, and are meant to \\"ash\\" up the color. That's because a normal bleach job will bring out orange/brassy tones. These are NOT the same kinds of orange/brassy tones created by color removers and a bleach wash!!! Post-bleach toners will look so dark and ugly after color remover. Trust me: I've done it. Then you are back to square one. If you are happy with the bleach wash result and will not be coloring right away, then do a Bragg's rinse as described above, followed by a protein reconstructor (you can use the Neutral Protein Filler diluted with water: 1 part Protein Filler, 2 parts distilled water) or Joico K-Pak Reconstructor, and let that sit 15 minutes, preferably under your heating cap. Rinse that out and do a deep moisturizing mask. Don't do an oil treatment since that requires another round of shampoo to wash out, and you want a break from shampoo right now. Don't use more protein after this for a week. It can make fragile hair really brittle if used more often. That means avoiding hair products with Keratin or anything else that is protein. This whole Oops/bleach wash process can take half a day but it is worth it to do it right. I apologize to those who did not need this amount of detail.
  529. Didnt do SxxT. Just took out the really dark color and left the Ginger color from the brown color before it. Save your money Shave your head.
  530. I am tremendously impressed with this product. I was blonde and my hair dresser experiememted with some red and the result was pink hair. Horrible and it cost me 100$! I went home and panicked and added a semi permanent. Ugly. Then I went magenta from Sallys and loved it but only lasted a few washes then turned an ugly mud brown. After that I went to have my color corrected again and another expensive disaster. I went black a month ago and hated it! I just want my blonde hair back. Well I bought 2 boxes. Did them back to back, then did a bleach wash with 10 vol developer, left that I'm for 5 minutes, washed that out added protein filler from Sallys and waited 20 min then added the color. I'm like a copper blonde now. Not my ideal color but better than everything else. I'm amazed how well this stripped the black! This was a life saver! Try it!
  531. I feel like I've just wasted $15. After following the instructions on the box, I did a test clump, and got good results, going back to my days before I wanted to be a redhead like &#34;Annie.&#34; However, after almost an hour in the shower by doing the multiple rinses (I could tell stepping out of the shower that I was still red, so per the instructions, I did more shampooing and rinses). I used all of my hot water tank's hot water, something I've never done before, even when eight females were getting ready. So, I'm out the $15 for the box kit, and for my water bill. Not to mention a lingering eau de stink.
  532. My hair used to be medium brown with gold highlights, no gray. Two summers ago I bleached it and made it red, then got bored and dyed it back to brown. Last summer, I bleached again, dyed it red, then, again, got bored and dyed it back to brown. This summer I decided to forgo the bleach/red/brown situation, and went for a rich, dark brown instead. The rich dark brown turned my hair black :( This was four days ago.<br /><br />Bought Color Oops extra strength as it has no bleach or ammonia. Left it on for 20 minutes per instructions. Before rinsing out, my hair was a hideous combo of brilliant orange splotches and black. Instructions say to shampoo/rinse for 20 minutes, then shampoo again, and rinse for another 5 minutes. I'm impatient. I shampooed/rinsed for 10 minutes, then shampooed/rinsed for another 5 minutes, then conditioned the hell out of my hair.<br /><br />The orange splotches disappeared. My hair was initially a uniform light brown, which darkened to a medium brown with red/gold highlights over the next few hours. The black is GONE. I love the color; I'm glad that I didn't follow the instructions after rinsing, as my hair would (probably) have stayed a light brown, and I would have had to redye afterwards.<br /><br />Here's the drawback, and the reason for three instead of five stars: Color Oops really, really damaged my hair. As I said, I've bleached twice in the past. Neither of the bleaches damaged my hair as much as Color Oops did.<br /><br />I love my hair color. I do not love the present texture of my hair :(
  533. DO NOT PURCHASE IF YOU ARE GETTING RID OF FUNKY HAIR COLORS. It states only on the box itself that it will not work for any blue, pinks, purples or greens. Well it would be nice if it was stated before I purchased the item. Now I cannot return the other box I purchase, since I used one to try it out anyways. Blue hair=no go. Save yourself the trouble. It smells bad as well... tough luck huh
  534. Well first it worked as supposed to - it did clear my hair off any artificial dye and I am back to my natural (or close to natural) blonde shade. It did not smell THAT bad as some people say (or maybe I am not that sensitive but my washroom is tiny and not ventilated and I was applying it with doors closed) and it left my hair without visible damaged (off course I won't say that it does not damage hair at all). I was not expecting at all that it will completely take back time and all the staff that I tortured my hair with. Overall I have what I wanted and I am pleased with the results :)
  535. After dyeing my hair red for a year and a half, I decided that I wanted to go back to my natural darkish blonde color. I decided to give Color Oops a try, even though a lot of people said it wouldn't work if you'd been dyeing your hair for a while. Over the course of the 1.5 years I'd been dying my hair, I used many different colors of Feria hair dye, from dark red to auburn to a dark brown in an attempt to cover up the remaining red. This process is a bit smelly, but my hair didn't stink after I followed the rinsing and shampooing process. It takes quite a while, but if you make sure to follow the instructions exactly, you should be fine. Even though my hair was a bit longer than shoulder length and pretty thick, one box was enough. My hair turned out extremely close to my natural hair color, and even now (A little over 3 months after I used Color Oops in June), my hair has no noticeable growth line. Make sure you condition your hair after this process so it doesn't dry out. Also, it will not work if you had dyed your hair lighter, because it cannot reverse the affects of bleach.
  536. Took some of color out, not all
  537. It works all right. Don't expect it to be as effective as bleach, but it works better if it's used sooner after you have put dye in your hair rather than later.
  538. It works fairly well, but just use bleach for dyed black hair.
  539. This product is fantastic and well worth the 12 dollars and 40 minutes it takes from application to final rinse! Background: I have medium brown hair and I like my natural color but sometimes I get bored and want a change. First, my stylist colored my hair darker than it really is. This looked great for a while -- dramatic and all -- but I got sick of it. I wanted to go back to my natural color, but she said it would take two steps: lightening it and then dying it again (total of about 4 hours at the salon) and I started to think it wasn't really worth how much that would cost. Then I wondered about going red, but decided to think about it first, again because of the cost. I ended up dying my hair myself to see if I liked red before having my stylist do it more permanently. I used a semi-permanent medium auburn from Natural Instincts. I liked it for two weeks and then got sick of it. It wasn't going to wash out for a couple of months, and I was tired of how fake it looked in the light. All that to say, I read some reviews of Color Oops and decided to go for it. They had it at my local Walgreens. I followed the directions, left it in for 20 minutes, washed it out for 20 minutes, and not only did all the semi-permanent red come out but the previous dark permanent color too! I hadn't had medium brown hair with copper highlights (my natural color) for 6 months, and I'm loving how normal it looks on me. As far as I can tell, this is very close to my natural color. I am impressed at the ease of application for the product and how well it works. I deep conditioned my hair afterwards, but my hair feels completely fine now -- not too dry, just about the same texture as before. Great product, much cheaper than a 4 hour double correction at a stylist. I hadn't bleached my hair, though, so I can't speak to how it would look right now if I'd used hair dyes that had bleached my natural color. I probably would have had to recolor it after using Color Oops.
  540. This product did nothing to my hair but made it smell really bad for days and it made my hair very porous to the point where I couldn't run a comb through it. I beg you guys please don't spent your money you will get better results by just bleaching your hair. By the way I have dark brown hair and Ive used bleach on my hair a few times and it never made my hair so porous and flat out gross. I did this process a month ago and my hair still feel dry and brittle for those of you guys that don't know what it means to have porous hair I will leave the diffeniton on the bottom.<br /><br />Porous hair is a condition of your cuticle layer. Porous hair has a raised cuticle layer that easily absorbs water and is quick to lose moisture as well.<br />That what this product does it forces the cuticle layer to open because it's taking color out and leaving it like that. This can not be fixed but you can use fillers and moisturize the hair so that it feels better.
  541. After (over) dyeing my hair black-brown (permanent) for close to four years, I was ready for a change. Preliminary research indicated I could either grow it out and cut it off OR bleach it; neither option was at all appealing to me.<br /><br />Somewhere, somehow, (I think it was when I was reading about bleach washing) I learned about Color Oops. I read a gazillion reviews and decided to give it a shot. It seemed like it would be far less damaging than bleaching and was much more time efficient than growing the black dye out. I picked it up at the devil's department store, aka Wal-Mart, for just under ten dollars (my local Sally's doesn't carry this or any other product with hydrosulfite...I live in a rural suburb of Phoenix).<br /><br />ODOR: many reviewers and YouTube videos make mention of how this product smells. Most of those who mention the smell point out the sulfur smell which is understandable since the active ingredient in Color Oops is hydrosulfite. That being said, the smell was not nearly as bad as other reviewers led me to believe. It certainly doesn't smell GOOD, but its not the assault on the senses that I had read/heard about. I liken the smell to a milder version of a perm. I am a nursing mother and haven't quite gotten rid of the hypersensitive nose that comes with pregnancy, so for ME to say that the smell was tolerable goes a long way. As a precaution, my husband took my daughter out of the house and when they returned about 15min after I was finished, he said there was only a mild odor lingering throughout our two-story home (I applied it in our upstairs bathroom and rinsed in the kitchen sink downstairs).<br /><br />INSTRUCTIONS: the instructions that are included are extremely clear and very detailed. If you follow the instructions, you really can't go wrong. About the only thing I learned from YouTube and other reviews that wasn't mentioned in the instructions was to agitate my hair as I rinsed, but I'll get into that more below. It is important to note that Color Oops WILL NOT WORK ON VEGETABLE DYES (i.e. Manic Panic). It ONLY works on oxidative dyes. If you didn't pour part a into part b, it isn't an oxidative dye!<br /><br />APPLICATION: the formula of this product is VERY runny. In my situation, I needed to apply this to the ends of my hair first since they were the areas that were the most over-saturated with dye. I pulled my hair back into a ponytail and applied the solution to the pony first which made it a LOT easier to avoid spilling it all over myself and the floor. After allowing the ends to process for 10min, I saturated the rest of my hair to process for the remaining 10-15min.<br /><br />PROCESSING: once I put the included cap on my head, I went outside to the warm air. The instructions are very clear to stay out of cool rooms and away from air conditioning vents/fans. Since it was a lovely 105º outside, I sat on the porch and let the heat help things along.<br /><br />RINSING: several other reviewers mentioned that this was the most arduous part of the process and I can't disagree with them. While many chose to rinse the solution out in the shower (and thus running out of hot water in the process), I opted to use the kitchen sink. My faucet has a spray function and I alternated between the spray and the regular stream. I also could have used the spigot in the tub, but kneeling on the floor didn't seem desirable at the time. This product works by opening the cuticle and breaking down the color molecules to a size that will rinse out, so keeping the cuticle open is key. The sooner the cuticle closes (i.e. by being hit with cold water), the more dye that remains in the hair. This remaining dye can and will re-oxidize over time, giving the illusion that your hair is spontaneously re-dyeing itself. To keep the cuticle open, rinse using the hottest water you can stand. Since I needed the biggest result on the ends of my hair, I was able to use water that was hotter than I would be able to useon my scalp. To \\"help\\" the color molecules find their way out of my hair and down the drain, I followed other recommendations to agitate my hair whilst rinsing it. I think it worked like a charm.<br /><br />RESULT: I could not be more pleased with the result I achieved. My natural color is dark brown and I feel that I was returned to that color. This product works by removing just the artificial dye molecules, and because I had been using deposit-only oxidizing color, my natural color wasn't affected at all. See for yourself by looking at my uploaded photos.<br /><br />The instructions claim that you can re-color your hair immediately after completing the Color Oops process and I would say that my hair felt like it was ready to receive color again. I didn't have my new color on hand to re-color right away, but if I had I wouldn't have hesitated to jump right in. I did re-color the next day after using a protein filler and my hair is really beautiful; shiny, smooth, and soft.<br /><br />I would absolutely use this product again in the future should I have the need and I plan to rave about it to anyone who will listen. The box states that it will only remove the most recent oxidative process that has been applied to hair, but I am here to tell you that it has removed YEARS of color from my hair. I did not have any areas that had been previously bleached (i,e, highlights) which is why I was successful in achieving my natural color. For someone who has/had highlights or who has previously bleached any portion of his or her hair, just know that it is impossible for the bleached areas to return to your natural color because the natural pigments have been removed.on my scalp. To \\"help\\" the color molecules find their way out of my hair and down the drain, I followed other recommendations to agitate my hair whilst rinsing it. I think it worked like a charm.<br /><br />RESULT: I could not be more pleased with the result I achieved. My natural color is dark brown and I feel that I was returned to that color. This product works by removing just the artificial dye molecules, and because I had been using deposit-only oxidizing color, my natural color wasn't affected at all. See for yourself by looking at my uploaded photos.<br /><br />The instructions claim that you can re-color your hair immediately after completing the Color Oops process and I would say that my hair felt like it was ready to receive color again. I didn't have my new color on hand to re-color right away, but if I had I wouldn't have hesitated to jump right in. I did re-color the next day after using a protein filler and my hair is really beautiful; shiny, smooth, and soft.<br /><br />I would absolutely use this product again in the future should I have the need and I plan to rave about it to anyone who will listen. The box states that it will only remove the most recent oxidative process that has been applied to hair, but I am here to tell you that it has removed YEARS of color from my hair. I did not have any areas that had been previously bleached (i,e, highlights) which is why I was successful in achieving my natural color. For someone who has/had highlights or who has previously bleached any portion of his or her hair, just know that it is impossible for the bleached areas to return to your natural color because the natural pigments have been removed.
  542. I wish I knew about this stuff years ago!! I had to write my own review after reading all the others, which were very helpful and encouraged me to try this stuff. I'm naturally a dark blonde and have been highlighting my hair forever. I didn't want to maintain highlights anymore and wanted to get closer to my natural color and asked my stylist to dye it. She used a filler and then matched my shade, but of course it turned out DARK REDDISH BROWN!! So ugly on me and I just didn't feel like myself. I should have known better, since this has happened before. Anyway, I read about this stuff and figured it couldn't get any worse. I just used it this morning and was very careful to follow all the instructions. I didn't do an allergy test, but I did do a strand test. It seemed to lighten it a bit but not a ton, so I decided to go for it. I removed the rugs from my bathroom because I was afraid they'd hang onto the bad smell everyone kept talking about. I shut myself in the bathroom with a small space heater, since the instructions stressed it's important to do it in a warm place with no drafts. I had a chair, clock radio, my computer and my phone and some water, so I was all set, lol. The stuff was a little watery but easy to apply -- I did not spill any. Definitely keep the applicator tip pointed away from you after you're done mixing/shaking it, because a little exploded out and it could have easily gone in my eyes. Honestly, the smell was not even that bad. If you've ever done a home perm, I think that smell is much worse and stronger. I finished covering all my hair (I have thin, shoulder length hair and was able to cover it all easily with one bottle), waited my 20 minutes and used the time to check my email. When the time was up, I looked in the mirror and was shocked that my hair looked orange through the shower cap, but I kept my fingers crossed that would wash out. (It did). I started rinsing it and immediately shampooed using Neutrogena's Clarifying shampoo. Then, I looked at the clock and started my 20-minute rinse. That was a LONG time. Then I shampooed one more time, and then rinsed for 5 more minutes. I towel dried my extremely dry hair and checked it. Looked a tiny bit orange but I figured I would just wait it out, because I read another reviewer who said the orange actually toned down on its own within the first 24 hours. Then I slathered Aveda's damage remedy conditioner on my hair and put another shower cap on and waited at least a half hour. That helped a lot. I rinsed that out and then put some damage remedy leave in conditioner on my hair to comb it out. All things considered, it combed pretty easily and I didn't lose much hair at all. As it dried, the reddish tones seemed to go away a little bit, and now it's totally dry and it's actually a nice shade of dark blonde! I wasn't sure what to expect and whether my highlights and several inches of regrowth would come back, but it seems like they haven't! It actually looks really natural and like what I was going for all along. This product is amazing!! I will update this again if anything changes, like if it gets darker or something, but for now I am very happy!! Oh, and also many people mentioned that the smell lingered, but it did not linger in my hair, nor in my bathroom. After I was done, I opened the bathroom window and put a fan by the door to air it out, and it is fine!! The smell is honestly not a big deal at all, especially if you contain it and then use a fan and open the window. It does dry your hair out a LOT so it's important to have a good conditioner. Aveda's damage remedy is really expensive but it's also the best conditioner I have ever used and totally worth it.

  547. I have naturally med. brown hair w/ about 20% gray. I have been using lush henna noir since March 2012 probably ever 2 months or so. I used Color Oops Dec 2012 and it did not remove the darkness but it did give me my old texture back and I can see a clearer demarcation line between my roots and the henna now. The smell reminded me of perm solution not rotten eggs and it did linger a few days. I rinsed and shampooed using H&S because it seemed like it was the strongest detergent-y thing in my linen closet. My hair's condition seems better, not any worse so that is why I'm giving 2 stars.<br /><br />I may try Color Oops again and do a few things different--leave it on maybe 30 minutes?   548. I am using Color Oops as I write this review, so that I can give a thorough and honest review.<br />My hair: Currently black, very dark brown, and black cherry. Mostly black, I tried lightening it with olive oil which worked on some parts and not on others, thus the dark brown in places, and the black cherry was when my roots were about half an inch out, and I thought maybe it would blend some of the black. I died my hair black about 2 months ago. Before having black hair I had dyed dark blonde hair, before that red, and my natural hair is a medium brown (though I haven't seen it since I was 13).<br />Application: Mixing color oops was easy. Both of my gloves had rips in them so I was happy I had some cleaning gloves laying around. I have shoulder length, average thickness hair, and one bottle covered my hair just fine. After it was in I combed gently through my hair to make sure it was evenly dispersed. It was kind of runny, and a little messy to apply. I stood over a towel in my bathroom and wore an old large t-shirt I don't care about. I put on the cap and started cleaning up the bathroom.<br />Waiting: It takes 20 minutes to develop. You can't be in a cold room, or next to any fan or vent blowing cool or cold air. I am sitting at my dining room table with a space heater on next to me to make sure it doesn't get too cold. Warning, this is when you will start smelling that rotten egg smell. It wasn't too bad at first, no worse than your average hair dye smell, but over time the smell gets stronger. When you lift the cap to check your hair it will seep out and you will understand.<br />I have a fairly sensetive scalp, and this is not hurting, burning, or itching at all. 3 minutes from rinsing out and this is a better experience than any time dying my hair has been. Honestly, it feels warm, and kind of nice. I've spent the last few minutes making up a playlist because you are suppose to rinse and wash your hair for 15-20 minutes after you're done. Here I go.<br />Rinsing: Pain in the butt. It is hard to rinse because it feels dry. about 12 minutes in I had to condition my hair because I thought I was killing it. I wasn't, and I shampooed another 2 times after I conditioned it. I conditioned it with a nice, high quality conditioner at the end and left it in for 5 minutes. I don't sense any traces of egg smell any more, which is nice.<br />Result: My hair is a little lighter than I expected, but since all hair color has some peroxide I can understand that. There are traces of what I have referred to as &#34;muddy&#34; hair, but much less than I expected, and in a few days I should be able to dye over that no problem.<br />Why aren't I dying right away? In the directions it states that you should NOT redye your hair the same day unless you use a protein conditioner. I don't have a protein conditioner. My hair seems to be in good shape, but I will give it a few days to make sure before I go kiling it even more.<br />My hair felt a little dry before I started, and feels exactly the same now.<br />So why only 4 stars instead of 5?<br />Pros:<br />Got all of the black out with few traces of muddiness.<br />Didn't fry my hair as bleaching would have done.<br />Was pretty easy to use.<br />Didn't take very long.<br /><br />Cons:<br />The smell isn't overpowering, but it is there, and annoying.<br />There is a little muddiness on my hair.<br /><br />While both cons were known going in, it does still detract from usage of Color Oops.<br />Over all, I would recommend using it.nsing: Pain in the butt. It is hard to rinse because it feels dry. about 12 minutes in I had to condition my hair because I thought I was killing it. I wasn't, and I shampooed another 2 times after I conditioned it. I conditioned it with a nice, high quality conditioner at the end and left it in for 5 minutes. I don't sense any traces of egg smell any more, which is nice.<br />Result: My hair is a little lighter than I expected, but since all hair color has some peroxide I can understand that. There are traces of what I have referred to as &#34;muddy&#34; hair, but much less than I expected, and in a few days I should be able to dye over that no problem.<br />Why aren't I dying right away? In the directions it states that you should NOT redye your hair the same day unless you use a protein conditioner. I don't have a protein conditioner. My hair seems to be in good shape, but I will give it a few days to make sure before I go kiling it even more.<br />My hair felt a little dry before I started, and feels exactly the same now.<br />So why only 4 stars instead of 5?<br />Pros:<br />Got all of the black out with few traces of muddiness.<br />Didn't fry my hair as bleaching would have done.<br />Was pretty easy to use.<br />Didn't take very long.<br /><br />Cons:<br />The smell isn't overpowering, but it is there, and annoying.<br />There is a little muddiness on my hair.<br /><br />While both cons were known going in, it does still detract from usage of Color Oops.<br />Over all, I would recommend using it.
  549. I had brown dye over red dye.<br /> Three different products. Otherwise this is a wonderful product. No allergic problems even tho I am highly allergic to the dyes.<br /> My beautician told me to add one packet of sweet and low to the mix to neutralize the allergic response and it works.

  554. I never review products unless I'm completely wowed...and I am with Color Oops. My natural hair color is strawberry blonde, but I had been coloring it with John Frieda 5r for about 8 months. When my roots started to show this time, I figured I would try to get back to my natural color as the grow-out from Frieda was really dark and bland. Followed the directions to the T and my hair is as close to my natural color as its going to get. I did buy a color filler and a strawberry blonde L'oreal permanent dye just in case it needed a boost, but I think I'll hold off since the color is back to normal already. I think if you're hesitant, you should at least do the strand test and see what happens. That's what I did and I'm definitely not disappointed. Good luck!!
  555. Originally I dyed my hair blonde and used a white toner so that I could use a turquoise/green dye. I redyed my hair blue, but it came out too dark. I bought this product so that I could re-bleach and redye my hair a lighter blue. When I used Colour Oops, the hair returned to the blonde/ginger colour that was underneath it.<br /><br />The problem occurred when I realized that as my hair dried, the ends of my hair (all the hair that had originally been bleached and dyed, not my roots) had turned green. We thought if we used Colour Oops again, the green tint would come out, but we were wrong.<br /><br /> However, I learned that green dye molecules are much larger than most of the other dye molecules, such as red, so the Colour Oops may simply not have been strong enough. Regardless, I would recommend this product if you are trying to remove a colour less drastic than green.
  556. I read online on a couple of forums that I could use this to get rid of henna in my hair. It says specifically in the instructions not to use it on hennaed hair but I did it anyways. I did 2 treatments and left it on for 2-3 hours each time and honestly it made next to know difference. The good news is, my hair didn't feel super dry afterward and the treatments didn't make my hair break off easily or anything. So that's good. My hair still looks exactly the same so it was just kind of a waste of time for hennaed hair. So if you are looking for a solution to removing henna with this, I just wanted to say that it didn't really work for me as the forums promised. Doesn't mean it wouldn't work for chemical dyed hair though. The one thing that I truly regret about doing this is the smell. It has literally been a month and my hair still smells like rotten eggs. My boyfriend is not happy with me for doing the color opps treatment because he's had to smell rotten eggs in my hair for the past month. Now, a month later my dry hair isn't awful smelling but when I wet it, it still fills the entire shower with that awful smell. I've tried to get rid of it, nothing seems to help but time. So if you have chemically dyed hair, and you don't mind smelling like rotten eggs for a month, this product might be good for you.

  558. My natural color is a dull mousy brown with some graying at the temples. Usually, I color my hair with Clairol's Nice & Easy and I've never had any problems. This time I decided to go red with Garnier Nutrisse permament hair color but it turned out awful on me (think Raggedy Ann). I bought some Color Oops and used it about 6 hours after the initial coloring disater. It was easy and smelled a bit like a perm (sulfury), not overwhelming. The hardest part was rinsing it for 15 minutes! But it was worth it.... now my hair is even lighter than before... like a golden blonde. Some people may not be happy if their hair ended up lighter than normal, but I love it. This was a happy accident and SO much better than the awful red. Thank you Color Oops!
